The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.
loan_use: Rice farming

description: Guloglan was born in 1960 in Salyan region, and is married with four children. He began his business 15 years ago with a loan of $300, which enabled him to buy a cow. With his second loan of $600, he bought 5 pregnant sheep. Now he is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase 2 pregnant cows.\r\n\r\n
loan_use: To buy 2 pregnant cows

description:
Farida was born in 1963 in Yenikand village in the Salyan region.  She is married and has two children.

She has her own orhard in which she grows fruits.
She requests a loan of $500 to buy fertilizer.
She has 15 years of experience in this business.
loan_use: to buy fertilizer

description: Atira was born in 1960 in the Salyan region,is married, and has 4 children. A mother of 4 children she has saved enough money to set up her own business. She works very hard to improve her business. This buiness is the only source of income for her and for her children. Now she requests a loan of $800 to buy 3 sheep.
loan_use: To buy 3 sheep

description: Habiba D/O M. A. is married, has four children and lives in District 5 of Kabul City. She was in high school when the war broke out and that kept her from completing her education. The wars had a very bad impact on her financial situation and her life got worse day by day. In order to improve her family's finances, she took out her first loan to buy clothes for her sons to sell in the market and streets of Kabul City. Before the loan, only one of her sons was doing business, which made it difficult to overcome their financial problems. Her first loan made it possible to buy more clothes so two of her sons could work and earn money. She is requesting a second loan of $175 so she and her sons can continue to increase their income and opportunities to do business.
loan_use: To buy clothes to sell

description: V. is a resident of Beylagan town. She has three children. Together with her husband she built a small shop in 2005 and started the business of selling products for daily use. When she started the business she applied to Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed three loans, in the amounts of $400 and $500. For these loans she bought inventories to be sold in the shop. Now she needs $500 to buy a new counter stand.
loan_use: To buy a new counter

description:
Mrs. Antonia C. has a business in which she sells roasted chicken, meals and refreshments. This business is located in the Villa Nuevo Potosi neighborhood, on a hillside to the East of the city of La Paz. She has three married daughters who help her with taking care of her lodgings. She is 53 years of age, and has more than 15 years of experience in developing her business. Her sales and the preparation of meals take place daily, and if there is a surplus, it is used by relatives and the family. She has been a client of Impro since April of 2000. Her history with our institution qualifies her as a number one client, which is to say she has an excellent record of paying her obligations. The amount asked for is intended for the wholesale purchase of items such as potatos, rice and salsas, with the objective of lowering operating costs. Her work and previous dealings with Impro gives her access to this credit since she has experience in her business which provides income to pay back the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Dwight Davis, Kiva volunteer.

Historia del Cliente: La Sra. Antonia, tiene un negocio donde vende pollo broster, comida y refrescos, el cual se halla ubicado en la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí (Ladera Oeste de la ciudad de La Paz). Tiene tres hijas que están casadas y le ayudan en la atención de la pensión. Tiene 53 años y tiene experiencia en el desarrollo de su trabajo de más de 15 años. Sus ventas y elaboración de comida son al día y si existe excedente es para el consumo familiar. Es cliente de Impro, desde abril del año 2000. Su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente 1, es decir con cumplimiento excelente en el pago de su obligación. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de insumos (papa, arroz, refrescos, salsas) al por mayor con el objetivo de abaratar costos operativos. Su trabajo y antecedentes crediticios con Impro le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio, el cual le da ingresos para cubrir el préstamo.
loan_use: Working Capital

description:
Amina is married with three children. She lives in the outskirts of Dar es Salaam (Capital city of Tanzania) where water supply is irregular. She dug a well about twelve months ago. She sells water to her neighbors and nearby communities. She currently use a bucket to fetch water from the Well.

She needs an additional capital of USD 1200 to buy an electrical pump and two storage tanks to effectively run her business. Tanks will act as a reservoirs and water treatment points. Water is very important in her area due to usual cholera and amoebic dysentery outbreaks. Dar es Salaam is now in the rainy season.
loan_use: PURCHASE AN ELECTRICAL PUMP AND STORAGE TANKS

description:
M. lives in Kitunda area of Dar es Salaam. He is married with three children. He keeps egg-layers and broiler chickens on his farm. He need to expand the number of birds in his flock. The need of increase in birds number is the rise on demand of eggs and broilers after he recently obtained a tender to supply eggs and chicken meat in various restaurants in Ilala districts. The increase in birds number goes along with the increase in the size of chicken huts.

\r\n\r\nM. is in need of USD 1000 to execute his expansion plan. M. also grows vegetables which he sells on wholesale to food vendors and other retailers. He uses birds droppings as manure for the vegetables.
loan_use: Working capital

description:
Maria lives in Kitunda area in Dar es Salaam. She is not married and has two children - one in primary school and another in secondary school. Maria keeps egg laying hens and broilers near her residence. She would like to expand her business to enable her to pay for school fees for her secondary school children and increase income for her family.

She plans to increase the size of her flock from 400 to 600 chickens. Maria will hire one person in her business to take charge of the increased stock. Her expansion plan needs additional funding to buy the chicks along with stock of poultry feed, medications and expand the existing chicken hut. To implement her growth plan she need additional capital of USD 1000.
loan_use: Expand poultry business

description:
Guido produces rice and corn on lands given to him by his father, with also some small production of plantains. He lives with his brother who he works in the fields with. He will invest the loan to plant for the next cycle. He will prepare the lands and also buy fertilizer and seeds. Although he does not have children, he is still very family oriented. He is very close to his mother, father and brother. He hopes he can fix the lands so they can be productive for years to come. He is also hoping to start a family of his own in the near future.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.
loan_use: Rice Farming

description:
Rosenie started to utilize her skills cooking to support her and her daughter after she was unable to find a job elsewhere. Now, she has expanded beyond friends and neighbors to now serving dozens of customers daily in a large, open-air courtyard that is filled with artisans and other vendors. Rosenie needs this loan to take her business to the next level so that she can improve her household income and provide a nutritious diet and sufficient clothing for her young daughter, who is very close with her mother - she even helps out her mother grind ingredients on Saturdays when she does not have school.\r\n

\r\n

NOTE: Luisa has many friends in the community and is a dedicated member of her solidarity group. She represents nine other Esperanza micro-entrepreneurs, who will each receive an equal share of this $1,200 loan to invest in their respective businesses. Rosenie and the other members are responsible for making payments on this loan together and must help anyone in their solidarity group who may have trouble paying on time, which fosters accountability and social support.
loan_use: Purchase cooking ingredients, vegetables, a pot, a skillet and coals, matches, etc.

description: Taleh is an Internally Displace Person from the Armenian-occupied Khojavand region of Azerbaijan. When his family was relocated, he was a boy. Now he is 19 years old. His family faced many hardships. Now Taleh wants to contribute to the family income. He rented a room where he has only one TV and game device. Many children come to play games. Now he wants to buy two more computers to attract more people to his game cafe and also provide Internet services. This is his first loan and he wants $300.
loan_use: To buy two computers

description:
Mrs. Alma Nelly is 31 years old, is married and the mother of 2 small children. Her husband, Saúl, is employeed in security, but the salary he receives does not cover the family's basic needs. For this reason, Alma started selling cosmetics and products for the home by catalog two years ago. She started with a small amount of capital loaned by her husband and has made it into a good business, thanks to the enthusiasm with which she does her work and the good relationships she has in her friendships. Little by little, her business has grown and she has been able to expand her client base and her sales.

At this time, Alma Nelly needs credit in the amount of $475, which she will use to purchase merchandise to be able to meet her clients' orders, offer good service and continue growing her business. She intends to repay the loan in a period of 5 to 10 months. Alma needs your help, and you can be an important part of her success. She nad her family sincerely thank you for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Alma Nelly tiene 31 años de edad, es casada y madre de 2 hijos pequeños, su esposo Saúl es empleado de seguridad, pero el salario que recibe no cubre las necesidades básicas de su familia, razón por la que Alma inició con las ventas de cosméticos y productos para el hogar por catalogo, desde hace dos años. Comenzó con un pequeño capital que le prestó su esposo y se ha convertido en un buen negocio gracias al entusiasmo con que ella realiza su labor y a las buenas relaciones que tiene con sus amistades, poco a poco ha ido creciendo y ha logrado aumentar sus clientes y sus ventas.

En estos momentos Alma Nelly necesita de un crédito por la cantidad de $ 475 dólares que utilizara en la compra de mercancía para poder surtir los pedidos de sus clientes, ofrecer un buen servicio y continuar creciendo con su negocio, ella esta dispuesta a retornar el préstamo en un lapso de 5 a 10 meses. Alma necesita de tu ayuda, tú puedes ser parte importante en sus logros, ella y su familia agradecen sinceramente tu apoyo.
loan_use: Purchase merchandise

description: Vaimaila is 30 years old, and in an effort to support her family, she has started a small flea market stall.  Here she sells nuts, fruits, vegetables and coconut tree fibers.  Most of these items are grown or handmade by her and her husband.  She hopes to expand the products that she can offer the customers in her village, and is thus seeking a loan to purchase additional materials for making handicrafts and growing vegetables.  Vaimaila is passionate about becoming a small business owner and is putting all of her efforts into growing her flea market stall.  She feels that this is the best way for her and her husband to raise the standard of living for her family.\r\n\r\n
loan_use: Buy raw materials to make/grow goods for her flea market stall

description: After Manzuma lost her husband 10 years ago, she started working at the market with the help of a friend. At that time, she had two young children. She knew from her experience with children that she would be good at selling children's clothes and shoes. By now, Manzuma feels comfortable with her business, and she goes to the wholesale market herself. She would like to open a second business site where she would be selling women’s clothes. Her son will be helping her after school. She will invest the money she has collected and will add the new loan to open the second site.
loan_use: Opening new business site

description: Mr. Benjamin I.. Hails from Edo State, Nigeriaand is married with two (2) children. He sells cooked food to the community and wishes to expand his business with a loan in the above amount.
loan_use: To buy more food items

description: Mais is an Internally Diplaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. Married, he has three children. He started his business in 1994, and borrowed four Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $2000. Now he wants to borrow $900 to increase the variety of goods in his shop.
loan_use: To in increase variety of goods

description: "I changed to this business two years ago and I have no cause to regret it. I am 38 years old, married with three children; my numerous customers alway give me satisfaction," says Mrs. Mabel I.. She will use her loan of USD400 to expand her business.
loan_use: To buy more provisions for sales

description: Margie is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has benefited several times from the organization. She sells bread and fried fish in her locality. She wants to expand her business and is therefore seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva.
loan_use: Working capital

description: Hang S. is 35 years old and works in a garment factory in Phnom Penh.  She earns about $1.50/day and has 5 children.  With this loan she will build a home for rental to other garment factory workers.  She feels that this will provide her with more income, and may even allow her to leave the garment factory sometime in the near future.  If she is successful, she plans on sending all of her children to university.
loan_use: To build a house to rent to factory workers

description: Noor Jahan, daughter of Niam-U-Din, is 45 years old. She is married, has 8 family members, and right now lives in district 8 of Kabul City. She has a tailoring business and wants to take a loan for that. She is an uneducated woman because her family didn’t give her permission to study. However, she wanted to do something for her family, especially after her marriage, and that is why she started her tailoring business. She makes clothes and sells them in bazaar. When she first started her business, she didn’t have enough money. Therefore, her production was small, and she made little money. Then she heard about the loan process through AFSG from one of her friends, and she decided to start taking loans. Up to now she has taken 3 loan cycles from AFSG and wants to take a 4th cycle. Now her business has expanded, and she is making more clothes. As a result, her income has increased.
loan_use: Buying fabrics, string, etc.

description: Nkurankan, Ghana is a large market centre for the people of the Yilo Krobo District of Ghana. Madame B. is a resident of this town and sells cooked rice and stew. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation, and is seeking a Kiva loan of $800.00 to help her improve her business.
loan_use: working capital

description: Nkurankan, Ghana is a large marking centre for the people of the Yilo Krobo District of Ghana. Madam A. is a resident of Nkurankan and manufactures beads. She is also a client of Kraban Support Foundation and is however seeking a Kiva loan of $900.00 to help her improve her business.
loan_use: Bead Manufacturer

description: Ramil is an IDP from the occupied region of Fizuli. He is married and has two children. He rents a booth at the local market where he sells clothing. He started this business in 2004. In 2005, he applied to the Normicro Beylagan Branch for a loan of $700 for the first time.  He bought clothes to be sold. His next loan was for $900. He wants to build a small shop of his own and continue the business there. Therefore, he is applying for $1000$ for his third loan.
loan_use: to build a shop of his own

description: Luisa lives in the small Samoan village of Fagalii–uta  with her seven children.  She is 52 years old, and she is the proud owner of a small village shop.  In her small store, she sells a variety of products to the local villagers such as, snacks, mutton, toilet tissue, water and much, much more.  While there are several competing shops in the village, Luisa has a loyal cadre of customers and is committed to expanding her product line and ensuring a consistent supply of goods so that she can ensure her customers are satisfied.  She feels confident that combining the right products with good service will ensure her success.  Luisa’s children help her run the shop, ensuring she can remain open long hours to service the villagers.  Luisa will use a loan to purchase merchandise for re-selling in her store as well as to make some small improvements to better the appearance of the store and make it more attractive and inviting to potential customers.
loan_use: Buy merchandise and materials for renovation

description: Fazil is a Displaced Person from the occupied Agdam district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married, and has two children. He started his business in 2001, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $3500. Now he is willing to borrow $1200 to increase his variety of goods.
loan_use: To increase variety of goods

description: Kraban Support Foundation, a local NGO based in Ghana, has been assisting women, especially in business, for quite a number of years now. Grace H. (3rd from left) is a client of this organization. She sells used clothing in her locality from house to house. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 from Kiva to help her improve upon her sales.
loan_use: working capital

description:
Mr. S. has a cart where he sells a typical Ecuadorian food called Morocho. Morocho is made of corn, condensed milk, and cinnamon. He has been making morocho and running his business for a few years now, selling from about 3 pm until 10 pm. He hopes he can receive a loan because he is anxious to invest in a new cart. The cart he currently owns is not suitable for going out to busy streets where there are more clients. Mr. S. is married and has 2 children who are in school. His short term goals are to finish fixing his home and continuing to educate his children.

\r\n\r\n
loan_use: Buy a new cart to sell morocho.

description:
Jacinto is a hard working farmer who grew up in Baba. He produces rice and corn on land given to him by his father, who, he still helps and work with. He lives with his girlfriend, who he hopes to marry and start a family with in the near future. He will invest the loan so he can plant for the next cycle by preparing the land, and buying fertilizer and seeds. He does not have children but is still very family oriented, as he is close to his mother, father and brothers. He hopes he can fix the lands so they can be productive for years to come.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by big large companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans, as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plough the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are no drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of products including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many of the loans will also go towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.
loan_use: Rice and Corn Farming

description:
Juan has been working on this farm his entire life. He lives with his wife and 9 year old daughter, and helps his other two children who are grown up and independent. He relies completely on rice farming to feed his family, as his lands are only productive for this activity. He was born and raised in Baba and learned to farm rice from his father. He wants to make his land more productive by plowing them with rented machinery. In the long run, he wants to save for his daughter’s education.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of one the new Communal Banks formed in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Anzuelo Baba Communal Bank are part of an association of rice farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their organization, El Anzuelo Asociacion, works cooperatively to help their members cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. Most recently, El Anzuelo was able to start a program that improved their members access to watering services..

The members of La Asociacion El Anzuelo de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.
loan_use: Rice farming

description: Thy L. is 41 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 2 children.  She works at a local organization teaching people how to become tailors.  She earns $5 at this trade, while her husband makes $7 driving a tuk-tuk (motortaxi-type vehicle) that he rents daily.  Thy L. will use this loan to buy a tuk tuk and motorcycle for their family to own so they don't have to face the day-to-day rental fees.  In the future, Thy L. hopes to buy one more tuk-tuk to rent out and to send her children to university.
loan_use: To purchase a tuk-tuk trailer and a new motorbike.

description: Vitolina is 65 years old and has raised seven children.  Vitolina is quick to extol the virtues of hard work and, likewise, disparage laziness.  Vitolina owns a set of beach fales that she rents out to back-packers or picnickers passing through the village and works hard to keep the structures in good condition.  Fales are simple, small open huts with thatched roofs built in the style of the traditional Samoan house.  Vitolina’s fales are situated on a white sandy beach on the Samoan coast.  She readily welcomes guests and provides them with a simple roof, unbeatable views, and home-cooked meals. She will use the loan to renovate the beach fales.
loan_use: Renovate beach fales (small open huts)

description: Tine is good at gardening and planting. This is one of her hobbies in life. Tine’s backyard is filled up with different vegetables, but cabbages are the main crop. About one-quarter of her area is covered with cabbages. These cabbages only need two to three weeks to grow and re-grow. The place where she lives is mostly occupied with Europeans, and they really like vegetables. These are Tine’s main customers. When Tine has a surplus of vegetables, she prefers to take them to the market. Tine would like to use the loan to buy seeds, tools, and fertilizers from the agriculture store. \r\n
loan_use: To purchase vegetable seeds, gardening tools, and fertilizers

description: Fetu is a 49-year-old lady who is a Center secretary for the Puipaa Center. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a full-time fisherman, and this is their main source of income. This business pays for the education of their children, clothing for the kids, family dues and village and church financial activities.  Fetu works in her business six days a week and she earns $80+ per day.  She earns a total net profit of $100 a week, and some of this money goes into her savings account with SPBD to assist with her weekly loan repayments if the weather is bad, and her husband can't supply the fish she sells. She is requesting a loan so they can upgrade their fishing equipment and increase their catch.
loan_use: To purchase fishing equipment

description: Datura is a florist. She loves to work on her own beautiful garden by growing more different flowers to make beautiful bouquets, and also to make more potted plants for sale to the public. She earns ST$200 (approximately USD80) per day from the sale of flowers and potted plants. There is always a high demand from her clients, especially when there are special occasions which require flower decorations. Datura is applying for another loan to buy more pots and flower seeds for her business.
loan_use: Buy more pots and new oasis, and more flower seeds to grow in the garden

description: Gathering coconuts is not an easy or safe job.  But for Siavii, it is a way to ensure that she can fund the education of her children.  She is thirty-six years old, and she is able to run her business gathering and selling coconuts with continuous help from her four children.  Her husband works at one of the supermarkets in the capital, but his income is not enough to support their large family.  So Siavii has requested a loan to invest in some tools that will help make her work more productive, hopefully enabling her to increase her sales.
loan_use: Machetes and other tools

description: Cracking open a coconut and sticking a straw in it is a traditional Samoan refreshment. Lilly has a small plot of land with coconut trees. She harvests the coconuts and takes them to the main market and will crack them open for you to drink right away.  In a good week, she can earn up to ST 400 (about USD 150) by selling these coconuts. Lilly says that one of the main benefits of having joined SPBD and using the micro-loan facilities to start up her coconut business is that she has been able to use her profit to fix up her home.\r\n\r\n
loan_use: Machetes and other tools for harvesting coconuts

description:
Elisa Maria Cuna M. is a 38 year old born and raised in Moamba, Maputo province. She was raised by her parents and attended school until the 4th grade. In 1984 she married and had 4 children. In 2002, Elisa and her children were abandoned by her husband. Since 1985 she has been working on her own business of raising chickens. In the end of 2006, she was introduced to HLUVUKU-ADSEMA by her sister and learned about the possibility of access to credit. She supports her family and the schooling of her 3 children through this business. With the loan of 10.500,00 MT Elisa wants to expand her business to respond to the increasing demand for chickens, and to raise her income. Elisa’s activities have a positive impact in her community because not only it provides employment for Elisa and sustenance for her family, but it also provides chicken meat at competitive prices to the local market

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização : Bairro 2 - Boane Cliente: Elisa Maria cuna M. Sector de Actividade: Avicultura Valor de Empréstimo: 10.500,00MT (420.00 US$) Aplicação do Montante: Compra de pintos para engorde. Inicio: 10/04/2007 Fim: 31/03/2008 Elisa Maria Cuna M., de 38 anos de idade, natural de Moamba, Província de Maputo, cresceu sob responsabilidade dos seus Pais. Estudou até 4ª classe. Em 1984 contraiu matrimónio tradicional com o seu marido com o qual tiveram quatro filhos. Em 2002 foi abandonada pelo marido tendo deixado os 4 filhos sob responsabilidade dela. Desde 1985 vem assumindo na integra a gestão do negocio de engorde de pintos. Nos finais do ano de 2006 por indicação da sua irmã teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA, tendo se informado das condições de acesso ao credito. Com os rendimentos do negocio suporta os encargos da família, incluindo as despesas escolares dos seus três filhos. Com o empréstimo de 10.500,00MT pretende aumentar o volume do seu negocio para dar resposta a maior procura do frango que tem se verificado nos últimos tempos e aumentar a sua renda. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade porque para alem de providenciar emprego a ela própria, coloca o frango mais perto dos clientes a um preço altamente competitivo.
loan_use: To produce chickens

description:
Mrs. Bilhatu Y. N. runs a knitting shop in Maraba community. She has been in the business for over 5 years. Her experience has enabled her to train over 100 women in knitting. These women now have their own shops that are running successfully.

Mrs. Bilhatu is married with 6 children and 3 dependents. Her husband is a worker in a private company. Mrs. Bilhatu has been working very hard through her knitting business and she earns about N10,000 ($80) a week. It has enabled her to support the family in terms of school fees and feeding them. She has been able to support her husband and to build their own house.

She is part of the group Kauna 1 Maraba which has 8 members in total. They will distribute the loan amongst themselves as dictated by their business plan.
loan_use: Knitting - personal business and training others

description:
Silvia Nelly is married with six children, two of which are married, two are working and her two youngest daughters are still in school. Her husband Alfredo runs a machine shop from their home, but they don’t have a steady income. It was difficult at times to cover all of their expenses, so 17 years ago Silvia decided to earn another income and has since been preparing and selling Mexican sweets and fixed-price dishes.

Silvia only wants the best for her family. Her love for her children has motivated her to keep her business growing for so long. Currently she needs a $275 loan to purchase ingredients necessary for the meals she prepares because she would like to offer her clients a wider variety of dishes. Play a key role in this business and in Silvia's life. She and her family truly appreciate your help.

La señora Silvia Nelly, es casada y tiene 6 hijos, de los cuales 2 están casados, 2 trabajando y sus dos hijas más pequeñas aún estudian. Alfredo, su esposo, tiene un taller mecánico en su propio domicilio, por lo que en no tiene un ingreso fijo y en ocasiones era difícil solventar todos los gastos, por la necesidad de un ingreso extra, hace 17 años Silvia se dedica a la elaboración y venta de antojitos mexicanos y comidas corridas.

Silvia sólo busca lo mejor para su familia, el amor hacia sus hijos la ha motivado todo este tiempo a continuar con su negocio y hacerlo crecer, ahora necesita de un préstamo por $ 275 dólares que utilizará en la compra de los insumos que requiere para la elaboración de sus comidas, porque quiere ofrecer una mayor variedad de platillos a sus clientes. Se parte fundamental en el negocio y la vida de Silvia, ella y su familia agradecen sinceramente tu ayuda.
loan_use:
To purchase ingredients

\r\ncompra de insumos

description: Lay H. is 51 years old and lives in Phnom Penh taking care of her 4 children.  Her husband is a mechanic and earns $6/day.  Three of her children are students, and one daughter (pictured here) has already started her own family.  They also have a nephew that lives with them.  She will use this loan to repair her home in preparation for the rainy season.  In the future, she would like to send her children and her nephew to university.
loan_use: To repair home

description: Surkhay is a local resident of Beylagan. He is engaged in sheep breeding. He has 20 sheep at the moment. He sells sheep at the local animal market or slaughters them. He takes the herd out to graze very often. He needs to buy new heads of animals when he sells or slaughters some of them in order to keep up the number of the herd. Now he needs to buy 10 new sheep. His own funds are short and he has applied to Normicro Beylagan branch for a loan. He needs $400 to buy 10 sheep.
loan_use: To buy 10 sheep to add to the herd

description:
Ms. Rafaela had been in business for 6 months. "My shop is in a good location but there are lots of things customers come in asking for that I don\'t have. I have to stock up on a little of everything, so I\'m asking for $1000."

Translated by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

La Sra. Rafaela tiene 6 meses con su negocio. “Mi negocio esta en muy buena ubicación pero hay muchas cosas que mis clientes me piden y no tengo, necesito comprar mercancía y tener uno poco de todo”. Solicito 1,000.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio en la compra de mercancía.
loan_use: To invest in goods for her shop.

description: Le and her husband were born in 1972. They have two daughters, 16 and 14. The eldest daughter has stopped attending school, and the youngest is an eighth grade student. They have a little land for their hut and a pigpen. They earn about $10 per person per month from making baskets and raising pigs. They are requesting a loan of $75 dollars in order to raise more pigs and make more baskets. This will increase their income and standard of living.
loan_use: Materials needed for making baskets and raising pigs

description: Thanh is 69. Her husband died a long time ago. She lives with her three sons who are between the ages of 23 and 34. The sons work as laborers, but the work is not stable. Although she is too old to work, she can make baskets out of bamboo to earn extra money for her family. Their income is $7 per person per month. She is requesting a loan of $75 to purchase bamboo to make more baskets and increase her family's income
loan_use: To purchase bamboo for making baskets

description:
Mrs. Um M. D. is 35 years old and a widow living with her son in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She struggles to make her living by owning a clothes-making business with 2 workers. She can typically makes around $6/day from this business. Her child is a student and aids his mother when he is free from class.

D. hopes to use the loan to purchase more cloth and pays her workers' wages. In the future, if she saves enough money, she hopes to purchase two or three sewing machines in order to facilitate her business. If possible, she will build a garment shop and send her son to a university.
loan_use: To purchase more cloth and pay her worker's wage.

description: Mrs. Ogbedmudia E. is a 53-year-old woman who is married with five children. She became an LAPO client in 2005 (2 years ago). She started the above business in 2004 in the semi-urban area of Benin City, the state capital of Edo State, Nigeria. According to her, she came to LAPO in 2005 when her business was shaky, and her business improved after working with LAPO. With the loan of $550, she will expand her drinks store to serve a wide range of people in her local community.
loan_use: To buy more crates of drinks

description: Hudson is a married man with nine children, all in primary school. He has not undergone formal training, but has apprenticed in radio repair.\r\nHe started his business in 2002 after he began earning money by selling second-hand and new clothes on public buses while he was employed as a bus conductor. Now he does radio repair along with selling clothes, and he has trained three boys in radio repair since he started. With loan from PEMCI, he plans to buy radio spares to sell to his clients. He will also buy more stock for his clothes business. By making his radio service available to the local people and providing inexpensive, decent clothes to his customers, he is able to support his family's needs.\r\n
loan_use: To increase stock for radio repair and clothing business

description:
Ms Manuela and her husband, Jose, live on the outskirts of the city of Guachochi in the region of the Sierra Tarahumara. They have two children who attend school. Jose is a musician and works various parties. Their income is very inconsistent due to Jose’s vocation; thus, approximately one year ago Manuela decided to start a small grocery store business with the aim of obtaining an additional income and of helping with her children’s expenses. At the start of her business she began supplying merchandise with her husband’s income and little by little she has increased her sales. Her business is a family endeavor: she manages the business and her children, when available, help her.

She seeks a loan of 475 dollars to supply merchandise to her business now that her sales have increased. She intends to pay back the loan within 6-12 months. Your support of Manuela and her family is greatly appreciated.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Manuela y su esposo Don José viven a las afueras de la ciudad de Guachochi en la región de la Sierra Tarahumara, ellos tienen dos hijos los cuales asisten a la escuela. Don José es músico y trabaja tocando en fiestas, es por eso que sus ingresos son muy variables, debido a ello hace un año aproximadamente Doña Manuela decidió iniciar su pequeño negocio de venta de abarrotes, con la finalidad de obtener un ingreso adicional y poder ayudarse con los gastos de sus hijos. Al principio de su negocio empezó a surtir de mercancía con los ingresos de su esposo y poco a poco ha ido incrementando sus ventas. Su negocio es familiar, ella esta al frente del mismo y sus hijos le ayudan cuando tienen tiempo.

Ella esta solicitando un préstamo por $ 475 USD para surtir de mercancía su negocio, ya que sus ventas se han incrementado últimamente, y piensa pagarlo en un plazo de 6-12 meses. Apoya a Doña Manuela y ella y su familia te lo agradecerán.
loan_use: To purchase consumables

description: Mais K. is from Badu, the capital city of Azerbaijan. He is married and has two children. He started his business in 1998 and would like to borrow $1100 to expand the inventory of goods in his store.
loan_use: To increase the variety of goods in his food store

description:
Adriana is 22 years old. She is single and works as an employee in a factory. She lives with her parents, brothers and sisters. 8 months ago she began to sell beauty products to her coworkers, neighbors and friends. She started her business because she needed to help out even more with the family expenses. She wants to be a successful woman and that is the reason that she does two jobs at the same time.

Now she is requesting for a loan of $550.00, because she wants to purchase more merchandise and increase her number of customers by offering a greater variety of products. And we are sure that, if she gets this loan with your help, she will become a great business woman.
loan_use: To purchase more merchandise

description: Phal P., 33-years-old, is a father of 2 children living with his wife and his parents in Kampung cham province, Cambodia. He makes his living by feeding and selling pigs and chickens, and can typically earn around $5 a day, while his wife stays at home to look after her children. One of his children is a student and another is too young to go to school. Phal Part, is struggling to supplement his family, especially his parents by feeding and selling pigs and chickens. Eventually  he hopes, the loan will allow him to make additional profits by purchasing more pigs and chickens to feed and sell at the local market. \r\nIn the future, he expects to expand his business by purchasing one more piece of land to feed more pigs and chickens. If he has enough money, he would like to decorate his house and to send his children to a local university.   \r\n
loan_use: To purchase more pigs and chickens to feed and sell to the local market.

description: Sohaila lives in District 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and she doesn’t have children. She and her husband live alone. She is a tailor. She has good working experience and she wants to take a loan to buy new machines because all the equipment that she has is old. She wants to get new machines to help her husband and make a good life for their future. She would like to thank AFSG.
loan_use: Buy sewing machines

description:
Grey lives with her parents on their farm. Her parents are too elderly to run and manage the operations of the lands so they have given the responsibilities to their daughter. With the guidance of her parents, Grey is planting rice on the lands and she is gaining much experience. She wants the loan because she needs to invest in seeds and fertilizer. She also wants to avoid borrowing from informal lenders because her parents have told her about the risks of their interest rates. She hopes she can save the profits from the land in order to start a family of her own some day.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

She is part of one of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. They will use the microloans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each other's guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The sector is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with the rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.
loan_use: To farm rice on her lands

description:
Mr. Hernández has dedicated himself to the sale of jewelry for the past five years. He imports his products from the Mexican states of Guanajuato and Jalisco. "I make trips every month to stock up on supplies. I currently have some orders, but I have not been able to make the trip due to lack of funds. I need $1,200 to fulfill these responsibilities. I hope you can help me."\r\n

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

\r\nEl Sr. Hernández lleva 5 años dedicándose a la venta de joyería y artículos de piel, sus productos los trae del estado de Guanajuato y Jalisco. "Realizo viajes cada mes para abastecerme de mercancía ya tengo varios pedidos pero no he podido salir a comprarlos pues necesito $1,200.00 dlls para lograrlo ojala me puedan ayudar.
loan_use: To stock up on supplies and fulfill orders at his jewelry store.

description: Chan V. is 33 years old and is a mother of 3 children living with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She works in the nearby garment factory and normally generates around $3/day in revenue. Her husband, meanwhile, repairs tires in the village roadside and typically helps to contribute all the money to the household. Her children are students and assist their parents by cooking meals. V. hopes to use this loan to purchase an air pumping machine to help facilitate her husband's business to make more additional income. In the future, this couple hopes to make more money to open a simple vehicle repaire shop and to supplement their children's education.
loan_use: To purchase an air pumping machine to operate the tire repair business.

description:
Nila is a widow who runs a little business selling shoes at the busiest city market in Novaya Kahovka, Ukraine. She has been in the shoe retail business for 15 years.

Lending services from Nadiya Ukraine have promoted the expansion of Nila’s trade and helped her obtain needed inventory. Nila has proven to be an entrepreneur of integrity as she has faithfully repaid each previous loan. This-- together with her professionalism, determination, and tenacity--has added greatly to the success of her business venture.

Nila would like to get a loan of $1,200 to purchase new pairs of shoes for resale. She thinks that offering a wide assortment of brands and styles-–from sandals, flip-flops, espadrilles, and casual footwear to a great athletic shoe selection--will help her business stand out from her competitors and bring in extra profits. We believe that this loan will help Nila achieve a higher income and improve her entrepreneurial skills.

Ніла – вдова. Вона торгує взуттям на великому місцевому ринку в Новій Каховці. Вона займається цим бізнесом вже 15 років. Кредитні послуги „Надії України” сприяли розвитку торгівлі Ніли та допомогли їй отримати необхідний товар. Ніла – чесний та порядний підприємець, вона вчасно сплатила усі попередні позики. Її професіоналізм, наполегливість та витривалість стали тими чинниками, які допомогли їй досягти успіху. Ніла хотіла б отримати позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб придбати нове взуття для подальшого продажу. Вона вважає, що широкий асортимент моделей та стилів – від босоніжок, в’єтнамок та повсякденного взуття до широкого вибору спортивного взуття, допоможе її бізнесу вигідно виділятися серед її конкурентів та принесе їй додатковий прибуток. Ми вважаємо, що ця позика допоможе Нілі отримати додатковий прибуток та набути нових навичок у веденні бізнесу.
loan_use: To purchase new shoes wholesale

description:
Testimony: "My eagerness to contribute to my family and community has encouraged me and my friends to work together as a group. Today, I am proud of having a positive contribution at both levels: family and community. My opinion can be heard in our community."

Business: Shoe Seller

Family: A married woman with five children

Current Income: I have an average income of $45.00 per month.

Business Plan: I want to secure a shop were I can stock my goods for sell instead of going from place to place.

This is a group loan that Mrs. Mary belongs to called Gaskiya Cooperative.
loan_use: To rent a small shop and enlarge her stock of general use items.

description: Habil A. was born and raised in the Aghsu region of Azerbaijan. He is the sole supporter of his wife and three children. He has been to some extent involved in the family business of tailoring and alterations for the past 20 years. Habil realized the need to expand his operations and has started working with leather to create belts in addition to making commissioned clothing items. \r\n\r\nHabil is requesting a loan from Normicro to purchase more raw materials and supplies for his shop in order to meet the growing demand of his customer base.
loan_use: to purchase more raw materials and supplies

description:
Rebeca is married and has two children, ages 2 and 9. Her husband, Mario, is a house painter but his income is not sufficient to cover the family expenses. In light of this, Rebeca started 6 years ago to sell shoes via catalog to earn an extra income and help her family. She started with a little money she had saved, yet, little by little, she started to see results and now has many clients.

At this time, Rebeca needs a loan in the amount of $250, which she will use to purchase merchandise to fill her client’s orders and continue to offer good service. She pledges to repay this amount within three to six months. Now is the time to help those most in need. Make a decision to help Rebeca.

Translated from Spanish by Lighthouse Translations, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Rebeca es casada y tienen 2 hijos de 2 y 9 años, su esposo Mario es pintor residencial, pero el ingreso que obtiene no es suficiente para los gastos de la familia, por lo que desde hace seis años, Rebeca se dedica a la venta de zapatos por catalogo, para obtener un ingreso extra y poder ayudar a su familia. Inició con un poco de capital que tenia ahorrado pero poco a poco empezó a ver mejores resultados y ahora ya cuenta con muchos clientes.

En estos momentos Rebeca necesita un crédito por $ 250 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para surtir los pedidos de sus clientes y ofrecer un buen servicio, ella ofrece regresar esta cantidad en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses. Hoy es momento de ayudar a quién más lo necesita, decídete a apoyar a Rebeca.
loan_use:
To purchase inventory\r\n

Compra de mercancía

description:
This entrepreneur has a small shop in the south of Kirkuk in a poor area. He has worked in this shop since 2001. Until now, he was not able to develop his small shop. This is his first loan, and he wants to use it to buy an icebox to sell ice cream during the summer.

He has a big family; he supports his mother, father, wife, and five children. He wants to enhance his family's standard of living. He wishes to succeed in his work and develop himself to be the owner of a larger mini-market in the future.

Note: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, etc.).
loan_use: Buy a new icebox

description:
Marcelo is a rice farmer and cattle rancher in Salitre, Ecuador. He is hoping that with the loans he can begin preparing the lands in his farm for rice farming. He will work the lands and buy fertilizer for his crops. He lives with his two daughters, a son and his wife in a house near the home of his parents. His goal is to level the lands so that they will be more productive for years to come. He is pictured with our loan officer filling out his loan application.

He is the latest addition to one of the new Communal Banks in the Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the 10 de enero Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Salitre named 10 de enero. They will use the microloans to prepare the lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the 10 de enero Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but is imperative for the communities Mifex works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Loan Use and Repayment

The loans in this sector will be used to create water basins that will prevent flooding in the case of heavy rains or store water in case of droughts. They will also be used to treat the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase fertilizer. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 5 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the sixth and final month.

Below is more information about Salitre compiled by the staff at Mifex when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Salitre

Salitre is a rural sector in the Province of Guayas known as the capital of Montuvios (montuvio is a cowboy) with approximately 30,000 inhabitants. The main economic activities are herding and agriculture, which make up about 80% of the economy. The infrastructure and basic services are poor, especially the roads and water services.

Salitre is highly dedicated to farming rice and cattle ranching. Rice is a crop that yields about every four months. In order to farm rice, the environment must be very humid and there must be a high volume of water. The lack of a structured water system makes it difficult for the small farmers to be highly productive. The best months for cultivating rice are early in the year when it is the rainy season on the coast of Ecuador.

Salitre is a national tourist attraction as many Ecuadorians visit the freshwater Salitre River. There are cottages, small restaurants and water attractions that people come to enjoy.

Access to Credit

There are not many financial institutions that provides services to the productive sector of the local economy. The primary access to credit comes from loan sharks who charge extremely high interest rates averaging around 20% a month. The locals are also exploited by the intermediaries that buy their products in order to sell them in the city and to export abroad. These intermediaries buy crops in advance at very low prices, finance soil at extremely high prices and often provide emergency loans for even higher interest rates than the loan sharks.

Risks

Salitre is a dangerous sector considering it is in a rural area. There is a high incidence of robbery of cattle that results in many of the ranch owners owning weapons to protect their property. Because the police are not present in these areas, farmers and ranchers must apply their own laws and provide their own security. In some instances, they have formed their own cooperatives and associations to have a community crime prevention effort.

Salitre is in the lowlands of Ecuador and is vulnerable to flooding in the rainy season. In the event of a heavy rainy season, often at its worse when El Niño occurs, the rice farmers lose many of their crops. All this is due to a lack of infrastructure in the area.
loan_use: Level his lands for rice farming

description:
César is a native of Saltillo, Coahuila. He is married and his wife works as a pharmacy assistant: they have 2 children who are 1 and 6 years old. His father has a auto repair workshop and three years ago he began to help him. Thanks to the technical course he studied he knows this work well, and now he is in sole charge of the business. César wants the business to be able to grow in order to provide a better income for the well-being of his family.

In order to offer his services, given that the work done is paid once the vehicle is delivered, César needs a loan of $275 dollars that he will use to buy spare parts and tools which he needs for his work. He is committed to repaying the loan within 3-6 months. You can help to improve the quality business can grow: they thank you for your trust in them and your help.

Translated from Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer.

César es originario de Saltillo, Coahuila, está casado y su esposa trabaja como empleada en una farmacia, tienen 2 hijos, de 1y 6 años de edad. Su padre tiene un taller mecánico y hace 3 años comenzó a ayudarle, gracias a la carrera técnica que estudió conoce de esta labor, y ahora se encarga él solo del negocio, César quiere que este negocio pueda crecer y otorgarle un mejor beneficio para el bienestar de su familia.

Para poder ofrecer sus servicios, dado que los trabajos que realiza se los pagan una vez que ha entregado el vehículo, César necesita de un préstamo por $ 275 dólares que utilizará en la compra de refacciones y herramienta que requiere para hacer su trabajo, él se compromete a devolver este préstamo en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses. Tú puedes contribuir la mejorar la calidad de vida de esta familia y ayudar al que este taller pueda crecer, ellos agradecen tu confianza y ayuda.
loan_use: Purchase of spare parts and tools

description:
Maricela is a married woman and she has three children, two women of 21 and 26 years of age and a seventeen year-old boy. Her husband has a temporary job as a gardener in the U.S. In order to help pay for their home and for her children's education, Maricela decided fourteen years ago to start her own business selling groceries. She begun with a few articles, and little by little she's increased the number of products she sells. Her store is now well stocked and she occasionally receives help from her children in Sabinas Hidalgo, Nuevo León..

To keep her business growing, Maricela is asking for $550 in credit, which she will use to purchase merchandise and let her buy more products for her store. This way she can offer better service to her clients, thus keeping them loyal to her store. Maricela trusts people that help those who need it most and she thanks you for your generosity and support.

Translated from spanish by Maite Barragán, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maricela es casada, y tiene 3 hijos, dos mujeres de 21 y 26 años de edad y un varón de 17 años. Su esposo tiene un trabajo temporal de jardinero en Estados Unidos, para apoyarlo con los gastos del hogar y de la educación de sus hijos, hace catorce años Maricela decidió iniciar su propio negocio con la venta de abarrotes, empezó con pocos artículos y poco a poco ha ido incrementado el número de productos que comercializa, ahora tiene una tienda bien surtida en donde ocasionalmente recibe la ayuda de sus hijos en Sabinas Hidalgo, Nuevo León.

Para continuar creciendo con su negocio, Maricela solicita un crédito por $ 550 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía que le permita tener un mejor surtido en su tienda, ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes y conservar su preferencia. Maricela confía en las personas que ayudan a quien más lo necesita, y agradece tu generosidad y apoyo.
loan_use: Buying merchadise

description:
Maria Dolores is a widow with four children aged 23, 26, 28 and 30. When her husband died, her children were small and she had to make a huge effort to be able to give them the education and the sustenance they needed, carrying out various jobs. For the last eight years, she has concentrated on selling food: she started by preparing various meals and snacks that she sold in offices. Now with her savings she has managed to obtain a market stall where she makes tacos.

In order to expand her business, Maria is asking for a loan of $200 dollars which she will use to buy more ingredients in order to increase her production rates and her sales. She has committed to repaying this money within 2 to 4 months. Your help can improve the lives of Maria and her family. She trusts that you’ll help those who need it most and thanks you for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Dolores es viuda y tiene cuatro hijos de 23, 26, 28 y 30 años de edad, cuando su esposo falleció sus hijos eran pequeños y ella tuvo que esforzarse mucho para poderles dar la educación y el sustento que necesitaban, realizó varios trabajos y desde hace ocho años se dedica a la venta de comida, inició preparando diversos platillos que vendía en las oficinas, y con sus ahorros logró obtener un puesto en el que ahora elabora tacos.

Para hacer crecer su negocio, Maria solicita un préstamo por $ 200 dólares que utilizará en la compra de más ingredientes para incrementar su producción y sus ventas, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 2 a 4 meses. Tu colaboración puede mejorar la vida de Maria y su familia, ella confía en las personas que ayudan a quien mas lo necesita y agradece tu apoyo.
loan_use: Purchase raw materials

description:
I make furniture like tables, dressers, and cabinets as well as picture frames. I have been in business for five years and work by myself. At this time I need to buy wood to fill orders for tables and chairs. I need the income because my children are in school and there are many expenses related to their education.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer

Mi negocio es hacer variedades diseños de madera (mesas, retrateras, sillas, llaveros armarios y otros. Este negocio lo atiendo personalmente. Tengo 5 años de tenerlo. ahora necesito comprar madera ya que tengo varios clientes que quieren que les haga unas sillas y mesas. Necesito ingros para estos mes ya que mis hijos estan estudiando y tengo mucho gastos con sus estudios.
loan_use: To buy wood.

description: Razia lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives with members of her family. She is married and she is a traditional embroiderer. She has good experience in her job. She took her 3rd cycle group loan and expanded her business to make a good income for her family. She wants to take anther loan to buy new sewing machines and extra things for embroidery. She hopes to make a good business and help her husband support thier family better than now. She is very happy with this loan.
loan_use: To buy new machines

description:
Flora L. makes cows-milk cheese and sells it in the city of El Alto. She also tends dairy cows. These two activities give her the income to provide for her two dependent children. She lives in the rural area of La Paz in the municipality of Achica Baja in Ingavi Province. This loan will go towards the purchase of a cow so Flora can make more cheese. This is her second loan with IMPRO. Her good borrowing history gives her access to this new loan so she can increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Flora L., es productora de queso de leche de ganado vacuno que comercializa en la Ciudad de El Alto, también trabaja como ayudante de crianza de ganado constituyendo esta actividad su fuente de ingreso económico que le permite la manutención de sus dos hijos que depende de ella. Flora vive en la Área Rural de La Paz, localidad Achica Baja Provincia Ingavi. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una Vaca productora de leche, misma que le permitirá producir mayor cantidad de quesos. Es el segundo crédito con IMPRO, su buen antecedente le permite acceder a otro crédito para mejorar sus ingresos económicos.
loan_use: To purchase a dairy cow.

description:
Delia is married and has two young children--a two-year-old daughter and a six-year-old son. Her husband works as a maintenance man but his pay is very low so six years ago, to help her husband with the family's expenses Delia decided to begin her own business in sales. Lately she has been selling home decor items like paintings, decorations and furniture, as well as lingerie, out of catalogs. She shows her merchandise in the homes of friends and family and has seen demand for her products and her business grow. At this time Delia needs a loan of $200 to invest in merchandise and meet customer demand. You can play an important role in the life of this family so please do not hesitate to help her.

translated by a Kiva volunteer

Delia es casada y tiene dos pequeños hijos, una niña de 2 años y un niño de 6. Su esposo trabaja en el departamento de mantenimiento en una empresa, pero su salario es muy bajo, para ayudarle a su esposo con las obligaciones del hogar, Delia se dedica a las ventas desde hace seis años, últimamente comercializa productos para diseño de interiores como cuadros, decoraciones y muebles, así como también ropa interior por catálogo, ella ofrece demostraciones de sus productos en casas de familiares y amigas, esto le ha permitido incrementar la demanda por sus productos y crecer con su negocio.

\r\nEn estos momentos, Delia necesita de un préstamo por $ 200 dólares que invertirá en la compra de mercancía para poder cubrir los pedidos de sus clientes y continuar creciendo. Tú puedes ser parte importante en la vida de esta familia, no lo dudes más y decídete a apoyar a Delia.
loan_use: To buy merchandise.

description:
Laura is a very enthusiastic and hard-working woman. She is married and has three daughters ages 11, 13 and 15. Although her husband works as a hospital orderly she decided to work to help him with the household expenses, so two years ago she opened her own business selling clothing. She is very driven and her business is going well. She has many new customers and her income is rising. She travels to other states to buy at factory prices. At this time, she needs to expand her product line so she is asking for a loan of $200 that she will use to buy merchandise. She promises to repay the loan within 3-6 months. Please help Laura's business and her family. They would be very grateful.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Laura es una mujer muy entusiasta y trabajadora, ella es casada y tiene tres hijas, de 11, 13 y 15 años de edad, aunque su esposo trabaja como camillero en un hospital, ella decidió trabajar para apoyarlo con los gastos de su hogar, para lo que inició su propio negocio con la venta de ropa hace dos años, a Juana siempre la ha gustado salir adelante y se esfuerza mucho para lograrlo, afortunadamente su negocio ha prosperado y ha logrado tener mas cliente y mejores beneficios.

\r\nPara obtener mayores beneficios, Juana viaja a otros estados donde obtiene precios de fábrica, ahora necesita incrementar la variedad de productos que ofrece, para esto requiere de un préstamo por $ 200 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en un plazo de 3 a 6 meses. Se parte fundamental en la vida de esta familia y en el crecimiento del negocio de Laura, ellos te lo agradecen sinceramente.
loan_use: To buy merchandise.

description: Fazel Ahamad lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is uneducated and he has a workshop for repairing cars. He took his 2nd cycle individual loan and opened this shop and now he wants to take anther loan to buy new machines and expand his business to make a good monthly income for his family and send his children to a good school to became educated. He is very happy with this loan.
loan_use: To buy new machines

description:
Don Miguel is a vendor who has recently moved to the city after living most of his life in rural Ecuador in a town named Quevedo. Although Don Miguel and his wife are older they refuse to be burdens to their children who do not make much money. They purchase certain fruits and vegetables at wholesale prices from his town and take them into the city to be sold.
