Actividade: Agro-Pecuaria Valor De Empréstimo:20.000,00Mt(800 USd) Aplicação:Compra De Frangos Para Revenda Inicio: 28-11-07 Fim: 22-03-09 Guilaze Almeida M., Natural de Massaca,distrito de Boane , província de Maputo, de 50 anos de idade teve duas irmãs estas já falicidas, orfao de pai e mãe. Estudou ate a 4 classe na escola oficial de boane. Depois segue para escola de electricidade da baixa tensão para uma formação na área de elctricidade, nao conseguiu concluir. No mesmo ano vai a escola de condução para tirar a licença de conduçao.

Em 1988 começa a trabalhar na empresa de drenos como motorista do Director. No ano seguinte é promovido à chefe de transportes. O emprego durou poucos meses, largou e começou a assumir a conta própria na área da agricultura na produção de batata reno nas quintas que erdou dos seus progenitores. Um tempo depois para com actividade agrícola, por ter sido comprada a empresa que fornecia-lhe energia para alimentar as suas motobombas que usava para o regadio. Em 1979 compra o seu talhão com a sua namorada, e no mesmo ano casou-se e conta com 5 filhos dos quais 3 são menianas. Tem um pequeno estabelecimento comercial e uma capoeira onde tem criado os frangos para revenda. A sua actividade de criação de frangos fica parada por ter sofrido roubo, neste momento vende apenas produtos de primeira necessidade.

Passado algum tempo decide aproximar-se a Hluvuku-Adsema para remeter um pedido de empréstimo para criação de frangos, actividade. Soube da nossa existência da Hluvuku-Adsema apartir do seu sogro, Sr. Matendeudja, residente no Umpala que é nosso cliente. Entende o credito como uma boa ferramenta que possa ajudar as populacões que nao tem possibilidade de entrar nos grandes bancos maiores. Tem como maior sonho desenvolver a agricultura nas suas quintas e ter uma boa producao na area de avicultura.
loan_use: To buy chickens

description:
Rasse Antonio T., 54, was born in Maputo where she studied until the second grade. Due to her family’s financial situation, she left home at the age of 13 to live with her grandfather in Boane, where she lives until today. In 1970 Rasse began a small business in order to survive. She got married in 1973 and today has 6 children. Rasse took out her first loan through a small association called G.G.L.S. in Matola that offered credit to groups. It was not a good experience because, besides the loans being very small, the borrowers had to take responsibility for anyone in the group who defaulted on their part of the loan.

Rasse heard about Hluvuku through her friends, and applied for her first loan to purchase products. She intends to use the 15,000.00 MT to increase her supply of merchandise, and with the profits provide for her family’s needs and her children’s education. She is currently hoping to have her own building in a good business environment.

Rasse’s business has a significant impact on the community because it offers clients easy access to her products, and it provides work for her and her children, who are older but without employment opportunities. Rasse runs the business herself, and her children help out when she’s absent. In the future, Rasse would like to have a safe, brick building.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva Volunteer.

Localizacao : bairro 4 Cliente : Rasse Antonio T. Actividade : Comercio Valor de empréstimo : 15.000,00mt ( 600 USD ) Actividade: Compra de produtos para revenda Inicio : 28-11-07 Fim: 22-03-09

Rasse António T. nasceu em Maputo em 1953, tem 54 anos de idade, estudou ate 2ª classe devido as condições financeiras da família aos seus 13 anos deixa de viver com os pais e passa a viver com avo em Boane onde encontra se a residir actualmente .Em 1970 comecou a exercer um pequeno negocio para a sobrivivencia .Em 1973 juntou-se com o seu marido e passou a viver com ele ,tem actualmente 6 filhos . Teve o seu 1º contacto de empréstimo com uma pequena associação G.G.L.S localizada na Matola que oferecia créditos em grupos ,não tendo sido uma experiência boa porque para alem dos valores cedidos serem menores tinham de assumir responsabilidade de pagar o empréstimo em casosde um dos elementos do grupo não efectuasse o pagamento .

Conheceu a Hluvuku-Adsema através das amigas e dai aproximou e solicitou o seu 1º empréstimo para compra de produtos ,com este emprestimo de 15.000.00 MT pretende aumentar o volume de mercadoria,com os rendimentos do negocio suporta os encargos familiares e escolares dos seu filhos . Actualmente esta explorando um estabelecimento próprio ,mas sendo o único no local que oferece um bom ambiente de negocio .

A sua actividade tem um maior impacto na comunidade pois para alem de colocar o produto mais próximo do cliente providencia o auto emprego a ela e para os filhos já maiores mas sem oportuniodade de emprego. Ela dirige pessoalmente o seu negocio na ausência os filhos é que tem tomado a conta do mesmo. Futuramente pretende ampliar o seu negocio e ter um estabelecimento seguro de alvenaria.
loan_use: To increase stock

description:
Activity: Residence

Loan amount: 16.000 meticais (677USD)

Loan use: to purchase construction material

Loan start date: Nov 19, 2007

Loan end date: Dec 5, 2009

Silvano Mateus B. was born in Massaco, Boane, in 1972. He only studied until eight grade. In 1986 he joined a troop to train as a militiaman, returning in 1987.

He quit his studies because he had to change shifts, and the conditions were not conducive to continuing his studies.

He lived with his parents until he was 19 years of age, and at 26, he started having a girlfriend, marrying officially once 35 years old.

He currently has four kids, the eldest 14 years old.

He has already worked in several organizations, such as Ara Sul (1989-1995), CMC (1998-2000), Trac Africa (2000-2005), currently working for Bananalândia as a driver.

He has already worked in commerce, traveling to the north of the country to buy beans and corn for resale in Maputo. The results of the sale were not satisfactory, and he later chose to cease this effort.

He got to know Hluvuku-Adsema thanks to his wife. He approached them and asked for credit in the amount of 16000 meticais, and plans to enlarge his house.

For him, credit is a viable, highly progressive fund for rural and urban communities.

In the future, he plans to ask for credit to finish his construction effort.

Translated from Portuguese by Ilse Ackerman, Kiva volunteer.

Silvano Mateus B. Nasceu em Massaca, distrito de Boane em 1972. Estudou apenas ate a 8 ª classe.

Em 1986 foi a tropa para treinar como Miliciano e voltou em 1987.

Deixou de estudar porque teve que mudar de turno e as condições em que se encontrava não lhe favoreciam para continuar com os seus estudos.

Viveu com os pais ate aos 19 anos de idade e aos 26 anos começou a namorar tendo casdo, oficialmente, aos 35 anos de idade.

Tem actualmente 4 filhos sendo o mais velho com 14 anos de idade.

Já trabalhou em varias instituição como : Ara Sul (1989-1995), CMC (1998-2000) Trac Africa (2000-2005) e actualmente esta trabalhando na Bananalândia como Motorista .

Já praticou o comércio, viajava para o norte do país para comprar feijão e milho para revender no Maputo, o resultado da venda não era satisfatório tendo depois optado em desistir.

Conheceu a Hluvuku - Adsema graças a esposa dai aproximou se e pediu um credito no valor de 16.000.00mt e pretende ampliar a sua casa.

Para ele, o credito e um fundo viável e de alta progressão para as comunidades rurais e urbanas.

Futuramente pretende pedir um crédito para concluir a obra.
loan_use: to buy material to build a house

description: Entin is 38 years old and a mother of a 9 year old son. She sells some clothes and veils on credit. She has to go around various places to offer and sell them. She can earn $5 per week. Her husband is a driver in Jakarta. She requests a $100 loan to buy more goods, and hopefully will earn more income to fund her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.
loan_use: To buy more goods to sell

description: Yeyet is 30 years old, and a mother of a 17 year old son. She has a small shop which sells some household goods. She can earn $30 per day. Her husband, J., is a driver who earns $3 income per day. She is requesting a $50 loan to buy more goods to fill her shop and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.
loan_use: To buy more goods to fill her shop

description:
Sati is a 37-year-old widow and lives with her daughter and her son-in-law. She sells some snacks and beverages and usually earns $5 per day.

She wants to expand her business and really needs a $50 loan to buy more food to sell. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.
loan_use: To buy more beverages and snacks

description: Mrs. Mich M., 54, is married and lives with her husband (who is pictured because Mrs. Mich M. was unavailable) and five children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia.  She works with her husband on their rice paddy growing rice crops, earning collectively around $2/day.  Three of her children work at a garment factory, earning together $150/month.  Another one is unemployed and the other is a student.  Mrs. Mich M. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motor-bike for one of her children to operate a motor-taxi business.  With the help of the loan, her family will have another source of income.
loan_use: To purchase a motorcycle for one of her children to operate a motor-taxi.

description:
Rebecca, 52, has been working in the timber market in Tema for 15 years. She is now running two businesses at once. One is selling second hand clothing, and the other is a public bathroom for workers at the market to shower/use the toilet. 

Currently the toilets are just pits under cement holes. With the loan, Rebecca would like to build a reservoir and a new structure for flushable toilets with tiled floors. Not only will she be able to charge more for use of the toilets, it will also create a more sanitary environment for the community. With the remainder of the loan, Rebecca will purchase second hand clothing for her shop in the market.

Rebecca is a member of the lending group, Zion. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.
loan_use: To construct a public reservoir for a public toilet and to purchase second hand clothing.

description: Mr. Ung B., 35, is married and lives with his wife in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia.\r\nTo cover his household’s expense, Mr. Ung B. works as a construction foreman, earning around $16/day in revenue, while his wife works as a housewife looking after her child and cooking food for him. Mr. Ung B. hopes to use this loan to purchase wood frames and some construction tools to facilitate his business.
loan_use: To purchase wood frames and some tools to facilitate his business.

description:
Anna is a dedicated entrepreneur who sells shoes at the busy Barabashovo market in Kharkiv, the second largest city in Ukraine. An experienced business owner, she has been in business for about ten years. She is able to buy shoes wholesale from a large distributor and then resells them for a profit. Anna is divorced and has two kids. Her business is a valuable source of income for her family. \r\n

\r\nAnna has requested a loan to help purchase some new inventory. The onset of the colder season makes this a busy time of the year for many market vendors. This loan will enable Anna to capitalize on demand and increase her profits while she works to support herself and improve her business.
loan_use: Purchase inventory

description:
Justo Pastor sells clothes, electrical household items, stuffed toy animals, pillows, toys, vases, towels, shoes... practically everything. They even have the drive to sell basic grains.

He has been working this business for 15 years, starting with $54 of his own money. He started with the need to help out his mom, remembering how before, when he was a boy, he would go out with her to sell in the streets door to door. Later, they were able to establish themselves in one of the sidewalks in the central market of Leon, selling watches, cosmetics and small things.

Justo wants to use the money he is requesting to stock his space with more merchandise. He is marries and has two sons and a daughter who is in her first year in college. To make sure nothing is lacking in their home, he has faith that investing more in his business will allow him to have a better profit.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Justo Pastor vende ropa, electrodomesticos, peluches, almohadas, juguetes, floreros, toallas, zapatos.....practicamente de todo. Hasta tienen animos de vender Granos Básicos

Lleva 15 años trabajando en este negocio, comenzó con 54 dólares de su propio dinero., inicia con la necesidad de tener ayudarle a su mamá, recuerda que antes cuando era niño salia con ella a vender a la calle, de casa en casa...luego lograron establecerse en una de las aceras del mercado Central de Leon vendiendo relojes, cosméticos y cosas pequeñas.

El dinero que esta pidiendo lo quiere utilizar para surtir su tramo con mas mercadería, es casado con 2 hijos y a su niña la tiene en el primer año de la universidad y para que nada falte en su hogar tiene fe que al invertri mas en su negocio le permitira tener mejores ganancias.
loan_use: Working capital, to buy merchandise (Compra de mercaderia, Capital de Trabajo)

description:
Mary owns a small stall by the ocean. She carries mostly foods used for typical Ghanaian dishes such as tomato paste, oil, and fermented corn doe (used to make a kenke). She also sells basic home necessities such as mosquito coils (malaria is the number one cause for hospitalization in Ghana), soap, and candles (the power crises causes frequent brown-outs in the country and many are not connected to electricity in the first place).

With the loan, Mary will expand her store by purchasing more stock. The profits that she makes will partially go to her youngest child’s education fees. She has six children, ages 19 to 34. The 19-year-old is currently in junior high. None of her other children completed junior high school due to financial shortages.

Mary is a member of the lending group, Kamfo Ewurade group. This group of twenty-three guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.
loan_use: To purchase corn doe, soda, tomato cans, oil, and other products for her stand.

description: Ismawati is 24 years old and the mother of a child aged 3. She has been running her business selling snacks, household goods, and cigarettes in her small shop. She usually earns $10 per day whereas her husband, A., is a laborer at the market who earns a small income. Ismawati is requesting a loan to buy more goods to fill her shop and hopes that, with more inventory, she can contribute more toward her family's income. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.
loan_use: To buy more goods for her shop

description:
Muhabbat is a happy mother of 4 children and sells dishes, thermoses and kettles. She is 37 years old and has been in this business for 10 years. Her husband sells small goods at the market. Muhabbat’s children are good students in high school. She will use this loan to expand her business in order continue to support her family’s standard of living.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Мухаббат счастливая мать 4-х детей ,которая занимается продажей посуды и термосов и чайников.Самой Мухаббат 37 лет, уже 10 лет как занимается торговлей, муж также торгует на базаре мелкой розницей.Дети прилежные ученики в средней школе.Займ хочет взять для расширения своего бизнеса,чтоб поддерживать уровень жизни семьи.
loan_use: Business Expansion

description:
R. Zebi Amonovna is selling children's clothing for the past 16 years. She is married and has five children. After the collapse of the Soviet Union (USSR) she and her husband lost their jobs. Her husband is currently unemployed. Zebi had to start selling on the market to feed her family. Her older son was also helping her. As her children grew older her income was not enough. Her older son had to go to Russia to find work. He was sending home US$100 a month, but it was still not enough. In the early 2006 Zebi obtained a loan to expand her business. She started buying merchandise in large quantities (wholesale) for a lower price and selling it retail or semi-wholesale. Her younger son, Zubaidullo is helping her with the business. Zebi wants to be more competitive and intends to travel to Bishkek, the Republic of Kyrgyztan, herself to purchase merchandise which will allow her to start selling wholesale.\r\n

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

\r\nРасулова Зеби Амоновна в течение 16 лет торгует детской одеждой. Замужем. Имеет 5 детей. После распада СССР они остались без работы. Муж в данное время без работы. Чтобы прокормить семью она была вынуждена выйти на базар торговать. Старший сын помогал ей. По ходу взросления детей ее доход не был достаточен. Её старший сын вынужден был поехать на заработки в Россию. Он присылал по 100$ в месяц. Но и этого было, не достаточна и в начале 2006 года она для расширения своего бизнеса получила кредит. Она закупает большими партиями товар (оптом) по низкой цене и продает в розницу и мелким оптом. Ему сейчас помогает ее младший сын Зубайдулло. Чтобы быть более конкурентоспособным она намеревается ездить сама за товаром в Бишкек (Республика Кыргызстан), что позволит ей перейти в оптовую торговлю товарами.
loan_use: Increase the assortment of goods and purchase new products for winter

loan_name: Subgroup G in group Tujikwamue Ukonga
description:
Tatu, age 30, runs a food sales business at a local slaughter house, which she started in 1989. She sells different types of food from 4pm until 8am the next day. Each night, she serves around 80 customers, earning a profit of about US$9. With this profit, she pays for additional food stock and for general household expenses. She also employs two women to help her cook and serve the food, and pays about US$27 a month in rent for the stall. Tatu is a single mother of 4 children (15, 13, 10, and 8 years old) and is also looking after her mother.

Tatu is the leader of Subgroup G in group Tujikwamue Ukonga (Tujikwamue meaning “progressing from one stage to another” in Swahili, and Ukonga being the location), which totals 55 members. Tatu will be sharing this loan with her subgroup members: Fidea M. (food sales), Palina W. (chicken sales), Zainabu A. (food sales), Flora R. (food sales), Rehema S. (food sales) and Emanuel M. (used clothing sales). She knows her subgroup well, as they are neighbors and have shared 2 previous loans together, which they paid back successfully.

Tatu used the previous loans to increase the quantity of different food items in her stall. The new loan, too, will be used for the same purpose. In particular, Tatu plans to buy big sacks of baking flour, cooking oil, and charcoal. She also wishes to open a day business for food sales.
loan_use: Business expansion
borrower_names: Zainabu, Rehema, Emanuel, Fidea, Tatu, Palina, Flora
borrower_genders: female, female, male, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description: Djamal (his brother is pictured) is single and lives in Khaladj village in the Salyan region. He is 23 years old. This young man has run this business for 8 years. Djamal requests a loan of $1200 to buy clothes to improve his business.
loan_use: to buy clothes

description: Latifat O. is 25 years old, married with 2 children. She hails from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. Latifat sells provisions and has been in business since 2002. She needs the loan to buy more provision for sale.
loan_use: To buy more provisions for sale

description:
Victoria K. is a multi-talented multi-tasker! She is married to John Shumari and has two children, Yoeli, 7, and Wingrac, 3. In 2002 she established a business selling Christian literature and books. She now wants to expand this business by purchasing additional goods, as well as open a new business raising guinea fowl for sale. Christ and guineas? Books and fowl? It may not make sense, but I’m sure it will make money! For these business ventures, Victoria requires a loan of $525 and trusts she will find some Kiva lenders who appreciate her eclectic range of enterprises! 

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions, as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback.
loan_use: To purchase Christian books and guinea fowl!

description:
Beatriz B., holder of Passport No. AB 226509, 38 years of age and a resident of the Laulane / 3 de fevereiro neighborhood, is married with 1 child and lives in her own home. She will begin the program by borrowing 6,000 MT to be repaid in 6 months. She sells clothing and is a traveling saleswoman. She plans to use the loan to invest in the business.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Beatriz B., portadora do passapot nº AB 226509, de 38 anos de idade residente no bairro Laulane / 3 de fevereiro, casada e tem 1 filho casa propria esta a iniciar no programa, vai tomar 6000 para pagar em 6 meses ,vende Roupas é vendedora ambulante e com o valor que vai tomar pretende Investir no negocio
loan_use: Increase stock

description: Yegana is a mother of three children. This young woman was born in 1979. She lives with her family in Khachmaz town. Yegana has sold clothes for three years. Now she requests a loan of $850 to buy clothes.
loan_use: To buy clothes

description:
María belongs to the communal bank "La Familia" (The Family). She lives in Jr. Lago Titcaca 139, in Calleria district in Ucayali. She is 52-years-old. Her husband is a mechanic, and they have 4 children who are adults. They help with the business when they can. Some of them work and contribute to the family income, but it still isn't enough. This is why María decided to open a small grocery store thanks to the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 nuevos soles ($100.)

Now her grocery store is well-stocked. She sells bread, sugar, rice, eggs, toothpaste, etc. She gets up very early to do her domestic chores, then goes to attend to her store where she feels very happy conversing with her clients and providing for their needs.

With the recent loan from Manuela Ramos of 2,000 nuevos soles ($669), which will be repaid in 4 months, she purchased 3 packages of soft drinks (small and large), ice cream, 2 bags of sugar, 1 bag of rice, 2 bags of salt, 1 container of eggs, 2 boxes of milk, etc.

María Luisa told us that she feels like a very lucky woman because thanks to Manuela Ramos, she will be able to expand her business and increase her income. She will have the opportunity to accomplish some things that she had to postpone before for economic reasons, and this will give well-being to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Maria pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Familia”, vive en Jr. Lago Titicaca 139, del distrito Calleria, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 años D. edad, su esposo es mecánico y es madre D. 4 hijos que ya son mayores D. edad y que la ayudan en el negocio cuando les es posible. Algunos trabajan. y aportan en el hogar, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza, por ese motivo María decidió poner una bodega gracias al primer préstamo D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$100.00).

En la actualidad tiene su bodega bien surtida, donD. venD. pan, azúcar, arroz, huevos, pasta dental, etc. Ella se levanta muy temprano para atender los quehaceres domésticos, y después se va a atender su bodega donD. se siente muy a gusto conversando con sus clientes y satisfaciendo sus necesidades.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 2,000 (US$ 669.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, compró D. 3 paquetes D. bebidas gaseosas (grandes y chicas), helados, 2 sacos D. azúcar, 1 saco D. arroz, 2 sacos D. sal, golosinas, 1 jaba D. huevos, 2 cajas D. leche, etc.

Maria Luisa nos dijo que se siente una mujer muy dichosa porque gracias a Manuela Ramos ella podrá ampliar su negocio e incrementara sus ingresos y tendrá oportunidad D. poder realizar algunas cosas que antes estuvo postergando por motivos económicos y que le dará bienestar familiar.
loan_use: Purchase of various products for a grocery store

description:
Doña Mirna B. is 50 years old, single, and has 5 children, 3 of whom are adults and two who are children studying in grade school. She is ethnically Creole, originally from Bluefields. For the past 20 years she has been working baking coconut bread, sweet bread, lemon cake, soda cake, and coconut cake. She does her baking 4 times a week and has a demand for cakes for Christmas as well as weekly orders from her neighbors. This is why Mrs. B. needs financing to buy the materials to be able to make her bakery products. This micro-entrepreneur needs to buy 1 oil drum which costs US$27.00, 4 quintales (100 kg. sacks) of flour which cost US$32.00 each, 4 sacks of coal which she buys for US$ 10.00 per sack, 1quintal of salt which she buys for US $13.00, 4 boxes of eggs which she buys for US$ 13.00 per box, 20 lbs. of butter which she buys for $0.50 per pound, and 20 lbs. of lard, which she buys for US$ 0.80 per pound.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Mirna B. tiene 50 años de edad, es soltera, tiene 5 hijos 3 adultos y 2 niños, los cuales se encuentran estudiando en primaria, es de la etnia creole y originaria de Bluefields. Se dedica desde hace 20 años a hornar pan de coco, pan dulce, pastel de limon, soda queque y pastel de coco. Hace sus hornados 4 veces a la semana y tiene una demanda de pedidos de queques para navidad asi como los pedidos que semanalmente le hacen susu vecinos. Por tal razon es que doña B. necesita que le financien para comprar los insumos para poder hacer sus productos del horno. Esta microempresaria necesita comprar 1 bidon de aceite que le cuesta US$ 27.00 dolares, 4 quintales de harina que le cuestan US$ 32.00 dolares cada quintal, 4 sacos de carbon que los compra a US$ 10.00 dolares cada saco, 1 quintal de sal que compra a US$ 13.00 dolares, 4 cajillas de huevo que la compra a US$13.00 dolares cada cajilla, 20 libras de mantequilla que la compra a US$ 0.50 dolares cada libra y 20 libras de manteca la cual compra a US$ 0.80 cada libra.
loan_use: To buy a can of oil, 400 kg. of flour, 4 sacks of coal, 100kg. of salt, 4 boxes of eggs, 20 lbs. of butter, and 20 lbs. of lard. (Para comprar 1 bidon de aceite, 4 quintales de harina, 4 sacos de carbon 1 quintal de sal, 4 cajillas de huevo, 20 libras de mantequilla y 20 libras de manteca.)

description:
Elizabeth belongs to the Communal Bank Las Activas, she lives in Asentamiento Humano Señor D. los Milagros Jr. Pachacutec Mz A1 Lt. 06, Calleria district, Ucayali state. She is 52 years old and mother of 7 children, her husband is a motocycle-taxi driver, but the income doesn't meet the household expenses. So Elizabeth, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for 300 Soles (US$100.00), decided to put a small chicken retail stand in the Bellavista market.

Because of her business she gets up at 1 AM to go and purchase the chickens in order to be able to sell them starting at 5 AM. Sales normally finish at 1 PM, then she goes home to rest and prepare to do it all again the next day.

With the recent loan from Manuela Ramos for 1000 Soles (approximately US$334), which will be repaid in 5 months, she will increase her usual purchase, now she will buy 70 chickens daily, and thereby increase her income.

Elizabeth is very happy to see her business prosper, as that is an important achievement for her, and thanks to this success she has helped her family's well-being.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Elizabeth pertenece al Banco Comunal las Activas, vive en el Asentamiento Humano Señor D. los Milagros Jr. Pachacutec Mz A1 Lt. 06, del distrito Calleria, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 años D. edad y es madre D. 7 hijos, su esposo es motocarrista, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos del hogar, es así que Elizabeth, con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$100.00) deciD. poner una pequeña tienda D. venta D. pollos en el mercado Bellavista.

Debido a su negocio, se levanta a la 1 D. la mañana para ir a comprar las javas D. pollo y así poder iniciar la venta D. los mismos a partir D. las 5 a.m. La venta, normalmente termina a la 1 p.m., luego se dirige a su domicilio para descansar y prepararse para la rutina del día siguiente.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 1,000 (US$ 334.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 5 meses, incrementará la compra habitual D. pollos, ahora comprará 70 pollos a diario, D. esta manera incrementará sus ingresos.

Elizabeth está muy contenta D. ver que su negocio prospera, ya que es un logro muy importante para ella, gracias a éste ha alcanzado el bienestar D. su familia.
loan_use: Purchase butchered chickens

description:
Dinora G. is 33-years-old, is a native of the city of Bluefields, and is married to Ramón Rosales. They have 7 children. Mrs. G. is the owner of a business in which she sells cheese and cream. She has 2 years of experience. Her clients are men and women of all ages who prefer her because she offers a delivery service. Mrs. G. needs to buy 253 pounds of cheese at $1 each and 16 pounds of cream at $0.82 per pound. This investment will let her cover her demand.\r\n

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

\r\nLa Sra Dinora G. tiene 33 años de edad, es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, esta casada con el Sr. Ramón Rosales ambos tiene 7 hijos. La Sra G. es propietaria de un tramo donde vende queso y crema, tiene 2 años de experiencia. Sus clientes son hombre y mujeres de todas las edades que la prefieren por brindar un servicio a domicilio. La Sra G. necesita comprar 253 libras de queso a C$1.00 dólar cada libra y 16 libras de crema a C$ 0.82 centavos dólar la libra, con esta inversión podrá cubrir su demanda.
loan_use: To purchase cheese and cream

description:
Teresa de Jesus is a woman who studied to be an accountant. For a long time she worked as an accountant in a auto parts store. However, in a personnel "readjustment" she was fired. This left Teresa without that income that she received in her home. That is how she started looking for work, but she did not succeed and the household expenses grew more and more. Therefore, she decided to start her own business to be able to obtain extra income because what her husband makes as a chauffeur was not enough. In the beginning, Teresa sold general store merchandise, but later her customers started asking for haberdashery items as well as office supplies. This is why her business includes these three types of products right now.

Little by little Teresa increased her customers and right now she is in a good position in her neighborhood. However, Teresa thinks this is a good moment to increase her business, to stock merchandise for the Christmas season. This is why she is requesting a loan for US $ 575 to be paid in a period of 6 months. With this money Teresa will be able to paint her locale and buy merchandise like wrapping paper and house decorations. With your help, Teresa will be able to make her business succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Teresa de Jesús es una mujer que estudió para ser contadora. Durante mucho tiempo se dedicó a ser contadora en una refraccionaria. Sin embargo en un reajuste de personal la despidieron. Quedando Teresa desprotegida de ese ingreso extra que recibía en su casa. Así fue que comenzó a buscar trabajo, sin embargo no tenía éxito y los gastos en el hogar se hacían cada vez más grandes, por lo tanto decidió comenzar su propio negocio para poder obtener ingresos extras. Puesto que con lo que gana su esposo como chofer no les alcanzaba. En un inicio Teresa vendía mercancía de abarrotes. Pero después sus clientes comenzaron a pedirle cosas de mercería y de papelería. Es por eso que actualmente tiene un negocio en donde mezcla estos tres tipos de productos.

Poco a poco Teresa se fue haciendo de clientes y actualmente ya se encuentra más posicionada dentro de su colonia. Sin embargo Teresa considera que es momento para crecer su negocio y para surtir de mercancía para la temporada navideña. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $575 Para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Teresa podrá pintar su local y comprar mercancía para envolver regalos y adornos para las casas. Con tu ayuda Teresa podrá sacar adelante su negocio.
loan_use: Painting her locale and buying merchandise for the Christmas season. (Pintar su local y comprar mercancía para la temporada navideña)

description:
Eva started a general store business 5 years ago because they couldn't cover the expenses for their four children, because her husband works as a bus driver. Eva started adapting the entrance to her house with a metal sheet roof, and little by little it has been growing and she has gotten more customers and making her little store better. Currently, she has been able to build a concrete roof so thieves cannot come in because before that the roof could be easily bent or broken because of how old and rusted the metal sheet was.

However, Eva does not have a lot of merchandise right now, and this is why she is requesting a loan for US$650 to be paid in a period of 6 months. With this money Eva will be able to buy more merchandise for the Christmas season, materials to make tamales, Christmas dinner, and things for the posadas (pre-Christmas celebrations). "Knowing how to invest this money will be very useful to me because right now it is a season of good income since it is when people have money," Eva commented. With your help, Eva will be able to move her business forward.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Hace 5 años que Eva comenzó con un negocio de abarrotes, puesto que no le alcanzaba para pagar los gastos de sus cuatro hijos, puesto que su esposo trabaja como chofer de línea de autobuses. Eva comenzó adecuando la entrada de su casa con un techo de lámina y poco a poco creciendo ha ido haciéndose de clientes y adecuando mejor su pequeña tienda. Actualmente ya pudo hacer un techo de concreto para que los ladrones no puedan entrar. Puesto que antes era muy fácil doblar y o romper la lámina por lo viejita y oxidada que estaba.

Sin embargo actualmente Eva no tiene mucha mercancía, por lo tanto está solicitando un crédito de US $650 para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Eva podrá comprar más mercancía para la temporada navideña, materiales para elaborar los tamales, la cena navideña, y cosas para las posadas. “Sabiendo invertir este dinero me servirá de mucho porque ahorita es temporada de buenas ganancias porque la gente es cuando trae dinero” Comentó Eva. Con tu ayuda Eva podrá sacar adelante su negocio.
loan_use: Buying merchandise for her customers' Christmas dinners. (Comprar mercancía para las cenas navideñas que realizan sus clientes)

description:
At 57, Annie Y. only recently ventured into the world of business but has so far been very successful. In 2006 she established a business raising and selling pigs. This year she added two other businesses, one raising and selling chickens (to keep the pigs company) and a small mushroom farm. Annie requires a loan of $700 for these two budding businesses. She plans to add more feathers and fungi. Annie is a mother of two and the profits from her businesses help support her daughter Secelela, 17, her niece Rachel, also 17, and her granddaughter Janeth, 9. Annie, the girls and all the livestock thank you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback arrangement as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and they are therefore termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback".
loan_use: To purchase additional chickens and farm inputs

description:
This is Mama M.. She is 37 years old and married to Alphonsi with whom she has three children, Petro, 16, Edadi, 10 and Asante, 7. Aresia also cares for her niece, Upendo, 13 and her younger brother, Erici. She runs a business selling clothes and stationery and requires a loan of $275 to purchase additional stock and expand her business. She thanks you for your support. Happy lending!

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback arrangement as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and they are therefore termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback".
loan_use: To purchase additional stock for her businesses

description: Rukiah is 32 years old and has an 11 year old child.  She has been selling kerosene and  clothes on credit. She can earn US $20 per day. Her husband, S., is a driver with no regular income. She requests a loan to buy more goods and expand her business because it is the only source of income for the family. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.
loan_use: To expand her business

description: Mirvary H. (her daughter is pictured) is a widow. She was born in 1972. Mirvary with her daughter live in Salyan region, in the village of Yenikand. She started a farming business 15 years ago. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy a plot of land for improving her business.
loan_use: Buy a plot of land

description: Rashad (his father is pictured) is a single man who lives in Salyan region, in the Khaladj village. This man has 8 years of experience in farming. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy  vine props.
loan_use: To buy vine props

description:
Javier lives in a rented place in the city of La Paz. He paints small landscapes and does pencil sketchings, whichever his clients request. His income is limited, so he has decided to sell his paintings with framing and glass so that they have more value. The credit he requests is to buy materials (wood, glass and canvases).

An evaluation has qualified him for this new loan. Javier has already had 2 previous loans, which have been repaid in full.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

Javier vive en alquiler en la calle Ángel Dávalos de la zona de Tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz; la actividad que realiza es el arte de pintar cuadros pequeños de paisajes y además realiza el dibujo en lápiz según lo que le pidan sus clientes. Sus ingresos son reducidos por lo cual decidió vender sus pinturas con marcos y vidrio para que tenga mas valor; el crédito que solicita es para comprar material (madera y vidrio y lienzos).

La evaluación realizada lo califica para acceder a un nuevo crédito. Javier ya obtuvo dos créditos anteriores los cuales a la fecha están cancelados en su totalidad.
loan_use: Purchase of wood, glass and canvases.

description: Leyla is a mother of 2 children who lives in the Salyan region in the Khaladj village.  She was born in 1969.  Leyla has 10 years of experience in the farming business.  Now, she needs a loan of $1200 to buy fertilizer and pesticides.
loan_use: to buy fertilizer

description:
Modesta is married and has three grown-up children (ages 34, 30, and 20). The two elder ones are married and living with their families. The youngest son lives with his mom and goes to the university in Santo Domingo, the capital.

For more than three years now, Modesta has been selling men´s and women´s apparel, mostly pants and shoes. She says she started the business specially to support her youngest son´s studies.

Every day, friends and neighbors from her community visit her home to see and buy her goods. She says the customers are satisfied with the quality of her clothing. Currently, she has a well-established clientele. Her weekly profit is about US$ 100.

Modesta would like to be able to sell more and attract new customers. With this second loan, she will buy clothing in bulk in Santo Domingo to resell in her community. Modesta envisions her business becoming a big clothing store in a few years with a big and beautiful locale.
loan_use: Purchase clothing in bulk for re-sale

description:
Dorothy S., age 37, is married with 4 children (ages 14, 12, 5, and 2). About a year ago, she started her own tailoring business. Before this, she was taking tailoring classes and was selling sodas and sarongs. Her husband works as a clerk for a local organization.

Her tailoring business, where she sews and continues selling sarongs, is open from around 9am to 5pm daily. She charges about $4.80 for each piece she sews and currently makes a profit of around $18-27 per month from both her tailoring work and from selling sarongs. She uses her profits to increase her stock of sarongs and to pay the shop rent of about $14 per month.

Dorothy is the leader of Subgroup D of group “Tegemeo” (Swahili for “expectation”), which totals 21 members. She will be sharing this loan with her subgroup members: Jamila A. (selling clothes), Rudia H. (tailoring), Visa J. (selling clothes), Rose K. (selling firewood), Habiba R. (café owner), and Sara R. (selling clothes). She knows her subgroup well as they are neighbors and have shared 2 previous loans which they paid back successfully.

Dorothy used the 2 previous loans to buy a sewing and embroidery machinery, which initially got her business up and running. When her subgroup receives the new loan, she hopes to use it to increase her stock of sarongs during this Christmas season.

In the picture, Dorothy is in the back row, second from the right.
loan_use: To buy sarongs
borrower_names: Habiba, Sara, Jamila, Dorothy, Visa, Rudia, Rose
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
Manuela lives with her husband and three children in the neighborhood of La Pina, in the outskirts of Santo Domingo. Over the past several years she has started a business for herself where she makes and sells cloth curtains (which often serve as makeshift doors in homes throughout the Dominican Republic), sheets, and comforters. She is asking for her first loan so that she can buy better quality fabric and a few new patterns of fabrics from which she will make her sheets, curtains and comforters.

She says her goal is to improve her business step-by-step and to watch it continue to grow “more and more as each day passes.” Her dream is to see her children become educated professionals and to live a life of healthy decisions and love. Personally, she says she strives to always be a good, honest, and hardworking person.

Manuela wants to thank everyone who is supporting her with this loan, and she says that “if at any time you need anything, she is your friend, and her doors are open.”

NOTE: This is a group loan. Manuela is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of the loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.
loan_use: To buy better quality fabric and a few new patterns of fabrics.

description: Mrs. Sou S. V., age 28, works on her plot of land growing vegetables and raising domestic animals. Her husband would like to operate a motor-taxi business to increase the family’s income. They support one child who is too young to attend school and her elderly father who also lives with them. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a taxi business. They anticipate this will earn the family an additional $5 per day in revenue, which will help raise their standard of living and pay for their child’s education.
loan_use: To purchase a motor-bike for her husband to operate a taxi business.

description: Mr. L. Tres is 23 years old. He is single and lives with his widowed mother along National Road 6, about thirty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Tres has been a fisherman since 1998.  It's a skill he learned from his brother. He fishes in the Mekong River around his village and sells the fish every day. Beside fishing, Tres also buys and resells recycled material in his village. His mother also helps him with the fishing too. He has not even finished primary school.\r\n\r\nTres is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $350.  He will use this loan to purchase fishing nets for his fishing business.
loan_use: To purchase fishing nets.

description: Rashid is a 23 year old man. He lives is south Lebanon in the Nabatieh region. Rashid comes from a poor background but made it on his own and was able to open a barber shop. He needs a loan of $500 to buy the required products to sustain and develop his business.
loan_use: Rashid would like to buy the required products to run his barber shop.

description: Zamira is very creative. Her goal of participating in the Kiva program is to purchase different kinds of New Year's clothes for her little clients. She wants to make holidays more interesting and unforgettable for children, and she wans to supply her market with more holiday dresses. During her shop's activity (5 years), she noticed that children from her region (J.Rasulov)have not had the opportunity to buy New Year clothes. She had seen other children from foreign countries meet the New Year wonderfully, and she wants children from her region to meet the New Year holiday also with great pleasure. That is why she ordered to her friend who brings goods from Bishkek to export New Year costumes for her. She needs a loan to pay for this batch of goods.
loan_use: Purchase of clothes for the New Year (a special holiday) for her little clients.

description:
PASCUALA dedicates her time to the craftsmanship of skirts and blouses. She also makes pillowcases, shawls, serviettes, and tablecloths with typical designs from the region. She is 37 years old, has been married for 12 years and her husband is a florist, cultivating and selling. In general, almost the entire group is dedicated to artisanal work, as it’s in demand in the region, by the tourists who visit.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

\r\n\r\nPASCUALA, se dedica al bordado de faldas y blusas artesanales , también hace cojines , chales , servilletas y manteles todos con bordados típicos de la zona.Ella tiene 37 años, esta casada hace 12 años y su esposo se dedica al cultivo y comercio de flores. En general casi todo el grupo esta dedicado a los trabajos artesanales ya que en la zona que ellas viven los productos bordados son muy cotizados por los turistas que visitan la zona .
loan_use: TO BUY MATERIALS LIKE THREAD AND FABRIC.

description: Mrs. Khiev T., age 47, works with her husband on her plantation growing crops, making around $4 each day. They have five children, three who are employed at a garment factory, and two who are students. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a cow to help her plow her field. This will lead to a greater output of crops and increase the family’s income.
loan_use: To purchase a cow for her farm.

description: Kaltoum is a 39 year old woman who lives in the Beirut suburbs in the region of Borj el Barajneh. Kaltoum owns a grocery shop which is her only source of income. Kaltoum suffers from a physical handicap and is striving to support herself through her business. She needs $400 to purchase enough merchandise for her store. Kaltoum is a remarkable woman who is determined to stay independent.
loan_use: to purchase merchandise

description:
Bukari’s profession is a trader in recyclable materials to cover his family’s expenditure. Everyday he starts work at 7 in the morning and return home at 6 in the evening. Bukari purchase recyclable materials like used cardboard boxes, empty bottle, cans, iron, household equipment and others then these are resold to recycle consolidators. Profit generated by Bukari is used to fund this activities the balance to cover their daily living expenses. Besides that Bukari needs to pay the monthly lease for the room costing Rp. 150.000 (about USD16).

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Bukari berprofesi sebagai seorang Penjual barang bekas untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya. Setiaphari Bukari mulai bekerja pada pukul 07.00 pagi dan kembali lagi kerumah pukul 18.00 atau jam enam sore. Cara kerja Bukari adalah membeli barang-barang bekas seperti; kardus, botol kosong, kaleng, besi, peralatan rumatangga dan lain-lain yang kemudian barang-barang tersebut di jual lagi ke Pengepul barang bekas. Hasil yang didapatkan oleh Bukari digunakan lagi untuk modal usaha selain untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya bersama istri seiaphari. Selain itu juga Bukari harus membayar kontrakan kamar yang perbulannya harus dibayar dengan harga 150.000 rupiah.
loan_use: Capital for purchasing recyclable materials (Modal untuk membeli barang bekas)

description: I am Farzana K.. I am 36, married, and a mother of one son. My husband is a rickshaw driver and I am a seamstress.  I sew very trendy clothes in the latest fashion.  My clients like the clothes very much. I would like to borrow $350 to buy a more modern sewing machine for my business in order to respond promptly to my clients.  The wedding season has just started and I have a great number of orders to fulfill. Thank you.
loan_use: To buy a sewing machine and few other necessary materials

description: I am Farida A. Q. from Lahore, a big metropolis. I am 39, married and have five children. All of my children study at a local school. I am determined to support my husband by sharing his financial burden by stitching clothes for my neighborhood clients. My husband is a shoemaker and needs to expand his business. by buying raw materials such as leather, glue and decorative ornaments for his shoemaking business.She urgently needs a loan and is requesting a $500 loan.
loan_use: Expand shoes business

description: Bilal is a 31 year old man who lives with his wife and child in the region of Saida in South Lebanon. Bilal owns a bakery. He is planning to develop his business. He therefore needs to buy an electrical oven, tables and merchandise to be able to sustain and improve his bakery. Bilal is asking for a loan of $1000.
loan_use: to buy an electrical oven, tables and merchandise

description:
I have been in the footwear business for more than 34 years. This business is the source of income for my family and I have dedicated my whole life to the making of leather shoes. Right now I lack the raw materials needed to fill some requests. I am asking for a loan of $1,200 dollars in order to buy raw materials for making shoes.\r\n

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

\r\nTengo ya más de 34 años que me dedico a la elaboración de calzado. Este negocio es la fuente de ingreso de mi familia y me he dedicado toda mi vida en la elaboración de calzado de piel. Pero me esta haciendo falta materia prima para elaborar unos pedidos que tengo y solicito un préstamo de $1,200.00 Dlls para la compra de materia prima, para la elaboración de calzado.
loan_use: To purchase raw materials

description:
Gavkhar M. lives in Chkalovsk, Tajikistan; she is married and has 2 children. She has a supermarket in the bazaar in Ainy Park. She has a wide assortment of goods, and repeat customers. She has been in this business for 15 years. She wants to expand her business and open a new market. \r\n

Gavkhar M. has received loans of increasing amounts from MicroInvest since 2006. Her business is stable and income keeps increasing. Now she requests a loan of 2000 TJS (about $600) to fund opening the new market.
loan_use: Fund opening a new supermarket

description: D. is 38 years old and lives in Uromi, Edo state of Nigeria. For the past fifteen years he has been earning income as a carpenter. He has been a LAPO member for three years and now needs a loan of US$875 to buy wood and other materials for making furniture in his store.
loan_use: Purchase of wood and other materials needed for carpentry

description: Boyukxanim M. is a low-income vulnerable person. She is 49, married with three children and lives in the city of Sumgayit the east area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Boyukxanim is busy with mobile industry goods trading. She cannot develop her business, because she has no collateral to get a loan from commercial banks. That is why she applied for a $300 loan. She wants to increase the assortment of industry goods and to buy additional kinds retail goods. She will repay the loan within 12 months. She hopes eventually to expand her business. She believes that this will further improve the living condition of her family.
loan_use: to increase her assortment of industry goods and to buy additional kinds of retail goods

description: Ramez is 32 years old and lives with his family in the Bekaa region of Lebanon. Ramez rears and breeds animals and needs a loan to increase his animal livestock. Ramez loves his work and enjoys working in a natural environment. He is his household's sole provider and is known to be an independent and reliable person.
loan_use: To buy livestock

description:
Ganna lives in Mukachevo where she helps take care of her sick mother. Ganna is a small entrepreneur who runs a business selling clothing in the local mall. The type of inventory for sale in her store is always in high demand and she has many loyal customers. She has been in this trade for 12 years. Currently, Ganna has about $1500 in inventory.

\r\n\r\n

Ganna is a people person which is why it’s easy for her to build and maintain relationships with the circle of people around her and her business. Moreover, Ganna is a persistent hard-worker. She is very committed to her venture and invests much energy and effort in it. Presently, Ganna is requesting a loan of $1200 to increase assortment variety for her little store. She believes additional financing will help her venture expand and blossom into a successful, profitable business.
loan_use: To increase the assortment of home product inventory

description:
Yrene is 53 years old; she completed her studies up to secondary school and has 7 children, only one of which depends on her. She has two stands in the Bellavista market located in the district of La Esperanza, province of Trujillo. At one stand she sells food and at the other, shoes, slippers and sandals.

In order to get what she has today, Yrene has worked at different businesses. She started out selling sweets and gelatin deserts in the streets; later she devoted herself to selling pots and containers for plants, also in the streets, and at the same time sold clothing to people she knew. Little by little she saved enough money to rent a space and put up her first stand in the Bellavista market, where she sold food. With her first loan from the Bellavista communal bank, she bought some sandals to start up her second stand.

With another loan from Manuela Ramos, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy plates, silverware, pots, etc., which she needs to prepare meals and to be able to better serve her customers.

Her greatest dream is to buy some property within the market where she currently works.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Yrene tiene 53 años de edad, estudió secundaria completa y tiene 7 hijos pero solo uno depende de ella. Tiene dos puestos en el mercado “Bellavista” ubicado en el Distrito de La Esperanza, Provincia de Trujillo Departamento de La Libertad; en un puesto vende comida y en el otro vende zapatos, zapatillas y sandalias.

Para conseguir lo que ahora tiene la señora Yrene ha pasado por distintos negocios primero se inició vendiendo por las calles dulce de chiclayo, mazamorra y gelatina (postres), luego se dedicó a vender maceteros, también como ambulante, y en paralelo vendía ropa a algunos conocidos. Poco a poco fue ahorrando hasta que pudo alquilar e implementar su primer puesto en el mercado Bellavista donde vende comida. Con el primer préstamo que recibió en su Banco Comunal “Bellavista” compró sandalias para implementar su segundo puesto.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará platos, cubiertos, algunas ollas, etc., las mismas que le hacían falta para la preparación de comida y poder servir al público en mejores condiciones.

Su mayor anhelo es comprar un terreno dentro del mercado donde actualmente labora.
loan_use: Purchase of kitchen supplies (utensils).

description:
Carol is a very vivacious, outgoing person. She took me all over town visiting the other clients. When it came to visiting Frisita Nakieya we had to get on a boda boda (motorbike) to reach Frisita’s still. (That’s right; still, as in moonshine.) So, Carol gets us a boda boda driver and tells me to hop on. Then she tells me to squeeze up tight to the driver - real tight. And with one more big push she climbs on behind me, riding side saddle! Between the driver and Carol, I was as happy and as bubbly as a slice of hot cheese in a grilled cheese sandwich. We went for 45 minutes on a dirt trail through the hills with views of Lake Victoria that brought tears to your eyes. Man, this is what traveling is all about! But this is a story of Carol and her business.

\r\n

Carol owns a hair salon called Mama Emannuel’s Beauty Salon. As I indicated before, she is a classy, well-dressed lady with a heck of a spirit. She has been operating her salon for 8 years and for the past 10 years has been bringing her upbeat attitude to her lending group. At 32 years old, she is married with 5 children. Her dreams are to educate her children so that they can go to the university and to enlarge her business. For now, she plans to use her loan to buy more braids, weaves, shampoos and chemicals for her business. She brings a joy to the people around her.
loan_use: Carol plans to use her loan to buy more braids, weaves, shampoos and chemicals for her hair salon.

description: Rosemary O. is a 27-year-old married mother of 2 children. She has spent two years learning the art of dressmaking/embroidery and has offered her tailoring services within her community in Kisumu, Kenya since 2002.  She specializes in making women’s dresses, men’s shirts and also embroidery.  Despite the stiff competition in her area, Rosemary has always been able to attract old and new customers.  She constantly updates her materials to keep up with the current fashions, offers a wide selection of patterns and maintains a good stock to meet her customers’ demands.  Her hard work, years of experience and well-established client base ensure that her business will continue to succeed.  She plans to use three quarters of her next loan of US $ 800 to buy new patterns and materials, and save the remaining amount into her  account to use in case of unforeseen circumstances.
loan_use: Buy stock of tailoring materials

description:
Maman A. is a dedicated woman who has been selling yams at the market in Assahoun for eight years. She is 39 and a married mother of two children. The successful management of her business has allowed her to earn an income to help meet her family’s needs. She has been a FECECAV client for three years and has already received and repaid three loans. With this new loan, Maman would like to increase her working capital so she can build up her inventory and meet her customers’ demand.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Maman A. est une femme dévouée qui vend des ignames au marché d'Assahoun depuis 8 ans. Elle agée de 39 ans , mariée et mère de 2 anfants. Elle exerce avec succès son activité qui lui procure des revenus pour la contribution des charges familiales. Elle cliente de FECECAV depuis 3 ans et a bénéficié de 3 crédits qu'elle payé avec succès. Avec le présent crédit Maman voudrait renforcer son fonds de roulement afin d'acrroître son stock pour la satisfaction de sa clientèle
loan_use: Purchase of yams in neighboring villages to resell them in Assahoun

description:
Elizabeth, whose main qualities are her politeness and determination to develop, is a committed and cheerful mother. For the past seven years she has been selling pumpkin juice with apples, on a small tricycle which her husband, Zenón, adapted for the sale of her juices. These juices are an appetising and nutricious product in this area of the country. Elizabeth begins the daily preparation of her nutricious nectars at 2am, in order to then sell her product in the Main Square of her small town, Macari. She wishes to purchase another tricycle and thus increase her sales area for the greater convenience of her busy customers. In addition to this task, Elizabeth and her husband dedicate their time to caring for their three small cows, work which they carry out with great care and dedication which means they will achieve favourable results. The loan which Elizabeth has requested will be invested in another tricycle and the purchase of a small calf, and with these two investments her family's economic situation will be improved further still.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva translator

Su cortesía y empeño por progresar son las características principales de doña Elizabeth, madre empeñosa y alegre que desde hace siete años se dedica a la venta de jugo de quinua con manzana, en un pequeño triciclo que su esposo, Zenón, adecuó para la venta de sus jugos, producto muy apetitoso y nutritivo en esta zona de su país.Elizabeth empieza la preparación diaria de sus nutritivos néctares a partir de las 2:00 de la mañana, para luego venderlas en la plaza de armas de su pequeño pueblito, Macari. Tiene el deseo de comprar otro triciclo y así ampliar su puesto de venta para mayor comodidad de su concurrida clientela; adicionalmente a esta labor, Elizabeth y su esposo, se dedican al cuidado de sus tres vaquitas, faena que desempeñan con sumo cariño y dedicación y gracias al cual van obteniendo resultados favorables.La solicitud que hace doña Elizabeth los invertirá en adquirir otro triciclo y comprar otra becerrita, y con estas dos inversiones busca mejorar aún más su situación económica familiar.
loan_use: To purchase a tricycle and a small calf.

description:
With over a decade's experience running small companies, 38-year-old Saumu M. is a veteran businesswoman. In 1995, she started a company that sold bed sheets. In 2000, she established a chicken-raising business. And this year Saumu diversified further and bought a dalla dalla (a minibus, the main form of public transport in Tanzania), which is driven and managed day-to-day by an employee. Saumu requires a loan of $1,050, which she plans to use to expand the chicken-raising business. She is married to husband Nurunidi and has three children, Aziza, 14, Alfani, 8 and Rashidi, 4.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".
loan_use: To purchase additional chickens to raise and sell.

description:
Amidst a flutter of feathers, Mama Shafii feeds her brood -- but her name refers to her 6 year-old son Shafii, not one of the birds she is feeding. She raises chickens for sale and requires a loan of $625 to purchase more chicks. Mama Shafii is 27 years-old and married to Shafii’s father Mohamedi.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not credit-worthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".
loan_use: To purchase additional chickens to raise and sell.

description:
Esperanza del Socorro L. owns a shop at the Leon market. She has built her business with a lot of effort as she does not have a family and has therefore needed to survive without a family support.

She sells plastics and electric appliances on credit. She started with the business 17 years ago as a street vendor until she could get her own shop at the Leon market.

As she didn’t have a family support, she got a credit with CEPRODEL and ever since she has been able to witness a growth in her business which has allowed her to compete with other sellers and stand out due to her sells and the infrastructure of her shop.

It is important to mention that Mrs Lopez started with a capital of C$ 50,000 (2700 USD) and nowadays, 3 years after she got the credit, she has had a lot of success developing into an efficient competitor on the market of electric appliances.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Esperanza del Socorro L. es una dama el cual posee un negocio en el mercado de Leon. Actualmente ha podido construir su puesto de venta a base de mucho esfuerzo ya que no posee familia y por lo tanto ha sobrevivido sin el apoyo familiar.

El negocio al que se dedica la Sra. Socorro L. es a la venta al crédito de plásticos y electrodomésticos iniciando este negocio hace 17 años por medio de ventas ambulantes hasta llegar a tener su propio local en el mercado de Leon.

Por la ausencia del apoyo familiar, la Sra. L. decidió realizar un préstamo en CEPRODEL de manera que a partir de haber realizado dicho préstamo, ha podido contemplar un crecimiento en su negocio pudiendo de esta manera competir con otros negociantes y sobresaliendo en sus productos e infraestructura de su local.

Cabe señalar que la Sra. Lopez inicio con un capital de C$ 50,000 y hoy en día con tres años de tener crédito en Ceproidel, ha alcanzado grandes logros en su negocio convirtiéndose en una eficiente competidora en el mercado de electrodomésticos.
loan_use: Buy electric appliances to resell them on credit

description:
Suititi is married with ten children, and she’s 45 years old. She is very interested in working on her potted plants business, which she has been doing for three years. She applied for this loan (her second) in order to buy tools and add more new plants.

Most of her clients come over to her house and buy her plants. She earns about $100 USD ($250 ST) per week from her business or more if she has many clients that week. She also wishes to grow her green plants through her loans so the plants look pretty and she can get more money for them.
loan_use: To buy new tools and plants for her potted plants business

description: Jesse F. is from the village of Samatau. This is one of the oldest and most active centres of the loan program. She is applying for this loan in order to improve her business and also for the improvement of her house. Jesse delivers her biscuits to the urban retail shops five days of the week and makes 300 WST ($120 USD) a week. She has no husband or children, and she is responsible for taking care of her elderly grandmother and grandfather. She is one of the active members of the loan program, and she is looking forward to receiving more loans.
loan_use: To buy bags of flour, sugar, and other ingredients for her Samoan biscuits business

description: Velonika is from the village of Vaiusu. Velonika is on her fifth loan, and she is planning to use this loan on her lawn mowing business. Velonika’s husband does not work, and this is their only source of income. They work only when requested, and they also have temporary orders for the week. The money they get depends on the size of the area where they work. Velonika is one of our most reliable members. She is hard-working and active.
loan_use: To buy a new lawn mower

description: Mrs. Long S., age 25, is a garment worker, making around $2 per day. Her husband is a laborer, making about $2.50 each day. Her child is too young to attend school. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi, which will enable him to generate much more income than working as a laborer. This will help improve their family’s standard of living.
loan_use: To purchase a motorbike to operate a motor-taxi business.

description: Jumagul Z. lives in Mastchokh and she is married and has two children. She has been a client of MicroInvest since 2004 and she recommends herself as a serious and executive client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedures. She is engaged in commercial and trade service. Mrs. Z. is engaged in the business of selling children's and men's wear. She has a wide assortment. She is very polite which is why she has permanent clients who want to buy only her goods. She is very experienced in her business. But working in the trade sphere she meets hard competitors which is why she wants to widen her existing assortment. Now Mrs. Z. requires a loan of 2800 STJ to develop her business. She wants to widen her business to increase the family's income which allows her children to get a good education.
loan_use: Jumagul would like to develop her children's and men's clothing business.

description: Mrs. Yi K., 43, is a mother of four children and lives with her husband in a part of Siem Reap province, Cambodia.  She and her husband run a butchery stand at a market, earning collectively about $4 a day in profit.\r\n\r\nOne of her children works grinding rice crops and the other three are enrolled in school.  Mrs. Yi K. hopes to use this loan to expand her inventory by purchasing more pigs to meet her clients’ needs (as she mentioned, pork is now good to sell).
loan_use: To increase her inventory to meet her clients' needs.

description:
Ms. Phoy L. (age 33) lives in a small village near the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Phoy has one daughter, who attends school in their village. Phoy herself never attended school. Phoy buys produce from farmers, which she then resells at a large market in Phnom Penh. Every day, Phoy leaves her village with her stock of vegetables at about 1:00 a.m., riding in a shared pickup truck. In Phnom Penh, she sells her produce to retailers, and then she returns home by about 5:00 a.m. She has been doing this for ten years and often sleeps only four hours a night.

In the attached photo, Phoy is bundling the leaves of the “kon tuit” (starfruit) tree. Cambodians eat these with some fish dishes.

Phoy is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA for $400, to buy produce from farmers to resell at the market in Phnom Penh.
loan_use: To purchase produce for resale in Phnom Penh

description:
M. Zarobiddin is 45 years old, has higher education and a mechanic by profession. He is married and has 3 children. Zarobiddin's main work place is a joint-stock company "Ato" where he operates a press machine. Besides his job he is also raising cattle at his home which he has been doing for 3 years. With his loan, Zarobiddin plans to purchase 2 heads of cattle and food for them and then sell them after 40-45 days of feeding. He will use his profit to buy more young cattle and food to sustain them. During the 12 months, he will buy, feed and sell cattle and at the end of the loan term he estimates he will make a profit of 3 heads of cattle. Zarobiddin is planning to pay off the loan in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Миров Заробиддин, возраст – 45 лет, образование высшее, по специальности механик, женат, имеет 3-х детей. Основным местом работы Заробиддина являетя Акционерное Общество Закрытого тиипа «Ато», в должности прессовщика. Помимо этого он также занимается разведением курпного рогатого скота у себя дома. Этим видом деятельности он занимается уже в течение 3 лет. На полученный кредит клиент планирует приобрести 2 головы крупного рогатого скота и корма для них, которые после откормки, через 40-45 дней будет продавать. На вырученные деньги он будет покупать новый молодняк и корм для его содержания. Куплей, откормкой и продажей крупного роагтого скота он будет заниматься в течение 12 месяцев, в конце кредитного цикла клиент планирует получить прибыль в количестве 3 голов крупного рогатого скота. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.
loan_use: Purchase two heads of cattle for breeding and sale

description:
Tatyana is a single mother with a grown son. She lives in Zaporozhye and owns a vending business at the Angolenka market. Tatyana sells bedding, children’s clothing, and household items. She has been in this trade for 11 years. Presently, she has about $900 in turnover capital.

Tatyana has an entrepreneurial mind that is always lively, active, constantly calculating, and always on the lookout for the next big opportunity. Her business is profitable and stable, however, she would like to press on and expand it even more. Today, Tatyana is requesting a loan of $1000 to increase her stock and meet the growing demand from this Christmas season.
loan_use: To increase stock

description:
Señora Maritza is 42 years old. She finished high school. She has 3 children who still depend on her financially. They live in the district of El Porvenir, in the town of Trujillo in the state of La Libertad.

She works in the craft industry making sandals which she sells at wholesale price to the various different local markets in her city. She has also asked her sister to sell sandals for her in other cities.

Señora Maritza is a member of the local community bank called 'Creative Little Seeds' which she joined at a request from one of her sisters. She obtained her first loan of $300 Nuevo Sol which she purchased leather and synthetic material to make sandals.

With this loan of $175 USD, which she will repay in 4 months, she will purchase material such as leather, moulds, soles and much more.

Señora Maritza is not only happy at making sandals, but she would also like to one day open up a bookstore out of her house.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maritza Elia tiene 42 años, estudió la secundaria y tiene 3 niños que aún dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad. Se dedica a la fabricación artesanal de sandalias, las cuales vende al por mayor en los diferentes mercados de la ciudad, además también le da a su hermana para que los distribuya en otras ciudades. La señora Maritza es socia del Banco Comunal “Semillitas Creativas” al cual ingresó por invitación de una de sus hermanas y obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300, con lo cual compró cuero y material sintético para la confección de las sandalias. Con este préstamo de S/.500.00 soles, el cual se pagará en cuatro meses, comparará material como cuero, hormas, plantas, entre otros. La señora Maritza no solo se contenta con la fabricación de sandalias, sino que sueña con poner una librería en su casa.
loan_use: To purchase leather, moulds and shoe soles

description: Mr. P. Chamroeun and his wife have been married since1987. They have four children; two sons and two daughters. One of the sons builds wooden houses with him and one of his daughters is working in a garment factory. Chamroeun and his family live along National Road number One about twenty five kilometers from Phnom Penh. He started his business in the year 1985. His wife stays at home and takes care of their children.  \r\n\r\nChamroeun is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $500.  He will use this loan, in addition to other money he has saved, to purchase supplies for finishing his wooden house (shown in photo).
loan_use: Home building

description:
Lucia is a member of the community bank La Amistad in the district and province of Moyabamba, in the department (region) of San Martín. She works selling groceries in her house, which is located on Jaen Street in the Vista Alegre neighborhood of the city of Moyabamba. She started her business with a credit from the community bank and went along growing her business, little by little. She started with a table on which she displayed a few products. The business has grown thanks to her effort and the good service she provides to her clients. Lucia decided to start the business despite not being able to count on the support of her husband because she is a very hard working person with good business skills.
