What's more, generating her own income nourishes her self esteem and allows her to contribute to the expenses of helping her children get ahead.

This loan of 1800 soles (Peruvian currency), which she'll repay in 4 months, will buy groceries such as rice, sacks of sugar, boxes of milk of many different sizes and brands, boxes of oil, packages of detergents, boxes of noodles, onions, sacks of garlic, and other products to better stock her business. She wants her clients to find what they are looking for when they come to her store; her sales are stronger when she offers a variety of merchandise. She takes advantage of the fact that she has no competition in her neighborhood.

Lucia is 37 years old with 3 children. She now has her husband's help in the business, as well. Lucia is happy with what she does and satisfied by the resuilts she has achieved up to now. Her clientele has grown, which also has helped her improve her economic situation and contribute to covering the family 's expenses. Her goal is to one day have a kiosk across from her house. A grade school is currently under construction there, and she wants to be prepared when it opens for classes so that she can increase her business by selling refreshments.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Lucia es socia del banco comunal La Amistad del distrito y provincia de Moyabamba, departamento de San Martín. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en su casa que está ubicada en el Jr. Jaen S/N del sector Vista Alegre de la ciudad de Moyabamba. Se inició con el crédito del banco comunal y poco a poco fue creciendo. Se inició en una mesa con algunos productos. En la actualidad el negocio ha ido creciendo gracias a su empeño y la buena atención que les brinda a sus clientes. Decidió iniciar el negocio a pesar de no contar con el apoyo de su esposo porque ella es una persona muy trabajadora y hábil para el negocio, además genera sus propios ingresos, alimenta su autoestima y le permite apoyar con los gastos que requiere para sacar adelante a sus hijos.

\r\nEl préstamo de S/. 1 800.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará abarrotes como arroz, azúcar en sacos, cajas de leche de diferentes marcas y tamaños, aceite en cajas, paquetes de detergentes, fideos en cajas, cebolla , ajos en sacos, y otros productos para surtir mejor su negocio porque quiere que sus clientes encuentren lo que buscan, cuando hay variedad aumentan las ventas. Ella aprovecha que no tiene competencia en su barrio.

\r\nTiene 37 años y 3 hijos, ahora cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo, está contenta con lo que hace y satisfecha por los resultados obtenidos hasta la fecha, su clientela aumentó, eso también ayudó a que mejore su situación económica y apoye en los gastos familiares. Su meta es contar con un kiosco al frente de su casa, porque al frente se está terminando de construir un instituto y quiere estar preparada para cuando inicien las clases para ampliar su negocio con la venta de refrigerios.
loan_use: Buy groceries as inventory: rice, sugar, milk, oil, etc.

description:
Julia is 35 years old and has 2 children. Maria Carmen is 32 years old with 2 children, and Victoria is 31 years old and has 4 children. They are all part of the communal bank called Sol Radiante (radiant sun). They told us that they began their businesses with a savings of just a few dollars, and that the members of the bank are a close, united group, demonstrated by the fact that if somebody has a problem, everybody helps out.

Julia makes beautiful woven handicrafts, a skill she inherited from her parents. 20 years ago she began to make the pieces on her own, together with her husband and children. She creates individual pieces and sends them to Cusco to sell. In addition, she has a small general store in her house. Victoria also works with woven handicrafts. She learned from her husband who has been doing this since he was young. Like Julia, Victoria makes individual pieces and sends them to Cusco.

Maria Carmen, on the other hand, has a shop where she sells general groceries and speciality items. She sells her things from a space she rents close to the market of Santa Clara. She brings her products from Lima, and sells them wholesale. She used to also work in handicrafts, like her friends, but she left it to begin her business which was more profitable. She began her new work 6 years ago, selling door to door and around the markets, little by little growing the business.

Julia, Maria Carmen and Victoria will use their savings for their children's education, and to improve their homes. They will invest the money in cinnamon, mushrooms, cloves, noodles, milk, rice, sugar and sodas, as well as wool, dyes and threads. All of these woman have a dream that their children will receive a good education and become professionals, that their businesses continue to grow, and that they will have happy family lives.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Julia tiene 35 años y 2 hijos, Maria Carmen tiene 32 años y 2 hijos, mientras que Victoria tiene 31 años y 4 hijos. Ellas pertenecen al Banco Comunal Sol Radiante desde hace 13, 13 y 5 años respectivamente. Julia y Maria son fundadoras del Banco Comunal Sol Radiante, y nos cuentan que iniciaron con un ahorro de 2 dólares y que las socias en su banco son unidas y solidarias, lo cual se demuestra cuando las socias tienen algún problema y todas las socias se apoyan.

Julia hace lindos trabajos de Artesanía en Telar, arte que fue heredado de sus padres. Hace 20 años realiza los telares independientemente junto a su esposo e hijos. Ella elabora individuales y los envía a Cuzco, además tiene una tienda de abarrotes en su casa.

Igualmente Victoria realiza trabajos en telar, actividad que aprendió de su esposo que es artesano desde pequeño. Victoria, al igual que Julia solo hace individuales y también los envía a Cuzco.

Por otro lado Maria Carmen es comerciante y tiene una tienda de abarrotes y especerías. Ella vende en un local alquilado cerca al Mercado Santa Clara, y sus productos los trae desde Lima y vende al por mayor. Maria Carmen también fue artesana al igual que sus compañeras, pero dejó esta actividad por el comercio, que nos dice era más rentable. Se inició en este negocio hace 6 años como ambulante y poco a poco fue creciendo.

Julia, Maria Carmen y Victoria utilizarán sus ahorros para los estudios de sus hijos y para la mejora de su casa.

Ellas necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 800 soles y 800 soles respectivamente que serán invertidos en la compra de canela, hongos, laurel, achiote, comino, clavo de olor, fideo, leche, arroz, azúcar, gaseosas, lanas, tintes, hilos.

Los sueños de Julia, Maria Carmen y Victoria son que sus hijos sean profesionales, que su negocio crezca, vivir feliz junto a su pareja e hijos, y exportar sus telares.
loan_use: To invest in their respective businesses, purchasing  cinnamon, mushrooms, cloves, noodles, milk, rice, sugar and sodas, as well as wool, dyes and threads.

description:
Mayja belongs to the Communal Bank Atenas Portillanas. She lives at Jr. Sargento Lores Mz. B Lt. 06, Asentamiento Humano Pedro Portillo, in the Calleria district in Ucayali. She is 37-years-old and is the mother of two children, who are still minors. She is separated, which is why the income she had wasn't enough to cover her home's expenses. This is why Mayja, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 nuevos soles, decided to invest in buying and selling fruit.

Currently, she has an Internet cafe, which she attends to with her children, who help her. She also shares the household chores with them so they can then open their business and devote their attention to their clients. With this loan of 1,000 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy a computer, a monitor, a keyboard, a printer, and their respective installation so she can supply her business and have a larger clientele. Mayja is very happy because her business is attracting a lot of customers. Her income is increasing along with the well-being of herself and her children, who are her reason for living. This is all thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Mayja pertenece al Banco Comunal Atenas Portillanas, vive en el Jr. Sargento Lores Mz. B Lt. 06, Asentamiento Humano Pedro Portillo del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 37 años de edad y es madre de dos hijos menores de edad, es separada, de tal modo que el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para cubrir los gastos del hogar, es así que Mayja, con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00, decide invertir en la compra y venta de frutas.

En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de alquiler de cabinas de internet, donde atiende junto con sus hijos que la apoyan, además también con ellos comparten las tareas de la casa para después abrir su local y dedicarse a la atención de sus clientes. Con el préstamo de S/. 1.000, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará un CPU, un monitor, teclado, impresora, y sus respectiva instalación para implementar su negocio y su clientela crezca mas. Mayja está muy feliz, su negocio está captando mayor clientela. Sus ingresos están mejorando para el bienestar de ella y la de sus hijos, que son su razón de ser, y todo gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos.
loan_use: Purchase of assets (a computer, monitor, keyboard, and printer)

description:
Mrs. Um S., 35, is married with two school-aged children and lives with her husband in a part of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia.

She works as a broker purchasing yams from the growers and reselling them, and typically makes on average $5 per day of profit. Her husband is a taxi driver and can make around $5 per day.

Mrs. Um S. has humbly requested a loan to expand her business by purchasing more yams to meet her customers' demands.
loan_use: To purchase more yams from the growers.

description:
Zacarías is a relatively young businesswoman, and she and her partner have a very big family: ten children, seven of them girls. Just two of the children work while the others attend school.

Zacarías has been selling men´s clothing for two years. She runs her business in the morning, and in the evening she works in a lottery bank. Biweekly, she leaves her neighborhood to collect clothing from Santo Domingo, the capital. She also occasionally buys garments from a frontier city in Haiti.

With her loan, she plans to purchase used clothing in bulk to resell in her community. Given the loan, Zacarías will be in a better condition to improve her very needy family´s living conditions.
loan_use: To invest in the purchase of used clothing in bulk to resell in her town

description: Sieni is a married mother of 26 years of age. She has two children, aged 2 and 18 months. Sieni and her family had lived on a plantation all their lives, but unfortunately when the taro plight destroyed all the plantations on the island, her husband had no other choice but to look for a job in town. Sieni had always believed that the plantation earned more money than what her husband does. She tried so hard to go back to the plantation and when she heard of SPBD she decided to join so she could get a loan to assist with developing their plantation again. Sieni is very confident that through her first loan she will make a change in the plantation and it will enable her to bring her husband back to work on the plantation.
loan_use: Sieni would like to buy supplies for her plantation.

description: Lusia is a married mother of 39 years of age. She has four children whom all in primary school. The plantation has been their only source of income over the years, and they have always wanted to buy a back sprayer, but money has been her problem. Lusia heard of SPBD through the village women, and she thought this was the only opportunity where she could get financial help. With her first loan she bought more equipment used on her plantation. This is now Lusia's 4th loan request and with her loans she has managed to improve her family's lives and develop her business.
loan_use: Lusia would like to buy supplies for her plantation.

description: Fuad is a married man who does not have a child. He was born in 1980. This man lives in the Salyan region in the Yenikand village. He has been in the farming business for 4 years. Now he needs a loan of $475 to buy fertilizer to improve his business.
loan_use: To buy fertilizer

description:
Charles is 26 and married with two children. For the past four years, he has owned a welding shop. Welding is a good trade as there is always a need for quality welders. Most shops operate as small businesses alongside the roadways and can easily hire 2-3 additional workers. This is the type of business where once you are established, you will always stay busy. Many businesses that open require no trained skill, i.e. produce stands, and exist only temporarily as long as the operator shows up. With welding, you have a viable business that can even be handed down to your children or sold for a profit.\r\n

\r\nCharles is a very talented welder who enjoys his trade. With time, he can build a strong clientele. With his loan he plans to buy more metal and oil for his welding machine. His loan is relatively small, but he is new to his lending group. He will need to show that he is capable of repayment before he can acquire a larger loan. In lending groups, the group is responsible for the repayment of any member who defaults; consequently, they have the final say as to who will be a member and how large a loan each member should receive.
loan_use: To buy more metal and oil for his workshop.

description:
Ibrahiri is 51, married with 5 children, and cares for two orphans. He sells charcoal. This is an excellent business as everyone in the villages uses charcoal for cooking. Charcoal is cheap. It is not like the briquettes you buy in the store. It is made by felling trees, which are then chopped into pieces. A hole is dug in the earth and a smoldering fire is set. Banana leaves are placed over the hot coals, and the chopped pieces of timber are placed on the banana leaves. On top of the timber are placed more banana leaves. The entire pit is then buried lightly with loose dirt, enough that the coals can still breath. In three days the pit is opened, and the timbers have been charred all the way through, thus making charcoal. \r\n

\r\nA person selling charcoal will always be needed. If he can build a strong clientele, he can operate his business for a long time. He will buy charcoal in 100kg bags and sell by 2 cups. Villagers usually only have enough money to buy enough for each day, about 2 cups. So, each day they will revisit Ibrahiri and purchase a day's supply. With his loan, Ibrahiri will continue to buy more bags of charcoal.
loan_use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell.

description: This young man was born in 1985. He is single and lives in Khudat town. Rashid has 2 years of experience in this business. He buys the cattle to fatten for sale. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy 2 head of cattles for improving his business.
loan_use: To buy 2 cattles

description:
Margrete is a 56 year old widow who cares for six children, seven grandchildren and 100 chickens. With that many children around, she often goes to the henhouse when she wants some peace and quiet! Each hen lays an egg per day on average. Margrete collects and places the eggs in a 36-egg cardboard tray which she sells for about 3,000 Uganadan shillings (about $1.75).

\r\nHer daily collection of eggs brings her about $5.25 per day, which is above the national average in Uganda. However she then has to pay for chicken feed and new chicks from her income. With her Kiva loan, Margrete will buy more chicken feed and week-old chicks.
loan_use: Margrete plans to buy chicken feed and more week-old chicks with her loan.

description:
At 27, Mrs. Woévi A. is a young married woman and the mother of 4 children. She decided to begin her own economic activity, combining selling cosmetic products and bonbons. It is this enterprise that earns her money. Not currently having the means available to her to meet the many demands of her customers, she is applying for a loan of $250. The revenue she gains from this enterprise will help her to contribute to the household budget.

Translated from French by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Agée de 27 ans, Madame A. Woévi est une jeune dame mariée et mère de quatre (4) enfants. Elle a décidé d’associer la vente des produits cosmétiques aux bombons. C’est d’ailleurs cette activité qui lui procure de l’argent. N’ayant pas les moyens nécessaires, elle sollicite un crédit de $250 pour faire face aux nombreuses demandes de sa clientèle. Les revenus de cette activité lui serviront de mieux contribuer aux charges du ménage.
loan_use: The purchase and sales of cosmetic products.

description:
Mrs. C. is a married, 45-year-old mother of two who sells pet supplies—such as pet food, vaccinations, apparel, etc.—for a living.

She has had this business for over 8 years, and she tells us that she has a steady flow of customers who purchase products from her every week.

Lucia says that thanks to this business, she can help her husband cover both the household expenses and the education of her children, who have already finished school and are now entering college.

She is requesting this loan so that she can restock her shop.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Lucia tiene 45 años, está casada y tiene 2 hijos, ella se dedica a la ventas de artículos y suplementos para veterinarias como comidas para mascotas, vacunas, ropas, collares, etc.

El negocio lo tiene hace más de 8 años, y según nos cuenta la misma, posee clientes fijos que cada semana compran de ella sus productos.

Lucia dice que gracias a este trabajo ella puede ayudar a su marido a cubrir los gastos de la casa y la educación de sus hijos quienes ya culminaron el colegio y ahora deben empezar la universidad.

Desea el crédito para poder comprar más mercaderías para reponer el stock.
loan_use: Purchase of pet food, vaccinations, shampoo, powder, collars, pet apparel, etc.

description:
Juana is 35 years old. Currently, she lives in the Lamas district of the province of Lamas in San Martin. She has three children who are still minors.

Before becoming a member of the “Ciudad de los Tres Pisos” (City of Three Floors) Communal Bank, she used to sell beauty products. With the first loan of S/. 300.00, she was able to buy toys and some perfumes, with which she started a business in the house where she lived. Thanks to her earnings, and with the other loans she received from her Communal Bank, she now owns a business selling a variety of products.

With the loan of S/. 900.00, which she will repay in 6 months, she will purchase toys for boys and girls due to the upcoming holiday festivities. She will also buy perfumes and clothing for men, women and children, as well as a variety of home decorations to offer her demanding clientele. She dreams of opening a children’s clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Juana tiene 35 años de edad, actualmente vive en el distrito de Lamas, provincia de Lamas, departamento de San Martín. Tiene tres menores hijos. La señora Juana antes de pertenecer al banco comunal “ciudad de los 3 pisos” se dedicaba a la venta de productos de belleza. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, pudo comprar juguetes y algunos perfumes, con lo cual abrió un negocio en la casa donde vivía, posteriormente gracias a sus ganancias y con los otros préstamos que recibe en su Banco Comunal posee un negocio con variedad de productos. Con el préstamo de S/. 900.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará juguetes para niños y niñas con motivo de estas fiestas navideñas, también comprará perfumes y ropa para damas, caballeros y niños y variedad de adornos para el hogar para ofertar a su exigente clientela. Sueña con abrir una tienda de ropa para niños.
loan_use: Purchase toys, perfumes, clothing and home decorations.

description: Kolopa is a 20 year old married mother from Malie J3 centre. She is one of a newest members applying for a loan.  She sells ice cakes (popsicles in a bag) from her own house.  She sells 100-150 ice cakes a day, which cost 50 sene (20 cents) each and she earns about $100-150 WST ($40-60 USD) a day. Her husband has a taro plantation but that does not stop her from trying to look for another business to support her new family.
loan_use: To buy supplies for her ice cake business

description: Lotoi is a widowed mother of 66 years of age. She is overage to get any loan from the program but she is fit and healthy plus she received help from her two sons. She is applying for a second loan just to extend and to help out with her family remittances.
loan_use: To buy supplies for her plantation

description: Roxanna is in her late twenties, and she is a single mother of two children.   Her son and daughter both attend school.  Roxanna runs a very small store that she recently started. She sells an assortment of perfumes, shampoos and other beauty products.\r\n\r\nThe entrepreneur is working very hard to make her business known in the community and to increase her clientele.  She is requesting a loan to increase the inventory for her store.  She wishes to continue to satisfy her customers’ demands and increase her income.  Roxanna wants to provide a comfortable lifestyle for her two children.
loan_use: To replenish a small store in order to satisfy her customers´ needs.

description: Folole is 37 years old, from one of the villages in town, and married to a man from Samusu. She has 5 children. Her husband is a strong farmer, but she never stops thinking about a business for some extra money. She started her small shop just in front of her house last year, and she earns $120-160 USD a day.
loan_use: To restock her shop

description: Tala is a widowed woman of 67 years. She is a member of Papauta centre. She is one of the longest standing members at the Papauta centre. She runs a sewing business by herself from her own house. She sews three to four puletasi (traditional Samoan garments worn by women) a day. She earns about $200.00-250.00 WST ($80-100.00 USD) a week. She is applying for this loan so she can buy another sewing machine.
loan_use: To buy sewing supplies

description: Petra is a married woman of 27 years of age and is currently a member of Lalovaea centre. She is one of the older members who started Lalovaea centre. Her business is sewing, which she does by herself at her own house. She sews 3-4 puletasi (traditional Samoan woman garments) per day. She earns about $200.00-250.00 WST ($80-100 USD) a week. To buy another sewing machine is the reason she applied for another loan.
loan_use: To buy sewing supplies

description: Taaitulagi is an old member of SPBD that supports her family through running her vegetable garden from the loan that she received from the SPBD Program. She is a young woman of 24 years of age and has five kids. She goes to the market once a week and she earns about $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD). Her first and second loan were use to buy stock for her vegetable garden, but to maintain and enlarge the garden is the reason she is applying for another loan. Also she plans to fix the floor of her house and to help out with her family remittances.
loan_use: To buy supplies for her vegetable garden

description: I am Shamim Bibi and a mother of five children between 10 to 23 years. I live with my family in Lahore. My husband Nazir sells steel, tin and bronze scrap. I fix artificial gems and stones on shawls for someone for daily wages. I need a loan of $500 for my husband’s scrap business. It is difficult to meet our household expenses with our current limited income, and therefore we want to increase our income.
loan_use: Expand scrap business

description:
Loice is a 30-year-old married woman who looks after her own four children as well as three orphans. She runs a tailoring business and sells the clothes she tailors. Tailoring clothes in her village involves using a treadle sewing machine. In fact, in these villages, it is common to see people pedaling away on their treadle machines outside their tailor shops. Clothes made by a tailor are always cheaper than store-bought and is more compelling for buyers because they can take part in the design!

\r\n\r\nTailoring is also a skilled trade, so if you have a knack for it and produce good work, you will always be in need, unlike a produce stand that can be here today and gone tomorrow. Here’s another interesting fact: In Uganda, young girls in rural areas often do not complete their formal education. Once a girl drops out of school, she becomes economically vulnerable and her hopes and dreams fade away. The abililty to learn a trade is therefore important so that she can support herself as boost her self-esteem. With her Kiva loan, Loice plans to buy more material and embroidery for her tailoring business.
loan_use: Loice will use her loan to buy more material and embroidery for her tailoring business.

description:
Nurmilah is 28-year-old woman who has a small shop where she sells snacks and drinks, and also household products. She can earn about US$ 100 per month with a small profit. Her husband, C., has no fixed income. She is requesting a loan to expand her and her husband's business.

Nurmilah hopes that she can increase her income so she can provide her children's tuition. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.
loan_use: To expand her and her husband's small store

description: Firangiz is a mother of 4 children. She was born in 1962. This woman lives in the Khachmaz region. She buys hazelnuts from the villages and prepares the kernel of the nuts at her home to sell. Firangiz has run this business for 5 years, to support her family. Now she needs a loan of $850 to buy hazelnuts to improve her business.
loan_use: to buy hazelnuts

description:
Mila is 26 years old. She studied only through primary school. She wasn't able to continue her studies because her parents had very little money and so she had to give the opportunity to learn to read and write to her younger sisters and brothers. She has 2 children; both remain dependent on her. She lives in the housing development Palermo in the district of Chao in the Virú province of the department (region) of La Libertad in Peru.

Mila decided to start her own business as a way of helping with the household expenses, since her husband does not have a full time job. She prepares and sells grilled chicken weekends in her house. She sells beer and soft drinks, as well. She does this work during the weekends because weekend days are the pay days of the workers in the local agribusinesses. She also works growing and selling ducks, pigs and sheep. With her earnings she is beginning to set up a small general store.

Mila is the President of the group Las Luchadores. With this group she received her first loan of 200 soles (Peruvian currency) with which she bought an oven to prepare the chicken; previously she had been renting her oven. With this new loan of 600 soles, which she will repay in 4 months, Mila will buy feed for the animals with plans to sell them duing the end-of-year holidays. Mila dreams of having her own house someday.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Mila tiene 26 años de edad, estudió solo primaria, no pudo continuar sus estudios porque sus padres no tenían dinero y tuvo que dar oportunidad a que sus hermanos más pequeños por lo menos aprendan a leer y escribir. Tiene 2 hijos y ambos dependen de ella. Vive en el Poblado Menor Palermo del Distrito de Chao de la Provincia de Virú del Departamento de La Libertad.

Decide empezar su negocio para ayudar con los gastos de su hogar ya que su esposo no tiene un trabajo fijo. Se dedica a preparar y vender pollo a la brasa los fines de semana en su domicilio, ahí aprovecha también para vender cerveza y gaseosa. Esta actividad la realiza solo los fines de semana porque son los días de pago a los obreros de las empresas agroindustriales; también se dedica a la cría y venta de patos, pavos, cerdos y ovejas. Con las ganancias que tiene está empezando ha implementar un apequeña bodega. La señora Mila es Presidenta del Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Luchadoras”, en este grupo obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.200.00 soles, con los cuales compró un horno para preparar el pollo a la brasa ya que antes tenía que alquilarlo. Con este préstamo de S/.600 soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará alimento para sus animales los que venderá en las fiestas de fin de año. La señora Mila sueña con tener su casa propia.
loan_use: Purchase of animal feed

description:
Sharon N. currently sells firewood. She will use the loan to increase her stock of firewood in order to increase her sales and profits.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.
loan_use: To expand her stock

description:
Marry J., age 36, is married with one 9-year-old boy. She owns two businesses- a cafe and a business selling soap. She began these businesses in 2006 and now she makes about $106 in profit monthly. Her businesses operate from 4pm to 8pm daily. \r\n

\r\nIn the past, Marry took out an $88 loan from BRAC Tanzania which she was able to pay back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to buy more stock for her businesses. She will be sharing this loan with her subgroup member Ester L., who is also a food seller.
loan_use: To purchase more food stock for her cafe and to also increase her soap inventory

description: Sopiyah is a 30-year-old woman who has a small shop where she sells snacks, household goods, beverages,  cigarettes, rice and many other things. She can earn about US$ 44.50 per month, due to the amount and variety of goods she has in stock. Sopiyah is requesting a loan to fill her shop. Her husband has no fixed income, so she has to work hard for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.
loan_use: To buy more inventory for her little shop

description:
Sayina N. is requesting a loan in order to buy more charcoal and sugarcane to increase her sales.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.
loan_use: To buy more charcoal

description:
Aisha N. wants a loan to purchase more stock to add to her agriculture business. With the extra profits, she hopes to be able to meet her basic needs.

loan_use: To purchase more stock

description:
Justine K. is requesting a loan to allow her to open a new selling space beside her existing store where she sells fish and operates a restaurant.

loan_use: To expand her store

description:
Miriam L. has a retail store, a stone quarry, and rears cattle. She will use the loan to increase her stone inventory, buy more stones, purchase another farm, start a brick making business, purchase a calf and buy feed for her cow.

loan_use: To buy farm inputs
borrower_names: Joyce, Cate, Immaculate, Betty, Numi, Annet, Miriam, Lydia
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
Margaret M. sells clothing and charcoal. She sells her charcoal and clothing outside and, when it rains, her stock is damaged. With a loan, Margaret wants to build her own store. With her profits she will pay her children’s school fees and build her own home (rather than renting it as she does now).

loan_use: To buy more stock

description:
Sarah S. wants to set up her own bakery. She is requesting a loan to purchase baking supplies. In addition, she also wants to buy a fridge with the loan.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.
loan_use: To set up a bakery

description:
Marian B. is a 45 year old married mother of 4 (14, 18, 23, 25) who operates a tailoring business as well as rearing chickens. She will use the loan to bring in more chicks and to purchase feed. With the profits from these birds she will build another poultry house.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.
loan_use: To bring in more chicks and feed

description: Ai J. is a 38-year-old woman who owns a small grocery store selling rice, snacks, vegetables, etc. She usually earns US$17 a week, while her husband Mad Sari does not have a permanent job. Ai is asking for a loan to buy various goods for her store. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.
loan_use: Purchase of goods for a grocery store

description:
Carmen is 49 years old. She is married to Antonio who is her same age. The couple has two children who are 20 and 16 years old. The oldest son is following the course of admission to enter a university while still studying in high school.

Carmen owns a grocery store where she began working 40 years ago and she explains that it was owned by her father until it died 10 years ago, so he left it for her to run.

Her husband is a carpenter by profession, and with the income he generates, helps with the household expenses.

The grocery store Carmen runs is well stocked and has a good clientele. Their project in the short term is to invest in building a bigger room so they can expand their grocery store.

Now she is requesting a loan to buy flour, sugar, sweets, beverages like soda, juice, wine, cider, etc., since the Christmas and New Year holidays will bring in customers who will want to purchase these products.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Carmen tiene 49 años. Está casada con Antonio que tiene la misma edad que ella. La pareja tiene dos hijos de 20 y 16 años respectivamente. El mayor de los hijos está siguiendo el cursillo de admisión para ingresar a una carrera universitaria mientras que la menor aún continúa estudiando en la secundaria.

Carmen es propietaria de una despensa que funciona hace 40 años y según comenta ella, la misma era propiedad de su padre hasta que este falleció hace 10 años, quedándose Carmen al frente de la misma.

Su esposo es carpintero de profesión, y ayuda, con los ingresos que genera su trabajo, con los gastos del hogar.

La despensa de Carmen se encuentra muy bien surtida y cuenta con buena clientela. Su proyecto a corto plazo es invertir en la construcción de un salón más grande con el fin de surtir más su negocio.

Ahora necesita de un préstamo para la compra de harina, azúcar, panificados, bebidas como gaseosas, jugos, vinos, sidra, etc. ya que en las fiestas de navidad y año nuevo aumentan las ventas de estos productos.
loan_use: To purchase flour, sugar, sweets, soft drinks, juices, wine, cider, etc. (compra de harina, azúcar, panificados, bebidas como gaseosas, jugos, vinos, sidra, etc.)

description: Elshad is 47 years old, married and has 2 children. The M. family lives in Khachmaz town. Elshad buys chickens and raises them for sale. He has run this business for 4 years.  Now he needs a loan of  $475 to  buy  hens and chicken for increasing his income.
loan_use: To buy  hens and chicken

description:
Galina is divorced with one child. She lives in Ordzhonikidze and sells plastic bags and purses in the central city market. Galina has a wide assortment of inventory and a variety of sale offers. Demand for this type of merchandise is consistent which creates good potential for the future. Galina has been in this business for 4 years. Presently, her income is about $600 per month. \r\n

\r\nGalina is hoping to open a new vending spot and increase her turnover capital. That is why she’s requesting a loan of $1200 to start working on this business project. One of her long-term plans is to open a wholesale business, selling plastic items to smaller entrepreneurs at affordable prices. We believe Galina’s perseverance, management skills and enthusiasm will help her achieve her goals and succeed in business.
loan_use: To open a new vending spot

description:
We are a group of women who would like to make crafts and house wares using local products. We make house wares with materials such as palm tree bark and leaves, with which we make things such as laundry baskets, breadboxes (which we sell in restaurants), mats and other types of baskets. Financing will allow us to buy a large quantity of raw materials and to train young girls in the village in the art of basket making. This will help discourage young people from fleeing to the city. It will also allow us to make brooms, which we sell in big cities in Senegal. This will be our group’s second loan, but this time it will be for a limited amount so that we will be able to create a sustainable business.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Nous sommes un groupe de femmes qui voudrais confectionner des objets d'art et d'ustensiles de maison
avec des produits locaux. Notre travail consiste à fabriquer des ustensiles de maison avec des matériaux comme le rônier et les feuilles de palmier avec lesquels nous fabricons des paniers à linge ou de rangement des paniers à pain que nous vendons dans des restaurants, des nattes et autres objets de vannerie. Le financement nous permettra de pouvoir acheter la matière première en quantité suffisante et nous permettra ainsi de pouvoir former des jeunes filles du village au métier de vannerie, contribuant ainsi à la lutte contre l'immigration des jeunes vers les villes. Cela nous permettra aussi de fabriquer des balais que nous vendons dans les grandes villes du Sénégal. Ce sera le deuxième prêt que notre groupe va recevoir, mais cette fois ci ce sera un nombre très limité, afin que le financement puisse nous permettre de créer une entreprise durable.
loan_use: Purchase of raw materials to make crafts

description:
Eliodora is married. Her husband is named Juan Jara and they have three children, all of whom are in high school. Her husband is a farmer and she is an ambulant vendor of crafts. As a result of their work and the sacrifices they’ve made, Eliodora and her husband have their own home.

Among the things that Eliodora sells are artisanal bed covers made by hand with cotton thread that is also made by hand by the artisans in the city. Every morning, she travels through the neighborhoods, house by house, offering her products that are very well accepted.

In addition, she raises pigs and slaughters them in order to sell them. This generates a good extra income. Eliodora is soliciting a credit so that she may buy bed covers in different sizes and colors in large quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Eliodora es una señora casada, su marido se llama Juan Jara y tienen 3 hijos, todos cursando sus estudios secundarios. Su marido se dedica a cultivar la tierra y ella es vendedora ambulante de artesanías, gracias al trabajo y sacrificio de ambos ya tienen su casa propia.

Entre las cosas que vende Eliodora, podemos citar cubrecamas artesanales hechos a mano y con hilos de algodón que también son hechos a manos por las artesanas de la ciudad. Todas las mañanas recorre los barrios casa por casa ofreciendo sus productos que son muy bien aceptados por sus clientes.

Además de esto, ella cría cerdos y los faena para venderlos, esto le genera un buen ingreso extra. Solicita el crédito para comprar cubrecamas de diferentes tamaños y colores en grandes cantidades.
loan_use: Purchase of bed covers of different types.

description:
Sergio has two children who are 2 and 11 years old. He wishes to give them the best so they can have a future with better possibilities than he had. His grandfather began to work as a carpenter and taught this trade to his son and to Sergio. He passed along secrets and the best way to work with wood. Nevertheless, when his children began to grow, Sergio decided to become independent from his father so both of them could make more income.

However, the fight to grow has made him work at top speed. This is why Sergio is requesting a loan of $475 that he is willing to repay in 6 months. With this money, Sergio will be able to buy wood to make furniture to offer his clients. With your help, Sergio will be able to get ahead in his business, and his children will have a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Sergio tiene hijos de los 2 a los 11 años, a los cuales desea darles lo mejor para que tengan un futuro con mayores posibilidades que el. Su abuelo fue quien comenzó a trabajar en el terreno de la carpintería enseñándole a su hijo y este a Sergio, pasándose los secretos y la mejor manera de aprovechar y rendir la madera. Sin embargo cuando sus hijos comenzaron a crecer Sergio decidió independizarse de su padre para así obtener más ingresos entre los dos.

Sin embargo la lucha por crecer lo ha ido llevando a trabajar a marchas forzadas. Es por es oque Sergio está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesto a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses. Y con este dinero Sergio podrá comprar madera para poder elaborar muebles para tener qué ofrecerle a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Sergio saldrá adelante en su negocio y sus hijos tendrán un mejor futuro.
loan_use: To purchase wood to make his products

description: Arzu has run this business for 5 years. This 32-year-old woman is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory. She lives in Fuzuli town and is settled in the Finnish houses, which are built temporarily on the front line in the Fuzuli region. She is single. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy goods to improve her business and get more income.
loan_use: To buy goods

description: “I love my small town, Vehari, that I have been living in for the past 15 years. I live in a mud and brick house with my husband and five children. My eldest boy and girl attend a school located in our local neighbourhood, while the rest of my children are too young to go to school. My husband requires a loan to purchase goats which we will sell over the Eid (a religious Muslim festival). During the Eid season, we will be able to sell the goats at a higher price. We took a loan last year for the same business and with the substantial profits we repaired our house, and we reinvested some of the profit in our business. We hope to do the same this year.”
loan_use: to purchase goats for re-sale for the Eid (Moslem holy day)

description: My name is Azra B. and I am a widow with four children: three sons and one daughter. One of my sons is a turner and possesses his own lathe. His business is our major source of income. He would like a loan of $175 to expand his business. I will save the profits to help my children marry. I currently supplement our household income by selling cloth and crockery from my home.
loan_use: To expand her family's business

description:
Tatyana K., who is 43, has a bachelors degree, is married, and has 2 children. Currently, Tatyana works at a Magnet School #1 in the town of Kurgan-Tube as an elementary school teacher, and her husband temporarily works in Russia. Using the loan, she is planning to purchase a computer for her children. Tatyana wants her children to learn how to work with a computer, since it is such an important part of our everyday life. Once her children with have their own computer, there will no longer be a need to use services of an internet cafe and pay additional fees. Tatyana plans to pay off the loan in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Хайдарова Татьяна, возраст – 43 года, образование высшее, замужем, имеет 2-х детей. Татьяна в настоящее время работает в лицее №1 города Курган-Тюбе, в должности преподователя начальных классов. На полученный кредит она хочет купить персональный компьютер для своих детей. Ее муж в настоящее время находится на заработках в Российской Федерации. Татьяна хочет чтобы ее дети научились работать на компьютере, так как сегоденя компютер это неотъемлемая часть во всех сферах нашей жизни. Ее дети получат возможность иметь свой собственный компьютер и не надо будет ходить в интеренет-кафе и платить за пользование компьютером дополнтельную плату. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.
loan_use: Purchase of a computer for students

description: My name is Tanzeela B.. I am married with four children: two of them are finished with their studies and are currently working whereas the other two attend school. My husband operates a secondhand store in the used items market of Lahore. One of my sons also assists him in the business. My son has gained enough experience and now feels that he can open his own shoe store. Please lend us $175 for this purpose.
loan_use: Open an additional shoe store

description:
Mohira Aminjanovna S. has been selling women's clothing for seven years. She has two children. Her husband was a construction worker who was killed on the job. After she was widowed, Mohira's brothers helped her support her children, but before long she had to find a source of income to feed her family. In 2000, Mohira began to trade at the market in Istravshan. She used some of her profits to enroll her daughter in a sewing course. Now her business is stable. She buys goods wholesale from Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan and sells them at her local market. She needs a loan in order to increase turnover and inventory.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Собирова Мохира Аминчановна в течение 7 лет торгует женской одеждой. Имеет 2 детей. Муж умер на производстве . Он работал строителем. После смерти мужа чтобы прокормит детей ей помогали ее братья но со временем потребность стал больше и она была вынуждена искать источник дохода чтобы прокормит детей. Начиная с 2000 года она стала торговать на вещевом рынке города Истаравшан. На полученный доход она обучила дочь на курсы шитья . В данный момент у нее есть стабильный бизнес. Она привозит товар оптом из Бишкека (Киргизстан) и продает на рынке. Она нуждается в финансировании чтобы увеличить товарооборот и асортимент товаров.
loan_use: Expansion of assortment of goods.

description:
Mr. Teodoro González Yegros resides in San Antonio city, San Ignacio state, and is owner of a animal clinic called Santa Rosa, located in the center of San Antonio. 

He sells supplies for cattle as San Antonio is a city where the main activity is agriculture and beef.  Among the supplies he sells are vaccinations and mineral sals for beef, he also provides animal health services. 

The income he receives from this activity helps maintain his family, which consists of 3 daughters ages 25, 20 and 16, who with their mother have a vegetable selling business in their home. They also cover the education expenses that the oldest daughter has as she is finishing her studies in Encarnación city.

He is asking for a loan to purchase mineral salts as the demand during this time of year is particularly high.


Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Descripción:	 El Sr. Teodoro González Yegros, reside en la ciudad de San Antonio distrito de San Ignacio, es propietario de una veterinaria llamada Santa Rosa, ubicado en el centro mismo de la mencionada ciudad.

 Se dedica principalmente a la venta de insumos para ganados ya que se encuentra en una ciudad donde la actividad principal es la agricultura y la ganadería. Entre los insumos que vende podemos citar vacunas y sales minerales para ganado vacuno, también realiza servicios de sanitación animal.

 El ingreso que percibe por esta actividad ayuda a la mantención de su familia, que lo constituyen sus 3 hijas, de 25 20 y 16 años de edad respectivamente, quienes con su madre en su domicilio particular poseen venta de verduras. También cubre los gastos de estudio que posee la mayor de sus hijas que se encuentra culminando sus estudios en la ciudad de Encarnación.

 Solicita de este préstamo para compra de  sales minerales debido a la demanda que posee en esta época del año es bastante alta.
loan_use: Purchase mineral salts for animals

description:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị T., 23 years of age, has been running her clothing store for 5 years. It is her family’s traditional business. Her husband, Nguyễn Văn Minh, lends her a hand in taking care of the store. Clothing sales are currently booming and profitable. After all expenses, the yearly income is about 3000USD. She often said: “This business of my family always relies on loans.” That’s the reason of her joining TYM Fund. In 5 years, her loans has totaled to 2000USD. This time Mrs. T. is applying for a loan of 950USD for purchasing more goods to get ready for this year’s Tết.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Nguyễn Thị T., 23 tuổi, mở cửa hàng kinh doanh quần áo cách đây được 5 năm, đây là một nghề chính của gia đình chị. Chồng chị, anh Nguyễn Văn Minh là người thường xuyên hỗ trợ chị trong việc kinh doanh. Nghề kinh doanh hàng quần áo của chị T. hiện nay rất phát triển, sau khi trừ chi phí, thu nhập một năm của gia đình chị khoảng 3000USD. Chị thường xuyên tâm sự, với nghề này thì gia đình tôi lúc nào cũng cần đến nguồn vốn vay. Do vậy chị đã tham gia vào quỹ TYM đã được 5 năm và đã vay tổng số vốn của Quỹ là 2000USD. Hiện nay chị đang đề nghị Quỹ cho chị vay mức vốn 950USD để mua thêm hàng về bán vào dịp Tết âm lịch.
loan_use: Buy clothes

description: Mrs. Dy C., 47, is the mother of three married children and works with her husband selling traditional medicines in her community, earning collectively about US$ 5 each day in profit. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle to use for their business transportation and buy more medicines in order to expand their inventory. In the future, Mrs. Dy C. hopes to save a lot of money to keep investing in and expanding her business.
loan_use: To purchase a motorcycle to use for her business transportation and buy more medicines in order to expand her inventory

description:
Mrs. Finè O. is married and the mother of four children. Her principal business venture is selling cooked food (a restaurant serving African cuisine). She needs to be able to stock grains and other foodstuffs for use in her little restaurant. To resolve the problems she encounters in managing her restaurant, she is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 so that she can satisfy her customers' needs in a timely manner. This loan will allow her to buy bags of corn, vegetables, and condiments to have on hand.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Agée de 35, Madame O. Finè est mariée et mère de quatre (4) enfants. Son activité principale est la vente de denrées alimentaires (restaurant à la cuisine africaine). Son programme à travers ce projet est de s’approvisionner en produits alimentaires et céréales pour son restaurant. Pour résoudre un certain nombre de problèmes qu’elle rencontre dans l’exercice de son activité, elle sollicite un crédit de $1000 afin de pouvoir satisfaire dans les délais les commandes de ses clients. Ceci lui permettra de s’approvisionner en sacs de maïs, légumes, et autres condiments.
loan_use:
Buying food ingredients for her little restaurant

Approvisionnement en produit alimentaire pour son restaurant

description:
Mrs. Akou A. was born in 1977 and is married and the mother of two children. Her main business is selling personal care products which she presently carries through the streets in a basin balanced on her head. Very ambitious and intent on helping her husband provide for their family, she is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 1000 so that she can open a little kiosk where she can display and sell her products. This will free her from the necessity of walking from place to place to sell her wares.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame A. Akou est née en 1977, marié et mère de deux (2) enfants. Son activité principale est la vente des produits cosmétiques qu’elle fait promener dans les quartiers. Très ambitieuse et voulant plus contribuer aux charges du ménagé, elle sollicite un crédit de $1000 pour ouvrir un petit kiosque et exposer ses produits. Ceci l’épargnera des kilomètres qu’elle parcourt afin de vendre ses produits.
loan_use:
Opening a little kiosk for her personal care products business

Achat et vente de produit cosmétique

description:
Yolanda is 60-years-old and is a cheerful and active woman. She has copy machines with which she offers services to the general public, and she also has copying contracts with some well-known companies in the region. She and her husband, Severo, no longer have the responsibility of caring for their children, since they are professionals, have their own families, and live in different cities throughout the country. Both have the goal of putting their copy machines in place and maintaining them, with the aim of continuing their work with satisfaction. Let's offer Yolanda a breath of hope so she can accomplish her goals as soon as possible.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

\r\nYolanda de 60 años de edad, es una mujer jovial y súper activa, tiene sus máquinas copiadoras con los que brinda servicios al público en general, también hace contratos de copias con algunas empresas reconocidas en la zona.En compañía de su esposo el señor Severo ya no tienen responsabilidades con sus hijos, ya que los mismos son profesionales, se hicieron de familia y se encuentran radicando en las diferentes ciudades de su país.Ambos tienen una meta, implementar y realizar el mantenimiento respectivo a sus máquinas copiadoras a fin de seguir desempeñándose con satisfacción en esta su labor.Otorguémosles un aliento de esperanza a la señora Yolanda para que en el menor tiempo posible se cumpla sus propósitos.
loan_use: Expansion of her service space and maintenance of her copy machines

description:
Liz Carolina is 28 and a single mother; she has a 3-year old son named Luis Miguel, who is her motivation to get ahead. Liz Carolina\'s objective for herself and her son is to provide him with an education and with all he needs to become a competent professional. To reach this goal, she sells fast food such as "salchipapas" (a Peruvian dish of sliced hot dogs with french-fried potatoes) and broasted chicken, which help her to support them economically. For this reason, she needs a loan to keep growing, as her goal is to increase her sales and to soon build a small shop. With your help, Liz will get ahead in a very short time.

\r\n

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

\r\nLiz Carolina de 28 años de edad es madre soltera, ella un niño de tres añitos de edad, llamado Luis Miguel, motivo por el cual le inspira a seguir adelante, el propósito que Liz Carolina tiene para si misma y su hijo es brindarle una adecuada educación y todo lo necesario para que sea un profesional competente, para alcanzar este propósito se dedica a la venta de comidas al paso como: salchipapas y pollos broaster, que le ayuda en su sustento económico.Por tal motivo requiere de un capital para seguir creciendo, ya que tiene como meta ampliar su venta de comida y poner pronto su bodega.Con tu ayuda la señora Liz saldrá adelante en muy corto tiempo.
loan_use: Start up a business and build a small shop.

description: “I live in Lahore the second largest city of Pakistan. I have five children, two boys and three girls and all of them go to school except the youngest one who is only two. My husband and I want to pay-off our Rickshaw (local three wheeled vehicle) which we bought a few years ago. With a loan we will be able to pay off the cost of the Rickshaw and it will be ours and we will save on interest payments. Besides driving the Rickshaw, my husband does gardening, which brings in extra income. Hence, we would have no trouble paying off your loan.”
loan_use: Pay-off a Rickshaw

description:
Julia has been selling fruit for the past 22 years. She started her business with her own savings and a loan. She decided to start this business after finding herself unemployed. Her family runs a small stand in the market. This has been the only means they have found for earning a living. The financial assistance of CEPRODEL would allow Julia to develop her business by purchasing in bulk. She could thereby offer a better price for her products.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Julia se dedica a la actividad de venta de frutas desde hace 22 años inicia su negocio con sus ahorros y un préstamo .

Decide el iniciar su propio negocio al quedarse sin empleo ademas de que su familia tiene sus pequeños negocios en el mercado por ser la unica forma que encuentran de ganarse su sustento diario.

Con los financiamientos de CEPRODEL le permiten el desarrollo de su negocio, compra de contado y ofrece a un mejor precio sus productos.
loan_use: To purchase fruits and vegetables

description:
Irina lives in Beregovo, western Ukraine. She sells second hand footwear in a local market called “Progress”. Irina’s business has been growing consistently because of little competition in the market. She started selling second hand items eight years ago. Today she has about $4000 in inventory. Her monthly net profit is about $500-600.

\r\n\r\nIrina is requesting a loan of $1200 to increase her turnover capital and assorted inventory in her kiosk. She enjoys doing what she’s doing and likes working with this type of merchandise. Irina wants to invest her savings in opening a new vending facility in the future. We believe her focused efforts, hard and committed work and great communication skills will help Irina grow in her business and be a successful entrepreneur.
loan_use: Increase capital and inventory

description:
Maria started this work twelve years ago with her life savings, selling breakfasts starting early in the morning at bus stations located in the markets of Managua.

With the financial support of CEPRODEL, she has been able to develop her business and, in addition, now has an area where she sells meals at breakfast, lunch and dinner to customers that come by her establishment.

One of her goals is to improve the condition of her establishment so that she can provide better service to her customers and, above all, have a prosperous family life so that her children improve their standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Maria inicia esta actividad hace doce años con los ahorros de toda su vida vendiendo desde muy tempranas horas sus desayunos ambulantes en la terminales de buses en los mercados de Managua.

En el transcurso del tiempo y con el aporte financiero de CEPRODEL ha logrado el desarrollo de su negocio y además cuenta con un tramo en donde vende sus comidas en el desayuno, almuerzo y cena a sus clientes que llegan a su establecimiento.

Una de sus metas es mejorar las condiciones de su establecimiento para brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes y sobre todo prosperar en vida familiar para que sus hijos mejoren su nivel de vida.
loan_use: Purchase of merchandise.

description:
Oscar C. sells vegetables; at the beginning he walked around the bus stations offering his products.

As time went on he decided to request a loan so that he could set up his business at a stand. Oscar tells us that the economic support that CEPRODEL has given him has been decisive in the development of his business and has allowed him to improve his standard of living. He no longer sells by walking around but now has his own stand. One of his greatest dreams is to improve the condition of his stand as well as improve the standard of living of his parents, who are now elderly and need his support.

His stand is very simple but his business contributes to the support of his family and allows his children to go to school.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

Oscar C. se dedica a la actividad de venta de verduras, en un inicio oferta sus productos ambulantes en la terminales de buses.

En el transcurso del tiempo decide solicitar financiamiento para instalar su negocio en un local especial. Manifiesta el Sr. Oscar que el aporte económico que la han brindado en CEPRODEL ha sido decisivo en el desarrollo de su actividad por lo que le ha permitido mejorar la calidad de vida, ya no anda ambulante sino que ahora tiene un local propio y uno de sus mayores sueños es mejorar las condiciones de su local así como mejorar las condiciones de vida de sus padres los cuales ya son adultos mayores a los que tiene que apoyar.

Actualmente su local no tiene muchas condiciones pero con su negocio contribuye al sustento de su familia y le permite que sus hijos estudien.
loan_use: Purchase of merchandise.

description: Mrs. Kosal D., 26, is married and lives with her husband and one school-aged child at Preveng Province, Cambodia. She and her husband run a store in their home selling coffee and soft drinks to the people in their community, earning collectively about US$ 6/day in revenue. This couple would like to request a loan amount of $1200 to expand and invest in their business so that it enables them to meet their clients’ needs and raise their standard of living.
loan_use: To expand and invest in their business so that it enables them to meet their clients’ needs and raise their standard of living.

description:
Here we find Mrs. Eulalia, working anxiously in her small carpentry workshop. This noble profession, to which she's been devoted from four months ago, helps to provide higher education to her three beloved children, while also helping two other children who look after the welfare and safety of their respective families. Mrs. Eulalia's greatest dream is to make her small carpentry shop, one of the largest and most recognized in the city of Juliaca. She plans to realize this goal by working carefully and thoroughly putting her best effort in each piece of furniture she makes. Her desire is to offer beautiful, fine and innovative works to her clients, in order to ensure that they feel very satisfied and pleased with the results of her products. To this end, Mrs. Eulalia wishes to obtain a loan which she'll invest towards the purchase of good quality wholesale lumber, so she can slowly meet the demands of her customers. Eulalia hopes to count on your help. Please don't let her down.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Encontramos a doña Eulalia, trabajando ansiosamente en su pequeño taller de carpintería, este noble oficio al que se dedica desde hace cuatro meses le permite brindarle estudios superiores a sus tres queridos hijos, y al mismo tiempo ofrecerle trabajo a otros dos jóvenes quienes velan por el bienestar y seguridad de sus respectivas familias.El deseo más grande de doña Eulalia es hacer de su pequeño tallercito de carpintería uno de los más grandes y reconocidos de la ciudad de Juliaca, es por ese objetivo que trabaja con sumo cuidado y detalladamente poniendo lo mejor de sí en cada uno de los muebles que realiza, con el fin de ofrecerles hermosos, finos y novedosos trabajos a sus clientes, con el propósito de que sus exigentes usuarios se sientan muy satisfechos y contentos con los resultados que obtienen.En esta oportunidad doña Eulalia desea obtener un préstamo de dinero para invertirlos en la compra de mayor cantidad de materia prima (madera) y así cumplir poco a poco sus metas propuestas.Eulalia espera contar con tu apoyo, no la defraude.
loan_use: To purchase high quality wholesale materials (lumber).  (Compra de mayor cantidad y variedad de materia prima.)

description:
Renaldy works renting computers because she couldn't find a job, so she decided to invest her small savings and a loan from CEPRODEL in this business, which contributes to supporting her family.

One of her goals is to improve his locale's conditions, buying a photocopier machine to offer a larger variety of services to her customers, who come to her business in search of those services.

Renaldy is hopeful of the development of her business because with the financial help offered by CEPRODEL she is able to offer better computer rental services to her customers and in this way support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Renaldy, se dedica al servicio de alquiler de computadoras por circunstancias de no encontrar empleo y decide invertir un pequeño ahorro y un préstamo que le aporta CEPRODEL en este negocio, el cual le contribuye al sostenimiento de su familia.

Una de sus metas es mejorar las condiciones de su local, comprar una fotocopiadora para brindar una mayor variedad de servicios a sus clientes varios que acuden a su establecimiento en busca de sus servicios.

Renaldy, tiene esperanzas en el desarrollo de su negocio ya que con el aporte financiero que le ha brindado su mano amiga CEPRODEL le permite el brindar un mejor servicios de alquiler de computadoras a sus clientes y de esta forma ha logrado el sustento de su familia.
loan_use: Buying computers for his business (Compra  de computadoras  para  su negocio)

description:
Mrs. Martha M. has been selling fruit for the past 10 years. Through loans, she has been able to purchase oranges in bulk and sell them in her neighborhood early in the morning.

Although she currently has only a small plot at the local market with a plastic roof, she has not lost hope that one day her business conditions will improve.

She believes that Ceprodel’s financial support has been the economic pillar that has allowed her to develop her business and improve her family’s quality of life. She hopes to continue developing her business little by little.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Martha se dedica a esta actividad hace 10 años y es por medio de prestamos que logra adquirir naranjas al contado para venderlas en los barrios aledaños a su domicilio desde muy tempranas horas.

Aunque actualmente tiene un pequeño tramo en el mercado con techo de plástico no pierde la esperanza en que algún día las condiciones de su local se mejoren.

Considera que el apoyo financiero otorgado por Ceprodel ha sido el pilar económico que la ha permitido el desarrollo de su negocio y a mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia y espera ir mejorando las condiciones de su local poco a poco.
loan_use: To purchase merchandise

description:
In 1993, when Ana Lidia's mother was diagnosed with diabetes, she started looking for a way in which she could acquire money. That is how she started applying facials professionally, since she was a cosmetologist. She started working in a room in her house and little by little, and since her son (who is now 15) needed more money to pay for his schooling, in 1998 she started selling shoes, which is easy for her because her customers are housewives and she offers them a good price.

However, right now Ana Lidia needs two chairs to apply the facials to her customers. This is why Ana Lidia is requesting a loan for US $925, which she is determined to pay in a period of 6 months. With this money Ana Lidia will be able to buy the chairs so her customers can be more comfortable while she applies the treatments, and so they will return more often because of the good work and comfort she offers. With your help, Ana Lidia will be able to support her son.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

1993 cuando a la madre de Ana Lidia se le detectó diabetes comenzó a buscar la manera de poder adquirir dinero, fue así que comenzó a aplicar tratamientos faciales en forma profesional ya que cursó la carrera de cosmetología e inició en un cuarto de su casa poco a poco fue creciendo, y como su hijo quien hoy tiene 15 años necesitaba más dinero para poder costear los gastos de su escuela en 1998 comenzó a vender calzado, ya que se le facilita esta venta por que su clientela son amas de casa y les ofrece buen producto a bajo precio.

Sin embargo actualmente, Ana Lidia necesita dos sillones para poder aplicar los tratamientos a sus clientes. Es por eso que Ana Lidia está solicitando un crédito de US $925 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Ana Lidia podrá comprar los sillones para que sus clientes puedan sentirse más cómodos en el momento en el que les aplican sus tratamientos. Y así ellos regresen más seguido por el buen trabajo y la comodidad. Con tu ayuda Ana Lidia podrá sacar adelante a su hijo.
loan_use: Buying chairs for beauty salon

description: Sulastri is s 27-year-old woman. Since joining MBK, she has been selling motorcycle spare parts. Her husband, H., has no fixed income. She requests a $100 loan to buy more goods and expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.
loan_use: To buy more inventory

description:
J. Musharaf is 45 year old lady. Musharaf’s husband is a mechanic. Musharaf and her husband have 3 children of school age and live together with Musharaf’s husband's parents. They both are working hard in order to support this large family and to ensure their children shall have opportunity to have higher education.

Musharaf sells fabrics for sewing national dresses. She has been in this business for more than 30 years. The national dress in Tajikistan is very beautiful and is one of the most important items in the dowry of a girl. Tajikistan is located in Central Asia and the spring is the most beautiful season for this region. When you see all these national dresses it seems that you are admiring the scenery awakening from a cold winter; the green leaves and grasses, bright red and yellow tulips in the mountains, and a blue sky which is so close to you in spring.

Musharaf has a very good taste and she is ready to advise her clients which textile to choose for this or that occasion. That is why she has customers. Moreover, Musharaf’s prices for fabrics are attractive for various levels of the population as she has a wide range of goods for any taste and any wallet.

Now Musharaf needs a loan for purchasing new fabrics. She has been the client of IMON for about 4 years. She was provided with loans for enlarging her range of goods. She has the positive credit history with IMON. Musharaf promises to pay the loan in 4 months.
loan_use: Purchasing of new fabrics

description:
Salma, age 35, is married with 2 children (ages 7 and 3). She owns a grocery store, which she began 4 years ago. Her business is open from 8am to 11pm daily, and she makes a monthly profit of about $140.

In the past, Salma took out 3 previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase her business. She now hopes for a new loan to start a water business and chicken business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in selling various foods, clothes, and charcoal.

In the picture, Salma is in the front row, third from the left.
loan_use: To start two additional businesses
borrower_names: Salma, Sikujwa, Neema, Zena, Hawa, Salma, Selina
borrower_genders: female, male, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description: Shukur is 59 years-old and is farmer who raises sheep in a southern small village in Imishli region. He raises and sells sheep to the local businesses and traders.  He has more than fifteen years of experience in breeding sheep. He is married and has six children. It is very hard to cover the family’s needs, as breeding sheep is the only income in his family. Now he needs $1200, he will repay it in 18 months. He needs this amount to buy more sheep to continue to expand his herd.  He thanks you in advance for the loan.
loan_use: Going to build sheep herd

description:
I am Naziran B., wife of Amanat Ali. I am a mother of six, one of whom is married. I live with my family in a small town, Depalpur, Pakistan. My husband operates a used clothes shop. He has been in this business for the past 20 years. He earns reasonable profits out of this business. Now, we want to expand our business and need a loan for this purpose.

My group members are also in need of loans and I request loans for them: Salma B. needs a loan for her husband’s wholesale business; Ulfat B. requires loan for her brother’s fruit business; Nasreen Anwer also needs a loan for her husband's business; Shugufta B. needs a loan for her husband who is an electrician.
loan_use: Expand used clothes shop

description: Tabu, age 28, lives with her parents and supports her 3 year old child with her cafe business. She started this food vending business in 2006 and now makes a monthly profit of about $160. Each day, Tabu works from 7am to noon, serving a variety of breakfast snacks. Tabu now requests a loan to buy more food stock to increase her cafe's business.
loan_use: To buy food stock for cafe

description:
Amancio is 50 years old. He works hard in his small farm of fruits, which for a long time has become the main source of income to provide for his beloved children. The responsibility to fulfill the rolls of father and mother in his home was very difficult . When he was told that he was going to have his first baby he was very happy and he has been since then.

His children are his motivation to keep working hard in obtaining every time better fruits in his harvest. Amancio’s new goal to start in the coffee production, since he did a business research and found out that the investment of the other families members of his community has been very profitable. He ask for your support to reach his desire to continue working for the well-being of his four beloved children. He ask for $525 that will pay off in six months.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva volunteer.

Amancio a sus 50 años, trabaja fervientemente en su chacra de frutas, la cual desde hace mucho tiempo se ha convertido en la principal fuente ingresos económicos para sus queridos hijos, la responsabilidad de cumplir los roles de padre y madre en su hogar era muy dificultoso pero no imposible ya que desde que le informaron que iba a tener su primer bebé estuvo muy feliz por la buena.La retribución diaria de sus hijos a través del inmenso cariño que le manifiesta impulsa a Amancio a seguir trabajando como hasta ahora para obtener cada vez mejores frutos en su cosecha y además para plantearse el nuevo reto de su incursión en la producción de café ya que durante meses realizo un estudio y se dio cuenta que la inversión de las otras familias miembros de su comunidad ha sido muy rentable..Requiere de vuestro apoyo para alcanzar su deseo con el deseo de seguir trabajando para bienestar de sus cuatro queridos hijos.
loan_use: Expand and capitalize his business

description:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 47-year-old Bertha M.. She is married with three children, aged 18, 23, and 25.
 
In 2001 Bertha established a dairy business. Bertha has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requests a loan of $875 in order to purchase additional livestock and milking equipment. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is an organization that is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania. Through leasing and leaseback, SELFINA provides a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.
