Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 2007.\nCe premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra de refaire son stock avec 20 paires de chaussures, 5 douzaines habits, et 10 pièces de pagnes.\n
description_translated:
Ms. Diane T. was born on October 27, 1974 in Sokodé, a city in Togo. She is single and does not have any children. Her business is to sell shoes, clothes and lengths of brightly colored African cloth. She buys these items in the main market of Lomé and resells them in the Agoè district in the north of the city to serve her local clients. She began this business in 2007. This first loan that she is taking out will allow her to restock with 20 pairs of shoes, five dozen outfits, and 10 pieces of the brightly colored African cloth.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase shoes and clothes

description: Madame N. Dzigbodi Mawéna est née le 24 décembre 1953 à Atakpamé ville située à 165 Km de la ville de Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de quatre (4) enfants. Elle a pour activité principale la vente des produits de consommation courante et de pagne dans le quartier d’Agoè au nord de Lomé. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé et a commencé cette activité depuis l’année 2007.\nCe premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter des pagnes pour une valeur de 100.000FCFA et des produits de consommation courante pour une valeur de 200.000FCFA\n
description_translated:
Mrs. Dzigbodi Mawéna N. was born on December 24, 1953 in Atakpamé, a town situated 165 km from the town of Lomé (the capital of Togo). She is married and the mother of 4 children. Her principle business is selling food staples and "pagnes" (brightly colored lengths of African cloth used as clothing, turbans, and to carry babies) in the Agoè neighborhood north of Lomé. She buys her inventory in the big open-air market of Lomé and began her business in the year 2007.

This first loan that she is requesting will allow her to buy 100,000 F CFA worth of "pagnes" and 200,000 F CFA worth of food staples.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: purchase of "pagnes" for re-sale

description:
La señora María Gloria Morínigo, es casada, vive en casa propia,     tiene dos  hijos, quienes  son  mayores de edad. La misma cuenta con una lavandería para ropas. En Paraguay, las personas llevan sus ropas a las lavanderías para que las personas ahí se encarguen de lavarlas y plancharlas pagando por el servicio, a diferencia de otros países en donde las personas hacen uso de las máquinas solamente y se encargan de lavar sus propias ropas.

El negocio lo tiene muy bien ubicado, situado a dos cuadras de la Avda. Eusebio Ayala, que es una de las principales avenidas de la ciudad. Se inició con un de aproximadamente U$ 650 que fue ampliando con el correr de los años, pues actualmente cuenta con una amplia cartera de clientes.

La señora María Gloria Morínigo retira el préstamo para la adquisición de un secarropas más para poder abastecer con los trabajos que tiene.

Uno de sus aspiraciones es poder ampliar próximamente este negocio, en lo que se refiere  al equipamiento o mobiliario,  y poder ofrecer un ambiente más cómodo y ameno a sus clientes.
description_translated:
Mrs. María Gloria Morínigo is married, lives in her own house, and has two children that are already grown. She has a landromat. In Paraguay, people bring their clothing to laundromats so that the people there deal with washing and ironing them, paying for that service, which is different from other countries where people make use of machines and take care of washing their own clothes.

The business has a very good location, situated two blocks from Avda. Eusebio Ayala, which is one of the main streets in the city. She started with approximately US$ 650, which has increased with the passage of time, and nowadays she counts on a broad client list.

Ms. María Gloria Morínigo withdraws this loan to acquire another dryer to be able to keep up with the work that she has.

One of her aspirations is to be able to expand this business soon, referring to the equipment or furnishings, and to be able to offer a more comfortable and pleasant environment for her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Tatman Montgomery, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy a dryer for clothes

description:
El Joven Marvin Sánchez C. tiene la edad de30 años, su estado civil es casado, tiene 2 hijas  su hija mayor Karen  tiene la edad de 6 años cursa recientemente el 1 grado de primaria y su hija menor génesis de 7 meses quien no estudia, su estado civil, su esposa labora en la venta de mercadería en general, sus deseos son de prosperar y mantener su negocio activo en sus propósitos esta el obtener su propia casa ya que actualmente donde reside es de mama y desea acondicionarla para que sus hijas tengan su casa propia y también proporcionarle a sus hijas un futuro de estudios.


El tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio  es de 4 años, su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general que consiste en la venta de pantalones, camisas, trajes para niños y trajes para dama, el inicia este negocio por cuenta propia y empieza colocando pequeñas cosas de venta como: colas, diademas y trajes para niños y mas tarde su esposa piensa en la idea de la venta de ropa y es así como inicia este negocio, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo ya que necesita realizar la compra de sus productos en Managua .
description_translated:
Mr. Marvin Sánchez C. is a 30-year-old married father of two children. The eldest child, Karen, is 6 years old and in the first grade, while the youngest, Génesis, is 7 months old. His wife works selling general merchandise. He hopes that his business will be prosperous and active. Because he currently lives with his mother, he plans on obtaining his own house and wants to furbish it so that his daughters can have their own house. He also wants to provide his daughters with an education.

He has had this busines for 4 years. He sells merchandise such as pants, shirts, children’s outfits and women’s dresses. He started this business on his own account, initially selling small items like hair bands, headbands and children’s outfits. Later, his wife got the idea of selling clothing, which was how this business was formed. The loan will be used as work capital because he needs to purchase merchandise in Managua.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Work capital

description: Mrs. Vu Thi M. is 53 years old.  She has 4 children and all of them are grown-up.  She lives in Nam Viem Commune, Phuc Yen District, Vinh Phuc Province.  In 1999, she joined TYM and accessed her first loan to invest in raising pigs. Now, her main income sources are raising pigs and her sons' salaries . For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow 10 million  to buy more pigs and feed for raising them.\r\n\r\n
loan_use: to buy more pigs and feed for raising them

description:
Kayum J. is 45 years old. He is married and is the loving father of 4 children. For 11 years, Kayum has been raising cattle and growing wheat on his land. He is planning to sow wheat on his 2-hectare plot of land. 

He wants a loan to purchase mineral fertilizer, and fuels and lubricants to prepare the land. In addition, he raises cattle with the help of his older sons. He want to spend part of the loan to rebuild his cattle shed. For these purposes, Kayum is asking for a loan of 3500 Somoni for 12 months. 

You can become an important part in Kayum family's life. He deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.
loan_use: To purchase fuels and lubricants, and to rebuild his cattle shed

description: Fidel tiene 41 años de edad, es conviviente, su esposa e hija, por el momento viven en la ciudad, él vive con su padre. Desde muy niño se ha dedicado a la agricultura, su padre es propietario de varias parcelas de terreno con acceso a la carretera, por ello que siembran en todas sus chacras, mayormente cultivan carambolas y demás frutas cítricas, cuando es tiempo de cosecha, envían sus frutas por camión a la ciudad. Sembrar carambolas le es muy rentable, porque es una planta que una vez que empieza a dar fruto no detiene su producción, es por ello que casi en todas sus chacras han sembrado carambolas, Fidel conoce muy bien cuando abonar y cuidar adecuadamente la planta. Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP. Con el dinero solicitado comprará insecticidas para evitar a las mosquitas que perjudican las hojas a las carambolas, también comprará abono para su chacra.
description_translated:
Fidel, 41, is partnered. His wife and daughter are living in the city for now, while he\'s living with his father. He\'s worked on farms since he was a boy. His father owns some land with access to a road so they can plant all over the land. They mostly grow "carambolas" [a kind of mango] and citrus fruits. At harvest time, they deliver their fruit to the city by truck. Growing carambolas is very profitable because once it starts to fruit, it doesn\'t quit. That\'s why almost the entire farm is planted in carambolas. Fidel well knows when to fertilize and how to adequately care for the crop. This is his third MFP loan. With the money, he will buy insecticides to ward off the bugs that damage the leaves of the carambolas. He\'ll also buy fertilizer for the farm.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy supplies for farming business.

description:
Patience O. A. is 35 years old. She is widowed and the mother of five children. Through her business, Patience supported two of her children through senior high school and continues to support the others who are still in school.

She is a food vendor who sells kenkey, as well as maize. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked, and then taken with hot peppers and fried fish. She has many customers since many Ghanaian enjoy kenkey for breakfast, lunch, and supper.

She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children’s education.

Patience O. A. belongs to the community group called "Abrabopa" (meaning Good Life) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans. She does not sell on the days the group meets. Her picture was taken during one of the group meetings.
loan_use: Buy ingredients like maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood

description:
La señora Mery Antonieta, socia del Banco Comunal “DORADINAS EN ACCION”, vive en el departamento de San Martín, provincia de El Dorado, distrito de San José de Sisa. Se dedica a la venta de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños, zapatillas y plásticos en general, ollas, etc. Su negocio está ubicado en el Jr. Comercio s/n cdra 2. Sus clientes son las personas de los caseríos y las personas que viven en la misma ciudad.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de ollas, bandejas, zapatillas, botas, mochilas, etc., además comprará ropa para damas como polos, blusas, y pedidos que le hacen sus clientes y así poder satisfacer sus requerimientos.

Mey tiene  52 años de edad, es natural de sisa y tiene 5 hijos, 2 de ellos todavía están a su cargo y quienes son su motor para seguir trabajando. Su meta es ampliar su negocio con abarrotes.
description_translated:
Mrs. Mery Antonieta, member of the Doradinas en Accion (Women of Dorado in Action) Village bank, lives in Dorado in San Jose de Sisa, San Martin, Peru. She sells clothing for men, women, and children, shoes, plastic goods, and pots and pans, etc. Her business is located on the second block of Commerce Street. Her customers are those who live on nearby farms and people who live in the city. With this $975 loan which she will repay in 4 months, she will invest in pots and pans, trays, shoes, boots, backpacks, etc. and will buy clothing for women like t-shirts, blouses, and other special orders that her customers make. Mery is 52 years old and is a native of San Jose de Sisa. She has five children, two of whom still live with her and are her primary motivation to keep working. Her goal is to expand her business by selling groceries.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase pots and pans, shoes, boots, backpacks, t-shirts, blouses, etc.
town_name: San José de Sisa - San Martin

description:
Zacarias L., 39 years old, is single and is a beauty expert who started his salon in Aloran, Misamis Occidental. Among 10 siblings, Zacarias is the 7th child. Coming from a big family, education for all of them was impossible, but despite this, he was not discouraged from pursuing his studies. His interest in cosmetology allowed him to support himself doing home services for his relatives, neighbors, professionals, government employees and even prominent people in their town.  He also has a small space for his parlor to accomodate walk-in customers.

Zacarias fell in love with the programs and services of Paglaum MPC.  The trainings, insurance, loan windows of the cooperative are what he likes most. He remains a member in good standing with his 6 loan. Recently, he applied for a PHP 7,000 loan to acquire additoinal beauty products and he aspires to have a bigger space for his loyal and potential customers.

He has supported his parents up to now, and he dreams of nothing more than to have a happy, healthy life and an adequate income out of his salon business.
loan_use: Purchase of additional stocks for his beauty salon

description: Mrs. Chanthy N. is a villager in Pong Toek Village, Takeo Province. She owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn her living. Her husband, Mr. Mon Neng, helps her on the plantation. They have three children who all attend the local school. Although Chanthy and her husband have two different businesses, they still cannot provide better conditions for their family. In order to improve their standard of living, Chanthy decided to ask for a loan to buy steel to build a house and she hopes to make her household in better condition to live in. Her husband is shown on the right of photo.
loan_use: Chanthy would like to buy steel to build her family's house.

description: Choun Y., 26, and his wife, Sreyneang Yoem, 23,  live in a small village off about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh  They were married in 2007 and have one young son.\r\n\r\nChoun has been a truck driver for one year. He carries cows, vegetables, and other goods from his village to other places for villagers to earn a living. His wife use to work in a garment factory but now she stays at home take care of her little boy. Choun is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase one motorbike for the family.
loan_use: To purchase one motorbike for using in the family.

description:
Sonak S., 28, lives on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She is married and has three children; two sons and one daughter. All of them are still young. Her mother also lives with her family.
 
Sonak has been a silk weaver for ten years, which is a skill she learned from her mother when she was thirteen years old. Her husband is a silk weaver as well. They sell their finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes it to resell in Phnom Penh. Sonak is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase additional silk materials for her weaving business.
loan_use: To purchase silk materials for weaving business.

description: Yanet tiene 19 años, vive en casa de su familia. La venta de ropa es  la labor con la cual Yanet se gana la vida, ella ha incursionado en este negocio desde hace cuatro años atrás, al culminar sus estudios secundarios. Lo que le gusta a Yanet de su trabajo es la dinamisidad que requiere la venta de ropa, debe convencer a la clientela de adquirir sus prendas, y así lograr buenos ingresos, lo cual es muy bueno, ya que le va muy bien con las ventas, pensando en expandir su negocio. Es su primer préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de prendas para lograr mejores ganancias.
description_translated:
Yanet is 19 years old and lives at home with her family. She makes a living selling clothes, which she starting doing four years ago after finishing her junior high school education. What Yanet enjoys about her work is the dynamic personality need to sell clothes, negotiating with customers to purchase her items so she can earn a good income, which she has, since her sales have gone very well. She is planning on expanding her business. This is her first loan with Kiva partner Microfinanzaz Prisma. With the money she is requesting she will purchase a larger quantity of clothing so she can increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase larger quantities of clothing to sell

description: Clara A. sells clothing. She has been in this business for many years. She is 47 years old and married with 4 children. Clara purchases her clothes from Lagos and Onitsha to sell in Benin City. With the festive period fast approaching, she hopes to increase her stock. She needs the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.\r\n\r\n
loan_use: To purchase more clothes to sell

description: Eva tiene 45 años, vive con su esposo y su hijo menor de edad. Ella es agricultora desde hace 30 años, y se dedica por ahora al cultivo de frutas cítricas, actividad que le agrada realizar porque no es muy pesado, sólo se tiene que limpiando los terrenos constantemente y poner trampas para insectos, y así proteger tu producción. Además, los cítricos, en sus temporadas, son muy rentables, ya que los precios de venta suben y esto la favorece y compensan lo difícil de su trabajo, lo cual es la siembra  y la inversión en abonos. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP. Eva tiene pensado invertir en la compra de más naranjales para incrementar su  producción.
description_translated:
Eva is 45 years old, lives with her husband and her young son. She has been a farmer for 30 years, and now cultivates citrus fruits, which she likes because it is not hard work. She only has to clean the grounds regularly and set traps for insects to protect the crop. In addition, citrus, during their season, are very profitable since selling prices go up, which is in her favor and compensates for the difficult part of her work - the investment in seed and fertilizer. This is her first loan with MFP. Eva plans to invest in buying more oranges to increase her production.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To purchase orange plants.

description: Mrs. Em H. is 30 years old and makes a living raising pigs at her home, which she sells to a slaughterer six months after raising them. She lives in Koktlokle Commune in Siem Reap Provice, and has one young child. Her husband, Mr. Vorn Paiy, age 33, is a local farmer. Em needs to ask for a loan to purchase two oxen for her husband to plow a field, and four piglets to raise. (She and her husband are in the picture.)
loan_use: To purchase two oxen, and four piglets

description:
Mrs. Sophal P. is a group leader of four people who live in Slaeng Village in Kandal Province.  

Mrs. Sophal P. is a farmer who has 1-hectar of land to cultivate rice to earn a living.  On this plantation, she now faces a small problem because of her infertile soil.  In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field and make her crop more productive.  Her husband, Mr. Bich Bo, is a palm juice collector who gathers juice to process into palm wine and sugar.  

Mrs. Sophal P. is 48 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the one other is attending the local school.
loan_use: To buy fertilizers to support the field and make her crop more productive.

description:
Vivant dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village Bougoula Hameau, situé à environ 3km de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali, les membres du goupe Benkadi (8 femmes: 7 mariées et 1 célibataire) avec en moyenne 3 enfants et une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans). Ce groupe est une émmanation de l’association Badeya  unie par des liens  de parentés (des soeurs et cousines) et qui a pour activités génératrices de revenus l’achat et  la vente d’huile d’arachide,  de riz, de savons, de noix de Néré, des  produits de beauté, du «Soumbala » et des  condiments alimentaires. Le “Soumbala” est fait à base des noix de Néré après cuisson. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clièntele qui ne cesse d’augmenter, ce groupe décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son 4ème cycle du prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe). Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles (les femmes du groupe) sollicitent ce prêt pour pouvoir acheter, 2 bariques d’huile d’arachide, 13 sacs de riz, 5 sacs de noix de Néré et une grande quantité de condiments (2 sacs d’oignon, 2 sacs d’aubergine, 1 sacs de gombo, 5 paquets d’arome , 5 boîtes de concentré tomate).
 Les villes de Bobo Dioulasso et de Bamako (respectivent au Burkina Faso et au Mali) sont les principales sources d’approvisionnement possibles des femmes de ce groupe. Les marchandises sont achiminées à Sikasso les jours de foire pour être vendues au comptant, à la fois en gros et détail à une clientèle composée très généralement des femmes et surtout des foraines. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au comptant et à crédits soit au marché local, soit à la maison à une clientèle locale feminine.
Elles (les femmes du groupe) envisagent réaliser chacune avec ce 4ème prêt un bénéfice moyen de 50.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir  aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités respectives.
description_translated:
Living in traditional extended families in the village of Bougoula Hameau, located about 3 km from the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali), the members of the group Benkadi (8 women: 7 married and 1 unmarried) average 3 children and 34 years of age. This group came out of the association Badeya and is united by ties of kinship (sisters and cousins). The group members work to earn an income by trading in peanut oil, rice, soap, néré seeds, beauty products, condiments, and "soumbala", which is made from cooked néré seeds.

To satisfy their ever-increasing customer base, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, with which they are on their fourth solidarity loan cycle (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

The women of the group are requesting this loan to buy: 2 barrels of peanut oil, 13 sacks of rice, 5 sacks of néré seeds, and a sizable quantity of condiments (2 sacks of onions, 2 of eggplant, 1 of okra, 5 packets of flavorings, and 5 cans of tomato paste). The cities of Bobo Dioulasso and Bamako (respectively in Burkina Faso and Mali) are the main sources of supplies possible for the women.

The goods are taken to Sikasso on market days to be sold in cash at wholesale and retail levels, both. Their customers are generally composed of women and especially market vendors. Sales are made either at the local marketplace or out of homes, cash or credit accepted.

Using this fourth loan, the women each envision realizing an average profit of 50,000 francs CFA that will be used to pay the loan interest, to provide for the family, and to invest the rest into their respective businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy conditments, peanut oil, rice, soap, néré seeds, beauty products
borrower_names: Lala, Maratou, Alima, Djénèbou, Mariam, Fatoumata, Aby, Assétou
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
Jinna pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Grandes Retos” del distrito y provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Tiene 20 años de edad y junto a su conviviente tienen 1 hijo. Afirma que su principal dificultad ha sido adecuarse a la ciudad de Huaraz porque es natural de la zona selva específicamente de Tocache. Desde hace 3 años vive en al ciudad de Huaraz y ha iniciado un negocio de venta de ropa a pedido y el lugar donde vive con su conviviente, Av. Manco Cápac 159, le sirve de almacén. Empezó este negocio con la venta de joyas y que ahora está invirtiendo en la venta de ropa. Su principal dificultad es que a veces los clientes se olvidan de pagarle o no le pagan a tiempo y ella tiene que buscarlos en sus respectivos domicilios para cobrarles.

Con este préstamo de S/. 500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en la compra de ropa para niños.
 
Jinna piensa crecer en su negocio y agradece el apoyo de su Banco Comunal por colaborar en su crecimiento.
description_translated:
Jinna belongs to the cooperative bank “Mujeres de Grandes Retos” (“Women of Great Challenges”), in the district and province of Huaraz, in the Ancash department. She is 20 years old and has one child with her partner. She affirms that her biggest challenge has been relocating to the city of Huaraz, as she is originally from the jungle area of Tocache. She has lived in Huaraz for three years, and has started a business selling clothing on order. The place where she lives with her partner, on Manco Cápac Avenue, is where she has installed her business. She started out selling jewelry, and is now investing in clothing sales. Her biggest hurdle is that, at times, her customers forget to pay her or don’t pay her on time. This forces her to seek them out in their respective homes in order to collect. With this loan of 500.00 soles, to be repaid in 4 installments, she will invest in the purchase of children’s clothes. Jinna plans to expand her business, and is grateful for the cooperative bank’s support and collaboration towards her growth.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To purchase children's clothing.

description:
Zunilda J., one of the members of the group, came to Esperanza International with almost nothing, just a desire to work hard as a means of changing her life and the life of her children. Zunilda is the mother of three children: two who are young and one who is 35 years old. She said she had a hard time raising the eldest child because money was scarce and she did not have a steady income. With her two young children, she wants to give them the best possible future and put them both in school.

She opened a salon with her first loan and is now trying to increase the size of the business. This has been the first steady income in her life, and finally she is starting to feel like a proper provider for her children. She has never been so happy! She is excited that her children are in school and preparing for a better future. She dreams of sending those children to college, and would also love to travel someday. She knows that she is going to continue growing and become a real success story!

Zunilda is part of a "Bank of Hope," and in conjuction with the other members of her group she will repay this loan over the coming months.
loan_use: To buy products for the salon
borrower_names: Maxima, Zunilda, Ramona, Ramona, Marcelina, Ana, Senoia, Margarita, Ydersa, Florencia, Deyeana, Rosa, Josefina, Porfiria, Ana
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, false, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
El comité “Mujeres Luchadoras” está actualmente en su 1º ciclo se formó gracias a la invitación de otras emprendedoras que ya están trabajando en sus respectivos grupos.
Estas mujeres poseen una actividad comercial diferente cada una, con lo que logran generar ingresos principalmente para el sustento de sus familias.
Estas mujeres y sus respectivas actividades son:
 Andresa C.	Artesanía
Julia Elena M. M.	Despensa
Agustina L. C.	Vta de ensalada de frutas
F. Patricia B. R.	Vta de cosméticos
Herminia B. R.	Vta de artesanias
Maria Carolina B. R.	Vta de artesania
Veronica Liliana G. B.  	Vta de bijouterie
Luz Marina B. R. 	Vta de artesania
Jorgelina M. P.	Vta de comestibles
Analia Roxana B.	Vta de merceria
Nery R. B.	Vta de Chipas
Gladys Martina P. de Zárate	Vta de comestibles
Rosa Maria P. C.	Vta de ropas
Marciana B. de Ramos	Vta de chipas
Maria Valeria U. de Campos	Fabricación y venta de productos de limpieza

Todas ellas retiran un pequeño monto del préstamo total para poder invertirlo en la compra de mercaderías, materias primas y/o materiales necesarios para sus respectivas actividades por ejemplo: compra de frutas, verduras, azúcar, huevos, aceite, carne y especias para aquellas que se dedican a la elaboración y venta de comestibles, así como también gaseosas, jugos, lácteos y agua mineral. Compra de hojas secas de palmas para elaborar artesanías, barro, compra de químicos para la elaboración de productos de limpieza y de detergentes. Compra de ropas para damas y caballeros, calzados, etc.
description_translated:
The "Women Fighters" committee is in it's 1st cycle and was started thanks to invitations by women who were already participating in other groups. Each of these women has a different business from which she earns an income, this income is mainly for the maintenance of the family.

The group comprises the following women: Andresa C., handicrafts Julia Elena M. M., grocery outlet Agustina L. C., fruit salad sales F. Patricia B. R., cosmetic sales Herminia B. R., artwork sales Maria Carolina B. R., handiwork sales Veronica Liliana G. B., jewelry sales Luz Marina B. R., handicraft sales Jorgelina M. P., food sales Analia Roxana B., grocery sales Nery R. B., bread sales Gladys Martina P. de Zárate, food sales Rosa Maria P. C., clothing sales Marciana B. de Ramos, bread sales Maria Valeria U. de Campos, Manufacture and sales of cleaning products.

Each of these women will receive a small part of the loan to invest in merchandise, basic materials and/or materials necessary for her respective business. For those who are in the manufacture and sales of food, it's to buy fruit, vegetables, sugar, eggs, oil, meat and spices, as well as, soda, juices, dairy and mineral water. For those who make and sell crafts and handicrafts, it will be invested in palm leaves and mud. For those who manufacture and sell cleaning products and detergent, it will be invested in chemicals. And for those who sell clothing, it will be to buy clothing for men and women, shoes, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy sugar, meat, dairy, soda, handicrafts, detergent, etc.
borrower_names: Julia, Jorgelina, Andresa, Luz, Maria Valeria, Nery, Flora, Agustina, Analia, Maria Carolina, Rosa, Herminia, Gladys, Marciana, Veronica
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, false, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
This is a group loan for four borrowers. Mrs. Sien P., 30, is the group leader. She makes a living raising pigs as well as growing vegetables such as cabbage, morning glory, and water lilies to sell. She has two children, both of whom are still young and attend school. Her husband, Mr. Mao Sitha, 37, is a motorcycle taxi driver. Sien is applying for a $50 loan to purchase more piglets to raise.

The other three members of the group are: Mrs. Dong P., 50, is a Khmer wine distiller. She seeks a loan of $50 to buy a cart. Mrs. Sam C., 25, is a local construction worker who needs a loan of $50 to buy a piglet to raise. Mrs. Moeut P., 25, raises pigs for a living. She is requesting a $50 loan to purchase zinc to decorate her house.

The borrowers live in the Leangdaiy Commune in Siem Reap Province.
loan_use: to purchase more piglets to raise

description: Assana A. is married and has 4 dependents. She completed her education through junior high school. Since 2000, Assana has sold groceries in Abura. Her husband is a teacher. Assana uses her income to assist her husband in meeting the family's financial needs. Assana will use the loan to increase her stock of groceries for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Assana plans to save toward building a family house with her husband.
loan_use: Assana will use the loan to increase her stock of groceries for sale.

description: Since 2006, Georgina K. has sold building materials in Abakrampa, near Abura. Georgina completed senior high school.  She is married and has 3 dependents. Her husband is a trader.  Georgina is responsible for taking care of her children's financial needs. Her loan will be used to buy more bags of cement and other building materials to sell. She hopes to invest her new profits in her children's education.
loan_use: To buy more bags of cement and other building materials to sell.

description: Doris E. is 46 years old and married with five children. She and her family live in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and she also grinds pepper and other food. \r\n\r\nShe hopes to meet the demands of her customers, so she needs an additional grinding machine. She is requesting a  loan amount of 100,000 to purchase one grinding machine and more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.
loan_use: To purchase one grinding machine

description: Miguelina S. has a small business selling clothing. She is hoping to receive her third loan and continue growing her business. She came to Esperanza International about a year ago hoping for some help out of her situation. She is a single mother who was living in extreme poverty. Before she started her small business she had no form of income and was barely able to feed her child. She felt alone, as if she had no purpose. Once she started her business selling clothes she was able to provide for her child, and for the first time felt like she had a purpose each morning. She has been growing the business since that first loan and has plans for further expansion. She dreams of being able to send her child to a university someday. She now feels like she is going to reach that dream someday, and is ready to work to get there!
loan_use: To buy clothes for resale

description: Candelaria tiene 41 años, vive con su esposo José Luis D. 43 años, el cual es chofer, y sus hijos Jeaneth D. 19, Mariela D. 16 y Karen D. 7 años. Los esposos José Luis y Candelaria son un verdadero equipo, mientras Candelaria cocina los alimentos que ofrecerán, José Luis atienD. a los comensales, haciendo que su pequeño negocio resulte muy atractivo al público, quien ya prefiere la sazón D. Candelaria. El negocio va muy bien y creciendo en clientela, a ellos siempre les ha gustado la cocina y piensan que en este rubro, en el cual ya están 7 años, será su ventana para lograr el éxito. Candelaria se encuentra en el segundo préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma. Con el dinero comprará sillas, algunas mesas y accesorios para mejorar su negocio, además D. ingredientes para preparar sus ricos platos.
description_translated:
Candelaria is 41 years old. She lives with her husband, José Luis, who is 43 and a driver, and her children Jeaneth 19, Mariela 16 and Karen 7 years old. José Luis and Candelaria are a real team. While Candelaria makes the meals that they offer, José Luis attends to the diners, making their small business very attractive to the public who prefer Candelaria´s cooking. The business is going well and growing in clientele. They have always like cooking and think that this line of work, which they have been in for 7 years, will be their window to success. Candelaria is now in her second loan with Microfinanzas Prisma. With this money she will buy chairs, some tables and accesories to improve the business as well as ingredients to prepare her delicious meals.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy some furniture and ingredients to prepare meals.

description: Oghogho O. is a 53-year-old widow with 3 children, who are all university students. She sells foodstuffs and firewood in her community. She is requesting this loan to purchase more firewood and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.
loan_use: To purchase more foodstuffs and firewood to sell

description:
Pedro es chofer interprovincial La Paz – Sataqui; también trabaja como productor de frutas y la esposa es la que comercializa los productos en la ciudad de El Alto. Estas dos actividades constituyen sus principales fuentes de ingreso con que cubre la manutención de su hijo, tiene dos domicilios, en Sataqui (a tres horas y media de la Ciudad de La Paz, y en Senkata en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
El préstamo lo destinará a la reparación y mantenimiento de su herramienta de trabaja (vagoneta) para poder continuar trabajando como chofer.
 
Es primer crédito con Impro y la evaluación realizada califica a Pedro para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado.
description_translated:
Pedro is an interprovincial driver on the La Paz to Sataqui route; he also grows fruit which his wife sells in the city of El Alto. These two activities constitute the main sources of income to help cover the expenses for their son and to maintain their two small homes--one in Sataqui (three and a half hours from the city of La Paz) and another in Senkata in the city of El Alto. This loan will be used to repair and maintain his vehicle to be able to continue his work as a driver. This is Pedro's first loan from Impro and he was evaluated and approved to receive the loan that he requested.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Maintenance and repair of mini-bus for interprovincial transport

description: Elifia tiene 52 años de edad, es separada, en su vida conyugal tuvo 5 hijos, con ella están viviendo ahora, su hija y su nieta. De niña trabajaba en la chacra ayudando a su padre, y cuando tuvo sus hijos se dedicaba a la venta de comida en el mercado, su esposo, es ese tiempo era chofer y le apoyaba en lo posible. Ahora tiene una tienda donde vende perfumes, joyas y objetos personales para mujer, pero también sigue vendiendo, en los días de feria, los sábados, salchipapas y refrescos. Los productos de su tienda las adquiere por catálogo, y le gusta mucho su negocio, cuando llegan sus pedidos sale a repartir de casa en casa, mientras que su hija se queda en el negocio para no perder clientela. Es su 2do préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma. Todo el dinero del préstamo será invertido en la compra de perfumes y tarjetas de navidad por campaña para venderlas en su tienda.
description_translated:
Elifia is 52 years old, separated, and had five children while married. Currently, her daughter and granddaughter are living with her. As a youngster, she helped her father work on the farm. Once she had children, she dedicated herself to food sales in the market. Her husband was a driver at the time, and helped her as much as possible. Currently, she has a store where she sells perfumes, jewelry and personal care items for women. She still, however, sells food and beverages on market days. She acquires her store’s products by catalog and very much enjoys her business. When her orders arrive, she leaves to distribute them door-to-door while her daughter tends to the store so she won’t lose customers. This is her second loan with Microfinanzas Prisma. All the funds requested will be invested into the purchase of perfumes and Christmas cards to sell in her store.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To increase the quantity of products that she sells.

description:
Madame B. Bagnidoma Yawa est née le 1 septembre 1977 à Lomé, la capitale du Togo.  Elle est célibataire est elle n’a pas d’enfant, donc elle peut utiliser les profits de son entreprise pour subvenir à ses charges et celles de sa famille.  Elle a pour activité le vente des pagnes, sacs et chaussures, et elle n’a jamais bénéficié d’un prêt au près de WAGES.  

Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite va lui permettre d’acheter 30 pièces de Phoénix Pagnes, 10 sacs, et 20 chaussures.  Ces types de marchandises sont  très utiles pour les cadeaux pendant les périodes de fête à la fin d’année, donc la demande a actuellement augmentée.  Avec ce nouveau stock, elle peut bien vendre et servir ses clients.
description_translated:
Miss Bagnidoma Yawa B. was born on September 1, 1977 in Lomé, the capital of Togo. She is single and has no children, so she is able to use her earnings to support herself and help her family. Her business is selling "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African cloth used for clothing, turbans, and to strap a baby on your back), handbags, and shoes, and she has never received a loan from WAGES.

This first loan that she is requesting will allow her to buy 30 lengths of Phoénix-brand "pagnes", 10 handbags, and 20 pairs of shoes. This sort of merchandise is very useful as presents during the end-of-year festivities so the demand has grown. With this new stock she will be able to make a lot of sales and fill her customers' needs.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: purchase of "pagnes", handbags, and shoes

description:
Yunusjon M. is a farmer and has been working the land during the past 4 years. There are 7 people in his family, including his wife, 3 children and 2 parents, all of whom are his responsibility. Educated through secondary school, he farms as his principal business activity, something he had formal training in. And it has done the trick for him financially.

\r\n\r\nIn the picture you can see his wife, as Yunusjon himself wasn’t at his home the day of our visit. Due to the upcoming season he needs to grow wheat, onions, and corn. This requires money and he does not have enough. And so he is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) for the term of 8 months to stock up on seeds and fertilizer for a successful harvest. The income will allow him to take better care of his children's health, nourishment, and schooling.
loan_use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

description: Monsieur G. Koffi est né à atchanvé dans la préfecture de Zio. Il est divorcé de sa femme ANGLO Adjo avec laquelle il a eu un (01) enfant, il habite dans le quartier d’Agoè Kitidjan. Il fait le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale et s’approvisionne au marché d’Agoè Atchanvé pour revendre son stock en détail à ses clients d’Agoè Atchanvé.\nMonsieur G. n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de WAGES, il demande un prêt pour pouvoir satisfaire la demande augmentée surtout en ces périodes de fêtes de fin d’année. Avec ce prêt il va acheter 20 sacs de riz GINO, 4 bidons d’huile et 9 paquets de sucre.\n
description_translated:
Mr. Koffi G., born in Atchanvé in Zio Prefecture, is divorced from his wife Adjo ANGLO with whom he had one child. He lives in the Agoè Kitidjan district and does commerce in grocery items. His supplies come from the Agoè Atchanvé marketplace and are sold retail to customers of that area. Having never been the recipient of a WAGES loan, he is requesting a loan to satisfy the increased demand, especially during this year-end holiday season. With this loan, he is going to buy 20 sacks of GINO rice, 4 drums of oil, and 9 packets of sugar. \r\n

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Commerce in food items

description: Madame I. Assana est née en 1967 à parakou au BENIN, un pays voisin du Togo. Elle habite le quartier d’Agoè kitigan à Lomé (Togo), elle a deux (02) enfants et est divorcé de son mari OUSSENI Salifou qui est un chauffeur. I. Assana est une revendeuse de produits d’alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis 1996. Elle est est très dynamique et très motivée dans son commerce pour pouvoir subvenir aux besoins de la famille. Elle a déjà obtenu un crédit de 500000F auprès de WAGES qu’elle a remboursée sans difficultés.\nElle demande un autre crédit pour s’approvisionner avec 15 sacs de riz et 12 bidons d’huile.\n
description_translated:
Ms. Assana I. was born in 1967 in Parakou, Benin, a country neighboring Togo. She lives in the Agoè Kitigan district in Lomé (Togo), has two children, and is divorced from her husband Salifou OUSSENI, a chauffeur. She is a retailer of grocery items and has been in this business since 1996. She is very energetic and highly motived in her work in order to support her family. Having already been a recipient of a 500,000 franc loan from WAGES that she repaid without difficulty, she is asking for another loan to get supplies: 15 sacks of rice and 12 drums of oil. \r\n\r\n

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy food items

description:
This is Kadiatu K., Umu S. and Ya Fola K.. They named their group "Rakom Group." They are local entrepreneurs from the town of Makeni. This is the third time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Most recently, each group memeber received a loan of Le 500,000. That loan was a great help to members of this group. It enabled them to expand their businesses, make more profit, and improve their living conditions. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are again asking for the same amount of Le 500,000 each. They prefer receiving a loan of Le 500,000, because they can manage this amount well.

Kadiatu (right) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-seven years of age. She was born in Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman and they have two children together. Kadiatu sells rice and salt. She has been in the business for over ten years now.

With this new loan, Kadiatu will expand her business. She will buy more bags of salt and a bag of rice. She will be able to get at least twenty bags of salt. She prefers buying more salt, because salt sells faster than rice. A bag of salt will cost her Le 17,000 and a bag of rice, Le 108,000. She sends her husband’s younger brother to buy the goods for her in Freetown.

Kadiatu faces a few challenges in her business. Sometimes sales are a bit difficult, especially when most of the customers travel to makeshift business centers to buy goods, often at slashed prices. Additionally, her husband is not comfortable with her traveling to Freetown by herself to purchase the goods. There is the added expense of sending her brother-in-law instead.  

Kadiatu’s immediate goal is to make a better life for herself. She would like to see her business expand, because this makes her life happy and comfortable.
loan_use: Buy twenty bags of salt and a bag of rice

description:
Mrs. At P. (shown in the middle) was selected to be a leader by group members for a loan from Maxima. In the group, there are three families including hers. The entire group is living on an island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. At P., 65, and her husband, Mr. Sim C., 61, were married in 1965 and have four children: one son and three daughters. All of her children are married, and three live outside the family house, while the youngest daughter and her husband assist At in her silk weaving business. At has been a silk weaver since she was fifteen years old; silk weaving is a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished product to the middleman, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a farmer; he grows vegetables. At is requesting a loan in the amount of $300 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

Mrs. Sam-ang C. (shown in the picture on the right), 38, and her husband, Mr. Mom At, 38, were married in 1989 and have seven children: one son and six daughters. Three of her children are garment factory workers and the other four children attend school. Sam-ang has been a silk weaver since she was thirteen years old; silk weaving is a skill she learned from her mother. She also taught her husband to be a silk weaver. They sell their finished product to the middleman, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh market. Sam-ang is requesting a loan in the amount of $200 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

Sam-oeun C., 22, and her husband, Mr. Ne Van, 23, were married in 2007 and have one little son. Sam-oeun has been a silk weaver since she was sixteen years old; silk weaving is a skill she learned from her mother. She also taught her husband to be a silk weaver. They sell their finished product to the middleman, who them takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Sam-oeun is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase silk materials for weaving.
loan_use: To purchase silk materials for weaving.

description:
Eoeun V., 20, is married and resides with her husband in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. This couple together has two young children.  She grows vegetables on a plot of land behind her house. She usually sells her crops and makes $0.50 of profit a day. Her husband Leam Lun, 25, pictured above, is a construction foreman and makes $4 a day. 

Eoeun V. would like to take out a loan of $500 to purchase more construction tools for her husband. This will allow her husband to access big construction.
loan_use: To purchase construction tools.

description:
Albino nasceu em Gaza, tem 59 anos de idade estudou ate 2ª classe do antigo sistema  é pai de 3 filhos: com idades compriendidas entre os 22 aos 17 anos de idade, as duas mais velhas encontram-se no lar e a mais nova e que vai a escola.
Albino iniciou os seus estudos com 15 anos, após concluir a 2 ªclasse teve que interroper os estudos devido aos maus tratos dos seus professores na escola, pois ele não era assimilado porque os seus progenitores não tinham condições finãnceiras pois estes eram camponesês. Sai de chókwe para Maputo  a procura de emprego.chegado a maputo consegue aranjar um emprego no Hotel Rovuma como servente e trabalhou durante 5 anos, porque o salário  não satisfazia as suas necessidades, abandona o emprego apos  ter  tido uma proposta para trabalhar no Hotel Libombos em Namaacha uma vila na fronteira da swazilandia, trabalhou  durante 2 anos porque não havia um bom ambiente de trabalho pois os colegas alegavam que o cargo que ele ocupava não lhe marecia e assim teve que abandonar o emprego. Mas com o fundo colectado e com ajuda da sua mulher esta que é modista, albino  inicia o seu próprio negócio de alfaiataria e sapataria, uma actividade que aprende com as irmãs missionarias quando ainda frenquentava a escola. Hoje é dono de uma sapataria e alfaiataria denominada “chapo-chapo’’  trabalha das 7h as 18h excepto quartas e sabados porque tem estado no mercado imformal que funciona 2 vezes por semana, tem tido mais rendimento nos sapatos pois solicitam muito os seus servicos principalmente no tempo chuvoso pois os sapatos descolam se com frequência devido a lama argilosa que se faz sentir naquela época. Tem tido um lucro mensal de 5.000.00mt  e consegue poupar 1.500.00mt porque não responsabiliza se por ninguem pois ele e o único na familia que sobriviveu na guerra dos 16 anos.
Este é o segundo empréstimo de albino na hluvuku e primeiro no kiva. O primeiro de 5.000.00mt usou para comprar uma maquina de engrachar sapatos e pede este segundo de 11.000.00mt para comprar uma maquina de costura, pois no inicio do ano tem tido muitas encomendas de uniforme escolar e pretende satisfazer as necessidaes dos clientes na totalidade e render mais ainda.
description_translated:
Albino was born in Gaza. He is 59 years old. He went to school until the 2nd grade under the old system. He is the father of 3 children with ages between 17 and 22. The two oldest are at home, and the youngest is in school. Albino began his studies when he was 15 years old, but after finishing the 2nd grade he had to interrupt school due to the bad treatment from his teachers at his school. Of course he was not very assimilated because his ancestors did not have the financial conditions being that they were country folk. He left Chókwe for Maputo in search of work. Having arrived in Maputo he was able to arrange a job at the Hotel Rovuma as a servant and worked for 5 years. Because he salary did not satisfy his necessities he abandoned his job after having had a proposal to work in the Hotel Libombos in Namaacha, a town on the border of Swaziland. He only worked there 2 years because it was not a very good work environment. His colleagues alleged that he did not deserve the responsibilities he was given and he had to leave. But with the funds collected and with the help of his mother who is a dressmaker, Albino started his own tailor and shoe shop, an activity that he learned from the sister missionaries when he was still attending school. Today he is the owner of a shoe store and tailor called "Chapo-Chapo". He works from 7:00am until 6:00pm except on Wednesdays and Saturdays because he goes to the informal market 2 times per week. He makes more income from the shoes. Of course many people need his services during the rainy season because the shoes become unglued frequently due to the muddy clay that made sense during that time. He has had a monthly income of 5,000MT and is able to save 1,500MT because he is not responsible for anyone else. He is the only one in his family that survived the 16 year war. This is Albino's second loan with Hluvuku and his first with Kiva. The first loan of 5,000MT was used to purchase a machine to clean shoes, and he is asking for this second loan of 11,000MT to purchase a sewing machine because since the beginning of the year he has had many orders for school uniforms, and he intends to satisfy the necessities of his customers in full and bring in more money as well.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase sewing machine

description:
La asociación “Nueva Vida” pertenece al centro focal Panamericana, ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto,  trabaja junto a Pro-Mujer hace más siete años.
Casadas en su mayoría tienen un promedio de cinco hijos cada una, en algunos casos sus parejas las abandonaron teniendo que hacerse cargo ellas solas de sus familias, es por ello que se vieron en la necesidad de buscar actividades propias que les permita generar recursos para el bien de sus familias.
La asociación “Nueva Vida” tiene diversas actividades, Soledad por ejemplo se dedica  a la filmación de eventos sociales, Ross tiene una tienda de lubricantes, otras de ellas realizan variedad de masitas (pastelitos y galletas) en horno industrial, y otras se dedican al tejido de mantas en macrame. Todas las socias del grupo quieren mejorar sus negocios, para esto solicitan mayor capital para comprar insumos y  materia prima, dependiendo del caso. Están seguras que sus ventas aumentaran y podrán obtener ingresos suficientes para solventar a sus familias.
description_translated:
The Nueva Vida ["New Life"] association is part of the Panamericana group in the Bolivian city of El Alto. The association has worked with Pro-Mujer for seven years. Mostly married with an average of five children each, some of the members have been abandoned by their partners andhad to take sole charge of their families. That's what led them to seek out ways to make enough money to support their families.

Nueva Vida members have diverse businesses. Soledad, for example, videotapes social events; Ross has a store selling lubricants; some make different kinds of "masitas" (a local snack); and others earn livings making macrame products. All of the members want to improve their businesses so they're applying for additional funds to buy products for resale or supplies, as the case may be. They are confident that their sales will increase and they'll be able to earn large enough incomes to support their families.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy products for resale or supplies, as appropriate.
borrower_names: PAMELA, EXALTA, AURORA, OFELIA, MARIBEL, ROSE, ANA, ROSSE MARY, TERESA, ALICIA, SOLEDAD, ESTEHER, LIDIA, ELIZABETH, SOFIA, JUANA, BEATRIZ, JESUSA, WILMA
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, false, false, false, true, true, true

description: B. Latofat is a happy mother of 5 children. She is 48 years old and married. Latofat is a teacher. Her salary is very little so she has also been running her own grocery business. For four years she has been selling foodstuff like sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks, alcoholic drinks and many others in her grocery store. Latofat’s wish is to increase her business, offering a variety of foodstuff to customers who pass through the market. She works with one aim in mind, to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved children who are all the apple of her eye and the reason for her daily efforts. With this opportunity, with the immense love she feels as a mother and with her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and is requesting a loan of 2500 Somoni (750 USD) in order to increase the range of her goods. She promises to repay the loan within 12 months. You can be an important link in the growth of this business by supporting Latofat.
loan_use: Purchasing of foodstuff in order to increase the range of goods

description: Beatrice T. is 42 years old and a mother with three kids. Two of them are in school now and the youngest has not started school. She has been selling grocery products for five years on a table in her neighborhood, to support her family. She says business is doing well, and she therefore wants to use the loan to buy more products to increase her inventory. Beatrice believes the loan would help her increase her savings towards the welfare of her two children who are in school now. She is a member of the group called Boldness. Members in the group agree in unison to guarantee for each other to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting. Her child is also in the photo.
loan_use: To buy more grocery products like tins of fish and tomatoes, cocoa products, skimmed milk, vegetable oil, etc. to sell

description: Miriam tiene 20 años, es conviviente, tiene dos hijos, por el momento está viviendo en la casa de su madre. Luego de terminar el colegio tenía la idea de estudiar una carrera técnica, por lo que había empezado a prepararse para su ingreso a un instituto, pero quedó embarazada, y estos planes se truncaron, tuvo que empezar a trabajar, y lo hizo mediante la venta ambulante de gelatinas en el campo deportivo frente a su casa, las ganancias le servían para cubrir los gastos de sus chequeos médicos, ahora ya tiene dos hijos y no sólo vende gelatina, sino que también prepara y vende refrescos de fruta, en adelante quiere comprar una parrilla para vender anticuchos por las noches, ya que la casa de su madre está en un lugar muy transitado. La venta de las gelatinas le está siendo rentable, sobre todo cuando hace calor. Su pareja trabaja con un motocarro realizando transporte de pasajeros. Es su 5to préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma, además paga sus cuotas en las fechas indicadas. Con el dinero solicitado, comprará la parrilla que necesita, además de utensilios para la preparación de anticuchos (brochetas).
description_translated:
Miriam is 20 years old, lives with her partner and has two children. Currently she is living in her mother´s house. After she finished high school she thought about studying for a technical degree and had started preparing for her entrance into an institute, but she became pregnant and those plans were cut short. She had to start working and did so by selling gelatin desserts at a playing field in front of her house. The earnings from this helped to cover the costs of her medical checkups. Now that she has two children, not only does she sell gelatin but she also prepares and sells fruit drinks. In the future she wants to buy a grill to sell anticuchos (a dish with small pieces of grilled skewered meat) at night since her mother´s house is in a very high-traffic area. The sale of gelatin has been profitable, most of all when the weather is hot. Her partner works with a 3 wheeled motor vehicle to transport passengers. This is her 5th loan with Microfinanzas Prismas and she makes her monthly payments on time. With the money she requests, she will buy the grill she needs as well as utensils to prepare the anticuchos.\r\n

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy a grill and utensils for cooking

description:
B. Tutiniso has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2003. She has proven herself a serious and reliable client; she has not any problems with previous loan repayments.

\r\n\r\nMrs. B. is engaged in the commercial service and trade. She has sold eggs in the Panjshanbe bazaar for the last 8 years. She is very polite and kind by nature, so she has a lot of repeat customers. Mrs. B. applies to KIVA for business development loan of 2300 STJ for 6 months to increase her turnover capital.
loan_use: Increase her turnover capital

description:
Bernardo P. is happily married and blessed with two intelligent children. He is 41 years old and is engaged in farming while his wife is making soft brooms for sale in their community. His earnings support the daily needs of his family and he wants to ensure that he can provide a good future for them. However, he is experiencing difficulty with the cost of farm materials such as fertilizer, which have become expensive lately.

To solve this dilemma, Bernardo thinks of converting into organic farming - the traditional way of farming which is a lot cheaper than commercial farming. Such a shift to a healthier method of farming will require additional capital of P15,000 (USD$325), that is why he wants to borrow money from a local institution.

Bernardo always dreams for the health and unity of his family. He also wants his children - Mary Ann, 16, and Mary Jane, 15 - to finish college education because he knows how important it is for his children to have a better future. At the moment, he is so proud of his children who are able to help them in making soft brooms by simply going around the community to collect the materials they need.
loan_use: Additional capital to convert to organic farming methods.

description:
Soft-spoken Hanifa, 38, is married with 6 children ages 2 to 18. She also cares for three cousins and her sister. Hanifa sells smoked fish caught in Lake Victoria. Local favorites are tilapia and Nile perch. Her customers are families and restaurants in her local village. Hard-working Hanifa goes the fish market in Lugazi, an hour and a half away on a public bus, every Monday, Wednesday and Friday to buy fresh fish to sell in local markets. She smokes the fish because she cannot afford a cold storage unit. Her business is robust: each week, she buys 1,000,000 Ush worth of fish in Lugazi and makes a weekly profit of over 200,000 Ush. Still, she can only save trace amounts of her income as very little is left after paying school fees and living expenses.  

Hanifa hopes to buy her own fishing nets and employ local boys to fish exclusively for her. This would significantly improve her profits. Further, if she could afford a refrigerator, she could sell higher-margin fresh fish as well as sell fish on a wholesale basis to more restaurants and retailers.Hanifa’s husband is a lorry driver. They would like to afford to put their children in boarding school, as day schools in their village are not good and they hope their children can complete university-level education. She has been a Pearl borrower for for over 10 years, and this is Hanifa’s 38th cycle.

Other members of her group have similar aspirations.
loan_use: Buying fresh fish at the wholseale market for resale
borrower_names: Peter, Prossy, Eva, Hanifa, Zubairi, Saudah, Betty, Halima, Florence, Justine
borrower_genders: male, female, female, female, male, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description: I Ketut Sada memiliki lahan seluas 1 hektar. Seluruh lahan yang dimilikinya ditanami dengan padi, karena pengairan yang cukup memadai sepanjang tahun. Selama 1 tahun, tanaman padi bisa dipanen sebanyak 3 kali. Sebelumnya, I Ketut Sada menanam padi dengan bibit jenis lokal karena harganya yang lebih murah. Namun, keuntungan yang didapatnya tidak maksimal, karena bibit jenis lokal mudah terserang penyakit. Dalam satu kali panen ( 4 bulan ), ia hanya mendapat keuntungan sebesar Rp. 500.000.- setelah dikurangi semua biaya untuk pengolahan tanah dan perawatan tanaman. Hal itu dirasakan belum mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya, apalagi dengan kondisi ekonomi saat ini. Karena ingin meningkatkan taraf hidupnya dan keluarganya, I Ketut Sada mengajukan pinjaman ke Yayasan Dinari sebesar Rp. 6.000.000.- Pinjaman tersebut dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit padi kwalitas unggul sebesar Rp. 3.000.000.-, biaya pengolahan tanah dengan menyewa pekerja sebesar Rp. 1.000.000.- dan membeli pupuk serta anti hama sebesar Rp. 2.000.000.- I Ketut Sada sudah belajar dengan petani yang sudah lebih dulu menggunakan bibit kwalitas unggul sehingga ia tidak ragu untuk mendapat pinjaman, karena sesuai dengan kenyataan, bibit padi kwalitas unggul mampu menghasilkan hingga 3 kali lipat dibanding dengan bibit jenis lokal. Satu kali panen, bibit unggul bisa mendapatkan keuntungan sebesar Rp. 1.500.000.- hingga Rp. 2.000.000.- Dengan terus didampingi oleh staf Dinari dan petani padi yang telah sukses dengan bibit padi kwalitas unggul, I Ketut Sada optimis yakin usahanya akan sukses.
description_translated:
I Ketut Sada owns a land of 1 hectare (around 2.5 acres). Due to his land does not have a proper irrigation system, he uses his whole land for paddy farming. He can harvests his paddy farming 3 times a year. He used local paddy seeds in the past because they were cheaper. However he was not able to get a good result out of it. In one harvest season (around 4 month period) he can only get a profit of IDR 500 thousand (around USD 45). That was certainly not enough to make a living especially in this current economic condition.

He applied for a loan from Dinari foundation for an amount of IDR 6 million (around USD 550). He used IDR 3 million (USD 275) to buy high quality paddy seeds, another IDR 1 million (USD 92) was spent for hiring some men to clear and work the land, and IDR 2 million (USD 183) to buy fertilizer and pesticide.

I Ketut Sada has learned from senior farmers in farming with high quality seeds, hence he is confidence he can succeed this time. He can triple his revenue using this quality seeds, so instead of having a profit of UD 45 per harvest seasons, he can earn up to USD 135 - USD 180/ harvest season. I Ketut Sada is also going to be guided by Dinari Foundation's field instructor, so he is confident that he will succeed this time around.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: High quality paddy seeds, fertilizer and pesticide

description:
I Ketut Sarna, tinggal disebuah desa di Bali barat yang hampir semua penduduknya berprofesi sebagai petani. Karena tinggal didaerah yang terpencil, hampir semua petani didaerahnya bercocok tanam dengan cara yang sangat tradisional. Hal itu berakibat kepada hasil yang tidak maksimal dan bahkan seringkali kekurangan untuk mencukupi kebutuhan keluarga. I Ketut Sarna mendapat informasi dari temannya yang juga seorang petani dari lain desa. Petani tersebut sudah berhasil karena bercocok tanam dengan cara modern dan menggunakan bibit padi jenis unggul.
I Ketut Sarna ingin menjadi pelopor untuk mengadakan perubahan didesanya. Ia ingin menanami sawahnya dengan bibit padi kwalitas unggul untuk hasil yang maksimal. Untuk mewujudkan hal itu, I Ketut Sarna mengajukan pinjaman ke Yayasan Dinari dan mohon pembinaan untuk proses menanamnya. Dengan adanya pendampingan usaha dari Dinari dan bantuan dari temannya yang telah sukses, I Ketut Sarna optimis usahanya akan berhasil dan akan menjadi contoh didesanya.
description_translated:
I Ketut Sarna lives in a village in the west of Bali. Almost all men in that village are farmers. They are using traditional ways in farming because their village is located in a remote area. As a result they cannot get the best result from their farming activities.

I Ketut Sarna got an information from his friend who live in another village. His friend is a successful farmer because he already uses modern farming methods and also he uses high quality paddy seeds. I Ketut Sarna wants to be pioneer in the modern farming method in his village. He also wants to pioneering the usage of high quality paddy seeds.

Therefore he applied for a loan of IDR 6 million (around USD 550) from Dinari foundation. He also requested to be guided by Dinari Foundation's farming specialist so he can succeed in this. He is hoping that he can succeed in this so he can inspire his fellow village men.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: High quality paddy seeds, fertilizer, pesticide

description: Kiko, joven trabajador de 24 años de edad, vive  en la casa de su madre en compañía de su hermano menor. Los padres de Kiko fueron agricultores, sembraban papa en grandes cantidades, pero hubo un mal tiempo donde ellos se quedaron sin capital, desde entonces, hace 5 años Kiko trabaja en las chacras de sus vecinos, le pagaban diario 15 soles, incluido almuerzo.  Y hace como 2 años que empezó a sembrar su propia chacra, donde tiene cultivado dos hectáreas de papa, y otro poco de arvejas, cuando cosecha los lleva al mercados y eso le causa mucha satisfacción. Tiene anhelos de progresar sembrando en grandes cantidades, debido al buen precio que se está cotizando actualmente en el mercado;  pero a la vez le es imposible por la falta dinero, ya que los fertilizantes son muy costosos. Esta es la séptima vez que viene trabajando Kiko con un préstamo de MFP, pagando sus cuotas en las fechas fijadas, sin mora alguna. El dinero que le facilitarán, es para la compra del fertilizante llamado “Alimuful” que sirve para el desarrollo de la papa.\n
description_translated:
Kiko, a young worker of 24 years old, lives in the house of his mother and in the company of his younger brother. Kiko\'s parents were farmers. They grew potatoes in large quantities, but had a bad season where they were left without money. After that, starting five years ago Kiko worked in the farms of his neighbors. They paid him 15 Soles daily, including lunch. And about 2 years ago he began to farm his own plot of land, where he is cultivating two hectares of potatoes and another little bit of peas. When he harvests, he takes them to the markets and this gives him much satisfaction. He longs to continue growing large quantities, owing to the good prices that he is receiving nowadays in the market; but at the same time it is impossible because of a lack of money, since the fertilizers are very costly. This is the seventh time that Kiko comes working with a loan from MFP (Microfinanzas PRISMA, a Kiva field partner), making his payments on the set dates without a single late payment. The money that they will give him is to buy the fertilizer called "Alimuful", which helps in the growth of the potatoes.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Tatman Montgomery, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy fertilizers for his crops

description:
Victoriano P. resides in Barangay Rizal in Quirino, Isabela. He is married to Adelaida and they are blessed with seven children. Most of the children are high school graduates. Some of the children were able to reach college, but never graduated because they didn't haven enough money to complete their studies.

Victoriano makes a living planting vegetables and rice. In addition to farming vegetables and rice, he also maintains mango plants, which are around their house. This provides extra income for their family, especially during summer.

Since Victoriano lacks financial resources, he is hoping to borrow PHP 18,000.00 so he can purchase additional farm inputs to cultivate his farm and plant rice. Some of his loan will be used to pay for laborers who will help him plant the crops. The loan will also help to pay for food and snacks to sustain him and his laborers during their work.

Victoriano wants to sustain his farming business and hopefully grow it so he eventually has a hectare of farmland to provide for the future of his family.
loan_use: Working Capital

description:
Ban P., 40, is married and lives with three of her children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a pig breeder on a plot of farm behind her house. On average, she makes around $1 a day. Her husband Sreng Sreang, 39, works growing rice with two of his children and makes $3 a day. He has been farming for about 10 years. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have created a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Sreng Sreang included.

Ban P. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a grinding mill. This machine will service the people in the village for extra profit.
loan_use: To purchase a grinding mill

description:
Elvira P. is a 51-year-old mother of two children from Fatima, General Santos City. Her husband, a retailer of rice, has been very supportive of her in her charcoal-retail business. Together, they work hard to address all their family needs.She is a loving wife and continuously dreams of a good future for her family.

She is requesting a loan to purchase additional stocks of charcoal to sell. She started her business for additional income for her family and to support her children.

"As a mother, I always seek the best things for my kids”, she said.
loan_use: To purchase more charcoal to sell.

description: Chhum S. is married and lives with her husband and young child in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She is a midwife who earns $2 a day, while her husband is a village chief who also earns $2 a day.  She would like a loan of $1000 to reinvest with her sister to open a food shop at Phnom Penh. She believes that a food shop can increase their income and raise the standard of living for the whole family.\r\n
loan_use: To open a food shop.

description: Ce habitant de la banlieue de Néma 2, sud de Ziguinchor, vend du poisson. Marié et pére de 3 enfants, il arrive à subvenir aux besoins familiaux avec cette activité. Il sollicite un prêt pour augmenter ses bénéfices en achetant beaucoup de poissons qu'il va revendre.
description_translated:
This resident of the Néma 2 suburb, south of Ziguinchor, sells fish. He is married and the father of 3 children. With this activity, he manages to provide for the family's needs. He is requesting a loan to increase his profit by buying a lot of fish that he will resell.\r\n\r\n

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Fish selling

description: Bridget O. is 45 years old and married with five children. She makes a living selling drinks to both wholesale and retail customers. She buys the drinks from distributor, and has applied for a loan to buy more items to sell. She says thank you to everyone who makes this loan possible.\r\n\r\n
loan_use: To buy more drinks to sell

description: Sofía tiene 35 años, es casada, vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos. Hace 3 años inició su actividad de bordados, motivada por los diseños que hay en las diversas elaboraciones, los adornos le llamaron mucho su atención y desde  entonces empezó a aprender lo básico para iniciar, luego fue mejorando su técnica, poco a poco, hasta que ahora logró que sus adornos navideños y sus diversos  trabajos sean muy solicitados por las personas. Sofía tiene en su máquina de coser, su mejor ayudante, y le agrada estar horas trabajando  en la elaboración de  diversos bordados, ya que por temporadas la demanda crece y las ganancias se triplican, hay que aprovechar, sobre todo en fiestas navideñas, sin embargo, lo difícil es hacer los moldes de diseños para todos los tamaños siendo éste, un proceso  dificultoso. Este es su primer crédito con MFP. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de materia prima para su trabajo, así como hilos especiales, lentejuelas y telas.
description_translated:
Sofia, 35, lives with her husband and three children. Three years ago, she started an embroidery business, inspired by designs that she'd seen. The designs captured her imagination and she immediately began learning the basics of embroidery, slowly improving her technique to the point where the embroidery she makes at Christmas is much sought after. Sofia's sewing machine is her best helper and she's happy to spend hours working away at her embroidery. Demand for Sofia's products grows this time of year and her earnings triple, so she has to make the most of the season, above all for Christmas fairs. One hurdle she faces is making designs for all possible sizes, a difficult process. This is Sofia's first MFP loan. With the loan, she will buy wholesale supplies of basic materials such as threads, sequins and cloth.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy materials for embroidery business.

description:
Vida A. is 46 years old. She is divorced with four children. As the mother, part of the family responsibility for the kids rests on her shoulders. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, bottled water, boxes of body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, and the like. 

She wants to use the loan to buy more inventory. She deems it a big opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by customers. She hopes to improve sales to enable her to save more for the children’s education. 

Vida belongs to the community group called Vibrant Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral for the loan and support one another in repaying the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting. 

She would be grateful for the assistance.
loan_use: To buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc.

description: Mom S. is a 29-year-old resident of the Pursat Province. He makes breads by himself in his home and sells them to his customers by going from market to market in his local area. He can earn an income of approximately $3 each day. Mom is married to Mrs.Tin Chan, 29, who is the mother of four children, all of whom are still young and attend school. She sells vegetables to help supplement the family income. To earn additional income, Mom has applied for a loan to purchase a motorcycle to begin a motor-taxi service.
loan_use: To purchase a motorcycle to begin a motor-taxi service

description:
Chị Phạm Thị Bích năm nay 55 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2003. Hiện tại chị đang kinh doanh thực phẩm khô tại chợ  thị xã Phúc Yên. Hàng tháng  ngoài thu nhập từ kinh doanh  buôn bán gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu từ việc cho công nhân  thuê phòng trọ. Với mức thu nhập 6.000.000đ/ tháng việc hoàn trả vốn của gia đình chị Bích rất thuận lợi.
