After working for a month, she sells everything she's made through her sister, who takes the embroideries to people who request them. There tends to be more demand during the region's various festivals. Susan has noticed that over time her household earnings have grown thanks to her embroidery work. Because of that, she'd like to continue this work in the future and produce greater quantities. This is her first loan with MFP, and she is committed to being responsible with her payments. She will use the requested loan for her embroidery, buying fabric and paying a portion of the cost of securing a market stall.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase materials for her embroidery

description: Norma tiene 31 años, vive en la casa que le dejaron sus padres, es muy trabajadora y tiene muchas ganas de superarse. Es dueña del restaurante más concurrido de su barrio, siempre está muy alegre y recibe con una sonrisa a sus clientes diarios, disfruta de atenderlos y brindarles la mejor atención posible, ya que sabe que de ellos depende el éxito de su negocio. Norma lleva 6 años en esta actividad y espera posteriormente poder abrir una sucursal de su restaurante en una zona más comercial, donde pueda vender su comida a muchas más personas y así mejorar sus ingresos económicos, ya que actualmente tiene muchos clientes que vienen desde muy lejos a probar su deliciosa sazón. Lo complicado de este negocio es preparar diariamente comida para casi doscientas personas. Es el quinto préstamo de Norma con MFP, y se siente en la capacidad de pagarlo a tiempo, ya que confía en su negocio y en su banco comunal, al cual se siente muy contenta de pertenecer. Este dinero le ayudará a incrementar su capital de trabajo, planea invertir todo el crédito en comprar las cosas que necesita para implementar más adelante un nuevo restaurante.
description_translated:
Norma is 31 years old and lives in the house her parents left her. She's a hard worker and is ready to excel in her life.

She is the owner of the most frequented restaurant in the neighborhood. She's always happy and greets her daily clientele with a smile; she enjoys serving them and giving them the best attention possible, as she knows the success of her business depends on them.

Norma has had this business for 6 years and in the future, hopes to open a locale in a more commercial area because already, many of her customers come from far away to try her delicious flavours. This would allow her to serve many more customers and, inevitably, increase her income. The difficult part of her job is to prepare meals for approximately 200 people a day.

This is Norma's 5th loan with MFP and she feels capable of paying it back on time because she trusts in her business and in the Communal Bank, of which she is happy being an associate.

This loan will help Norma increase her working capital. She plans on investing her gains in all the things she needs to implement a new restaurant in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy furniture and utensils in order to open her next restaurant.

description: Feliciano cuenta 64 años de edad, es casado hace 30 años y tiene 8 hijos, de los cuales vive con tres de ellos. Sus actividades agrícolas se inician a las 5.00am y a eso de las 8.00am regresa a desayunar, al regresar a su chacra lleva a sus animales, sujeta a los toros y al burro en zonas de mucho pasto, para trabajar con tranquilidad, y su esposa lo alcanza con el almuerzo. Una vez terminado de comer, ambos trabajan con alegría, porque gracias a sus cultivos se han sustentado durante los años de su matrimonio. Feliciano siembra espinacas, coliflor, lechugas, etc, y cada fin de semana cosecha, su esposa es la encargada de llevar a las ferias dominicales de Tarma a vender. Esta dinámica de trabajo les ha permitido educar a sus hijos, que ahora trabajan en otras ciudades, pero aun su responsabilidad de padre es con sus hijos menores, por ello ahora se dirige a la ciudad para realizar las compras de sus uniformes escolares. En este 8vo préstamo del banco comunal llamado “Vamos al futuro huaracaino”, Feliciano acaba de ingresar como un cliente nuevo, por lo que se compromete a pagar puntualmente sus cuotas a MFP, del cual está muy agradecido por tal oportunidad brindada. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de abonos de corral para sus siembras de hortalizas que todo este tiempo han le han permitido vivir cómodamente.
description_translated:
Feliciano is 64 years old, has been married for 30 years, and has 8 children, of which 3 live with him. His agricultural activities begin at 5:00 am. He goes home at 8:00 am to eat, then returns to his fields with his animals, and ties his bulls and the donkey in places with a lot of grass, so he can work peacefully. His wife later takes his lunch to him. Once he finishes eating, he and his wife work together happily, because their crops have sustained them over many years of marriage. Feliciano grows spinach, cauliflower, lettuce, etc. Each weekend he harvests, and his wife takes the crops to the Sunday markets in Tarma to sell them. This work dynamic has allowed them to educate their children who now work in other cities, but they still have parental responsibilities to their younger children, so they go to the city to buy their school uniforms.

In this 8th loan to the communal bank called "Onward to the Huaracayan Future", Feliciano has just become a new member, and he promises to make his payments on time to MFP, to which he is very thankful for the opportunity they have given him. The money he requests is for fertilizer for his fields to nourish his seeds, which have allowed him to live a comfortable life.

Translated from Spanish by Shaun Haines, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase of fertilizer for his farm

description: Nike sells clothing materials and fabrics. She needs the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more clothing materials to sell. Nike is 40 years old and married with three children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To purchase more clothing materials to sell.\t

description: Omolola is 42 years old and married with four children. She is a LAPO client. She sells fabrics and has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more fabrics to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To purchase more fabrics to sell

description: Foluke sells provisions like noodles, milk, detergent, bathing soap, etc. She hopes to expand this business. Foluke is 40 years old and married with a child. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their financial support.
loan_use: To purchase more provisions to sell.

description: Jessica sells women's shoes and slippers and also rents out DVDs. Jessica is 32 years old and married with 4 children. She requests a $700 loan to purchase more women's shoes and slippers to sell.  She says thanks to everyone that made this loan possible.\r\n
loan_use: To purchase more women's shoes and slippers to sell

description: Christiana sells cosmetics. She is a LAPO client. She is 32 years old and married with no children. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible
loan_use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

description: Nazario está a punto de cumplir 30 años, es soltero, aun vive en la casa de su madre en compañía de su hermana. Todos sus hermanos se fueron a Lima en busca de un mejor porvenir, y le han propuesto irse con ellos, pero él prefiere apostar por el arte de labrar la tierra, como él llama a la agricultura, ya que le gusta mucho esta actividad. Años atrás solo sembraba en chacras temporales (regadas por la lluvia), y sus cosechas eran en los meses abril a mayo. Pero quiso cambiar esa realidad alquilando chacras de regadío y cambiado todas las semillas de acuerdo al tipo de tierra. Han pasado más de tres años y por fin está viendo los frutos de su esfuerzo. Ahora sus cosechas son  cada dos o tres veces por año, y cree haber aprendido las técnicas para convertirse en un gran agricultor. Sus metas próximas son de sembrar en la costa, debido a que cuenta con una buena cantidad de semillas especiales para ese clima, así incrementará su producción, con ello sus ganancias y convertirá su labor en una actividad muy rentable. Hace un año Nazario fue el presidente de su banco comunal, y cumplió muy bien con sus funciones, este es su 8vo préstamo con MFP, en todo este tiempo demostró responsabilidad en sus pagos. El dinero que está solicitando es para la compra de fertilizantes químicos, para sus nuevas siembras en chacras costeñas.
description_translated:
Nazario is about to turn 30, he is single, and still lives in his mother's house along with his sister. His other siblings all left for Lima to look for a better future, and have proposed that he go with them, but he prefers to stay and work the land, as he refers to agriculture, since he really likes this activity. Many years ago he only farmed small plots of land (watered by the rain), and his harvests were in the months of April and May. But he wanted a change from renting land and changed all the seeds according to the type of land. More than three years have passed and he is finally seeing the fruit of his labor. Now his crops are harvested two or three times a year, and he believes he has learned the techniques to become a great farmer. His upcoming goals are to farm on the coast, since he has a large quantity of seeds especially for that climate. In this way he will increase his production which will increase his earnings and make his work a very profitable activity. Last year Nazario was the president of his community bank, and he completed all his tasks very well. This is his eighth loan with MFP and in all this time he has shown responsibility in his payments. The money he is asking for is for buying chemical fertilizers for planting his new coastal crops. \r\n

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To purchase fertilizers

description:
La socia María Antonieta; tiene 42 años de edad, ella es conviviente, y tiene 3 hijos de (21, 18, 14) años de edad, ella aún los apoya con sus estudios, ella vive en la Urb. pueblo libre en aracopata.

Nuestra socia, alterna sus actividades domésticas con la confección de todo tipo de prendas, ella es costurera de profesión; La sra. María Antonieta, necesita el préstamo para comprar diferentes telas y otra parte la destinará al mejoramiento de su casa, ella aún educa a sus hijos, el menor aún está en el colegio y los otros hijos están estudiando en el nivel superior, con la realización de sus obras ella podrá seguir educando a su hijos.

La socia valora y agradece el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago total del préstamo en el plazo programado.
description_translated:
The client Ms. Maria Antonieta is 42 years old and lives in the housing development Pueblo Libre in Aracopata. She lives with her common-law husband and they have three children, 21, 18 and 14 years old. She supports them with their schooling. The youngest attends regular school and the older ones post-secondary education.

Ms. Maria Antonieta is a seamstress and divides her time between housework and the making of all kinds of garments. She needs the loan to buy different textiles and to improve her home. She would be able to continue supporting her children’s education through her work.

The client values and appreciates the support given to her through this loan, and she is committed to repay the total within the scheduled time.

Translated from Spanish by Elsa Mejia Connelly, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy textiles and improve her house

description:
Rose A., 42, is a married mother of four children, two males and two females. According to her, two of her children are in the tertiary level – university and the training college while the rest are in junior high and the basic school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Mampong, in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Rose works very hard to support her husband financially to provide for the family. She runs a provisions store in her community. She also sells vegetables on a table top in front of her store. Rose has been in this business for eight years. She wants a loan to procure more goods. Rose is hopeful to support all her children to the tertiary level of education.
loan_use: Procure provision.

description:
Cirila es socia del Banco Comunal Florecer.
Cirila es viuda, tiene 62 años y 5 hijos, Cirila tiene un recreo restaurante en el mirador de la ciudad de Ayacucho llamado LA CHOZA DEL MIRADOR, en donde vende comidas típicas y bebidas, para lo cual cuenta con la ayuda de 3 personas.
Cirila necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de mesas y sillas.
Los sueños de Cirila son tener un negocio mas tranquilo y descansar.
description_translated:
Cirila is a member of the “Florecer” (“To Flower”) cooperative bank. Cirila, 62 years old, is a widow and has 5 children. Cirila has a recreational restaurant at a viewpoint in the city of Ayacucho called “LA CHOZA DEL MIRADOR”. Here, she sells traditional foods and beverages with the help of 3 people. Cirila needs a loan of 1,000 soles, funds that she will invest into the purchase of tables and chairs. Cirila’s dreams are to have a steady business and to be able to rest some.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: For the purchase of tables and chairs.

description: Javier tiene 33 años de edad, es soltero, vive en la casa de sus padres. En los años de su niñez, conjuntamente con su padre lideraba la labor agrícola en sus tierras, mientras que sus hermanos eran fieles colaboradores, ahora que ellos formaron sus propias familias, su dinámica de trabajo ha mermado por la falta de apoyo; pero igual sigue esforzándose al lado de su padre. En la temporada anterior ha sembrado alverjas y su cosecha le ha sido muy gratificante, con las ganancias pudo comprar un becerrito para que luego de dos o tres años le supla en el arado a su toro actual. Javier está muy contento y no piensa dejar sus cultivos, ya que la mayoría de las veces le ha resultado ser rentable, lo que le ha permitido vivir tranquilamente. Este es su 8vo préstamo con MFP, en todo este tiempo ha demostrado ser puntual en sus pagos. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de fertilizantes, para abonar sus chacras de papa.
description_translated:
Javier is 33 years old, single, and lives in his parents' house. In the years of his childhood, he helped his father lead the agricultural work on their land, while his brothers were loyal employees. Now that they have their own families, his work dynamic has weakened for lack of support, but he continues working alongside his father. In the previous season, he planted peas and his harvest was very rewarding--with his earnings, he was able to buy a calf that can pull his bull plow after two or three years. Javier is very happy and has no plans to quit agriculture, since the majority of the time it has been very profitable and has allowed him to live a quiet life. This is his eighth loan with MFP, and he has always demonstrated punctuality in his payments. This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers for his potato fields.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase fertilizers

description:
Jocelyn M. has a small farm. She is 42 years old and has 6 children. She lives in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato, a town of 36,228 people in 7,082 households. The most common type of livelihood there is farming, and some raise hogs and livestock. Her family has been engaged in farming for almost 20 years already. 

She is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies like 4 sacks of rice seeds, 2 bags of Urea fertilizers, and pesticides. The loan will truly help Jocelyn achieve a better yield to support her family well.

CEVI helps local farmers to sustain and grow their business. CEVI gives their client not just credit, but also trainings and insurance coverage.
loan_use: To purchase farm supplies

description:
Mary is a tailor and she also sells clothes to her customers. She is 29 years old and married with a child. \r\n

\r\nShe needs a loan of N40,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.
loan_use: Purchase more clothes to sell.

description:
Florence D. is 47 years old. She is married with seven children, four males and three females. All are in senior high, junior high or basic schools. Her husband is a retired educatior while she is a food vendor. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Mampong, in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Florence prepares and sells Fante Kenkey, a local dish. ‘Fante’ is a tribe in Ghana. The food is so named because it probably originated from the Fante land. It is produced from corn dough. Florence buys bags of maize from farmers in the nearby villages and sells Kenkey in the local market square. She distributes mostly to retailers. She has been in this business for over 20 years.

She wants a loan to procure maize in bulk to be able to supply more customers. Florence also sells palm oil and provision besides the Kenkey business. Florence hopes to sponsor her children in school to high levels.
loan_use: Buy maize in bulk.

description: Juan tiene 44 años, se reconcilió con su pareja y ahora viven con sus dos hijos Luz Mercedes de 17 y Juan de 15 años de edad, en su casa propia. Se dedica a su bodega, pero en determinados momentos cuando no está, sus hijos la atienden y ahora su pareja es la que pasa más tiempo en ella. Por otro lado, también se dedica al trabajo de estibador en uno de los mercados cercanos a donde vive, le gusta su trabajo porque que le da libertad y puede pasar más tiempo con su familia. Suele trabajar de 6am a 2pm como estibador y el resto del día en su bodega. No fue nada fácil para Juan y su familia poner su tienda, nos cuenta que todo nació por la iniciativa de su hija que comenzó a vender adoquines (barra de hielo elaborados en base a jugos de frutas), por la ventana de su domicilio, al ver que las ventas eran buenas decidieron comprar gaseosas, galletas y demás golosinas para los niños que salían del jardín (institución de educación inicial) que se encuentra al frente de su casa. Ahora su negocio va prosperando y ha crecido mucho, Juan y su familia esperan seguir progresando y en el futuro expandirlo mucho más en cuanto a tamaño, para así poner una pequeña librería que administre su hija que está pronta a salir del colegio. Él es un socio antiguo de Microfinanzas Prisma y está muy feliz de pertenecer a su banco comunal “Cristo Morado”, pues dice que más que un grupo, es como una gran familia donde todos se apoyan, siempre ha sido muy puntual en sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita, comprará mayor cantidad de productos para implementar la tienda e iniciar su ampliación.
description_translated:
Juan is 44 years old and is back together with his partner. Now they live in the home they own with their two children, Luz Mercedes (17 years old) and Juan (15 years old). Juan works at his small grocery store, but at designated times his children take over for him. Now his partner is the one who spends the most time there. In addition, Juan also works as a longshoreman in a market close to where they live. He likes his work because it gives him freedom and he is able to spend more time with his family.

He usually works from 6am to 2pm as a longshoreman and then works the rest of the day at his grocery store. It wasn't easy for Juan and his family to open the store. He told us that the entire idea was born from an initiative of his daughter, who began selling adoquines (bars of ice made from fruit juices) from their home. Once they saw that sales were good, they decided to buy soft drinks, crackers, and some candy for children that go past the garden (an early childhood educational facility) in front of their house . Now their business is prospering and has grown a lot. Juan and his family hope to continue growing their business substantially. In this way they will be able to establish a small bookshop that will be run by their daughter who is about to finish high school.

Juan is a long-time member of Microfinanzas Prisma and is very happy to be part of the communal bank "Cristo Morado." He says that it is more than just a group; it is a big family where everyone supports one another. Juan has always been very punctual with his payments. With this loan, he will buy greater quantities of supplies to establish and grow the store.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Morey, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Expand and increase merchandise

description:
Betty is a widow with five kids and three businesses! Her children range from 12 to 22 and all are currently in school. Betty manages to pay school fees at private schools for all five of them.

Betty works alone rearing cattle, pigs, and poultry. In her cattle business, she has two dairy cows and six cows that she is raising to sell for meat. Her two dairy cows produce 10 liters of milk per day, which she sells at 200 USH per liter to the community around her.

In addition to these cows, she currently has five pigs, two males which she will soon sell for meat and three females that she will keep to continue to grow the business.

In her poultry business, she has three layers (chickens that are kept for laying eggs) and four broilers (chickens that are consumed for food). In addition to this work, which she does on her own, she is working to expand her farm. She has created a work schedule for herself where she does agriculture in the morning and her other work (except her morning milking) in the afternoons. She is employing someone now to help with her agricultural work.

Now Betty is asking for a loan of 300,000 USH. She needs to purchase some chemicals to improve her farm. Betty hopes one day to move from her father’s place, where she and her children live now. She would like to build a very large house where she and all her children can live.
loan_use: To purchase some chemicals to improve yields on her farm
borrower_names: Jennifer, John, Teddy, Yero, Betty, Zedi, Sarah, Bigii, Issa, James, Isaah, Samuel, Farida, Faitia
borrower_genders: female, male, female, male, female, male, female, male, female, male, male, male, female, male
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, false, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
As a working mother, Teresita B. manages to devote her time to both family and business. She needs to double her effort just to make sure that all the needs of the family are met. Her husband died, leaving her with 3 kids to raise. With her present business, she knows that she is able to provide and give her family what they are due.

She is a banana cue and vegetable viand vendor during the day and a Balut (processed duck eggs - a Filipino aphrodisiac) vendor at night. Her humble desire is to let her children (who are attending college, high school and elementary school) finish their studies and to have a business that is sustainable and productive so they can have a stable source of living. She is in need of PHP 14,000.00 to finance her business.
loan_use: To purchase eggs, bananas and vegetables for her business

description: Ebenezer A. sells an array of merchandise including cosmetics, rubbers, watches, and belts in Kissi near Elmin. He has been in this business since 2004. He is married, has three children, and has completed a senior high school education. His wife is employed as a trader. He is financially responsible for his children's school fees and for other bills for his family. The goal of the loan is to expand his business and create higher profits. He plans to reinvest the profits in his business for further growth.
loan_use: To expand his business

description:
Moses S. is a member of Semuti group in Mityana. He was one of the first people to join this lending group nine years ago, and then he dropped out. Moses is frank to tell Pearl Microfinance Limited that for the three cycles he was out (one year), things were slow and his level of hard work had dropped a bit, and this affected his income.

He is the Chairman of the village and also has rental houses in Semuti trading centre that helps bring in money. Moses is also a farmer with various plantations growing matooke, cassava and maize.

Moses needs a loan to complete his other houses in the trading centre, by buying iron sheets. He also owns a boda (bicycle taxi) that he gives to others to ride for money, though at times he does the job himself. His wife is a teacher and they have six children who are all in school.
loan_use: Buy iron sheets for home construction.

description:
Najeba is the group leader of the Sayma group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their own business.

Najeba and Sayma want to take a loan for their carpentry business. They will use the loan to buy necessary materials for their business. Najeba wants to take a loan for her husband’s business. They all want to see progress in their businesses and to earn more money to support their families and solve their problems.

They believe that these loans can be very useful because they provide a chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.
loan_use: To buy carpentry materials

description:
Rolybeth L. is 38 years old and married to a tricycle (local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver, with three children. She was engaged in farming as one of their main ways to make a living. She became a member of PDP-LP in March 2007.

Rolybeth accessed the credit services offered by the program and she’s on her 3rd loan amounting to Php 6,000, used for purchase of fertilizers. Her project is farming and she is expecting to have a good harvest. Her dream is that all her kids can finish a course of study and can live independently in the future.
loan_use: Purchase of fertilizer

description: Salimon is 45 years old and married with three children. She lives in Lagos State in Nigeria. She sells frozen food. She has been in business for 15 years. She needs a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more frozen food to sell. Salimon says thanks to all who make this loan possible.
loan_use: To purchase more frozen food to sell

description:
Este banco comunal denominado “APU CURI - QUIQUIJANA”; proviene del respeto a los cerros y montañas de la región, para los antiguos inkas los Apus, eran las representaciones de deidades superiores como el padre, quien abraza y protege a la comunidad.

Los socios de este banco son naturales del distrito de quiquijana, una zona muy bonita y rica en productos, ellos tiene entre sus actividades caceras, las de, agricultores (papa, maíz, alcachofas, habas, verduras, trigo, cebada, flores, duraznos, choclos), y la crianza de alpacas, llamas, ovinos, ganados en general, aves de corral, y dos socios tiene su tienda de abarrotes, muchos de ellos venden productos secos, que son los granos que producen sus tierras. Nuestros nuevos socios, requieren el préstamo para poder invertir en su capital de trabajo y mejorar sus ganancias.

Los socios de este banco están muy agradecidos y valoran el préstamo otorgado y se comprometen en cumplir con sus obligaciones de pago en el plazo y fechas programadas.
description_translated:
This communal bank is called “ APU CURI - QUIQUIJANA ”; it comes from the respect given to the hills and mountains of the region, for the ancient inkas the Apus. They were the representations of top deities like the father, who embraces and protects to the community. The partners of this bank are natives of the district of Quiquijana, a very nice area and rich in products. The partners besides their home activities they are farmers (potatoes, corn, artichokes, beans, vegetables, wheat, barley, flowers, peaches, sweet corn), and they also breed alpacas, llamas, sheep, poultry. Two of the partners have grocery stores. A lot of them sell dry products, which are the grains product of their land. Our new partners need a loan to be able to have a working capital and improve their profits. The partners of this bank are very grateful and value the granted loans and promise to repay in the stipulated terms and dates.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase and sale of sheep, cattle, dry products, groceries and fruits.
borrower_names: ELBERT, GABINA, VILMA HONORATA, YOVANNA, CYNTIA BRINILDA, JULIO, DORIS, CARLOS, HECTOR, ROSA, ALICIA, VICTOR RAUL
borrower_genders: male, female, female, female, female, male, female, male, male, female, female, male
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
La mayor parte de su vida, Delsy la ha dedicado al cuidado de su hogar y a sus tres hijos que hoy tienen dieciocho, once y siete años. No fue sino hasta cuando una amiga le comento sobre los préstamos de EDAPROSPO que empezó a pensar que la idea de tener un negocio propio le seria menos difícil. Es así que empezó a vender gaseosas.

Poco a poco, en tres años, ha ido aumentando el negocio en la cantidad de mercadería. Hoy en día no solo vende gaseosas también cervezas y algunos dulces. Por otro lado, Delsy también es propietaria de un mototaxi, transporte que alquila para que sea trabajado.

Mas adelante, Delsy tiene planeado conseguir el capital suficiente para poder comprar un automóvil y alquilarlo como taxi. Ella y su esposo se encargan de mantener el hogar. Su esposo trabaja como soldador para una empresa.
description_translated:
Delsy has dedicated a large part of her life to caring for her home and her 3 children, who are 18, 11, and 7 years old. It wasn’t until a friend told her about the EDAPROSPO loans that she began to think that having her own business might not be so difficult. That is how she began selling soft drinks. Over the past three years she has slowly increased the amount of merchandise she has. Today she not only sells soft drinks but also beer and some candy. Delsy also owns a mototaxi that she rents out to drivers as a form of transportation. In the future Delsy plans on obtaining enough capital to buy a car and rent it out as a taxi. She and her husband are both responsible for maintaining their home. Her husband works as a welder for a company.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: purchase beer and soft drinks

description:
El grupo solidario Maria Auxiliadora, está ubicado en la comarca El coyolar que pertenece a la ciudad de Granada, está conformado por las siguientes personas:
Manuel Antonio M. C., vende granos básicos en el mercado de Granada, Juliana del Carmen F. C., vende frutas y verduras en el mercado de Masaya, María Lucrecia V. también vende frutas y verduras e n el mercado de Masaya y Granada de forma ambulante y Mario José O. C. vende granos básicos en el mercado de Granada. Tienen actividades similares ya que es en el mercado donde se encuentran y además se conocen en su comunidad.

Esperan trabajar bien, cumpliendo con sus cuotas, ellos llegaron a tener crédito con Adim porque una cliente les habló del tipo de crédito que recibían, donde confiaban en la honorabilidad de los clientes.

Doña María Lucrecia V., es una mujer de treinta y ocho años, con un hijo de catorce años, su fuente de trabajo es la venta de frutas y verduras ambulante  en el mercado de Masaya. Ella tiene la ayuda de su esposo en los gastos del hogar, piensa dar estudio a su hijo y mejorar su vivienda, expresa que esta contenta de trabajar con Adim porque ella nunca había tenido oportunidad de un crédito por no tener garantías y ahora ella va a agradecer mucho a la institución que confía en ella.

Estos señores abonan todos los Lunes, es el mejor día para abonar, después del fin de semana que las ventas son mejores y así garantizan la cuota del préstamo.
description_translated:
The Maria Auxiliadora group is located in the region of El Coyolar in the city of Granada. It is made up of the following people: Manuel Antonio M. C. sells basic grains in the Granada market. Juliana del Carmen F. C. sells fruits and vegetables in the Masaya market. María Lucrecia V. also sells fruits and vegetables in the Masaya market and in Granada as a street vendor. Mario José O. C. sells basic grains in the Granada market. They all have similar work, which is why they met each other in the market and know each other in the community, They hope to work hard, fulfilling their payments. They came to Adim for credit because another customer told them about her loans and their trust in the honesty of their customers. Doña María Lucrecia V. is a 30-year-old woman with a 14-year-old son. Her work is in the sales of fruits and vegetables from stalls in the Masaya market. She has the support of her husband in household expenses. She is thinking of giving her son an education and improving her home. She expresses her satisfaction for working with Adim, because she never had the opportunity to take out loans before for lack of credit. Today she is very thankful that the institution trusts her. They make payments every Monday, the best day to pay after the higher weekend sales and in this way guarantee the loan repayment.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Working capital
borrower_names: María Lucrecia, Mario José, Manuel Antonio, Juliana del Carmen

description:
Adwoa K. is 50 years old. She is widowed with five children; two males and three females. All are in junior high and basic schools. She is a food vendor. Adwoa lives with her children in a rented apartment in Mampong, in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Adwoa prepares and sells sugar Kenkey. It is produced from corn dough. She buys bags of maize from farmers in nearby villages and sells in the local market square. She distributes mostly to retailers. Adwoa has been in this business for five years.

She wants a loan to procure maize in bulk to be able to supply more customers. Adwoa hopes to sponsor her children in school to high levels.
loan_use: Procure bags of maize.

description:
LOURDES R. R., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Atenas Portillanas” con domicilio en el Psje. Alamo Mz. 186 Lt. 14 del distrito de Yarinacocha, tiene 48 años, 05 hijos, y su esposo tiene trabajo en construcción civil.

Hace 4 o 5 años se dedico a la crianza de pollos y la primera vez en Manuela Ramos, obtuvo un préstamo de S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, y afianzo su negocio en crianza de pollos, que con el tiempos con dedicación y empeño logro crecer hasta manejar la crianza de un millar de pollos, lamentablemente en el 2007, el precio del pollo decayó tanto que la obligo a cerrar ese negocio, entonces se dedicó al alquiler de un moto taxi.
Hoy el negocio creció y tiene 2 mototaxis.  Con este crédito de S/.1,800.00 Nuevos Soles, podrá comprar de un motor y dar mantenimiento al otro moto taxi.

Dice: “Manuela Ramos me ha ayudado mucho, pues gracias e esa ONG, estoy apoyando a mis hijos a estudiar en la universidad, me hace posible seguir con los moto taxis cuando estos necesitan una reparación o mantenimiento.”
description_translated:
Lourdes R. R. belongs to the Atenas Portillanas community bank. She lives at Psje. Alamo Mz. 186 Lt. in the Yarinacocha district. She is 48, has 5 children, and her husband works in civil construction.

About 4 or 5 years ago she started raising chickens. The first loan she received from Manuela Ramos was for 300 PEN, and this financed the care of the chickens. With time, dedication and effort she was able to manage raising a thousand chickens. Sadly, in 2007 the price of chickens fell so much that she was forced to close her business. She then started a “mototaxi” for rent business. The business grew, and she now has 2 “mototaxis”. With this loan of 1,800 PEN she would be able to buy a motor and do maintenance on the other “mototaxi”.

She says: “Manuela Ramos has helped me so much, thanks to ONG, I am supporting my children as they study at the university, it has made it possible for me to keep going with the mototaxis when they need repair or maintenance.”

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy a motor and maintance of moto taxi

description: Martha Leonor E. tiene 30 años de edad, su estado civil es casada. La actividad económica de Doña Martha es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 6 años que se dedica a este negocio, su negocio no tiene ubicación ya que se desplaza de manera ambulante para ofrecer sus productos, Martha comenzó con capital propio el cual lo obtuvo de la venta de 6 cerdos y el dinero los invirtió en una pulpería pero debido a la difícil situación decidió dedicarse a la venta de ropa. Los propósitos de Doña Martha son de incrementar sus ventas. Ahora solicita un financiamiento para capital de trabajo y así comprar mercadería como pantalones, camisas, faldas, calzado, bolsos y ropa para niños. El sueño de Martha es de establecer una tienda de repostería en su vivienda. la cantidad que solicita es de C$ 15.500 córdobas.
description_translated:
Martha Leonor E. is 30 years old, married, and makes a living selling a variety of merchandise. She has worked as a travelling saleswoman for over 6 years.

Martha started her business with the capital she obtained from selling 6 pigs She invested this money in a small grocery store, but due to the difficult economic situation she decided to sell clothing instead.

Martha’s goal is to increase her sales. Now she’s requesting a loan to use as working capital to purchase merchandise like trousers, shirts, skirts, footwear, bags and children’s clothing.

Martha dreams of opening a bakery in her home. She is asking for a loan in the amount of 15,500 córdobas.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Working capital

description: Хилола кредитуется на КИВА во второй раз. Ее бизнес заметно расширился и ассортимент товаров увеличен. Хилола ответственный и пунктуальный бизнесмен, показала себя с хорошей стороны. Хилола планирует увеличить ассортимент детской одежды, она знает какой товар сейчас наиболее востребован на рынке. Для реализации своих планов она просит займ на КИВА.\n
description_translated:
Hilola is taking out a loan at Kiva for the second time. Her business has noticeably expanded and assortment of goods has increased. Hilola is a responsible and punctual businesswoman and has shown at her best. Hilola plans to increase the assortment of children's clothing. She knows which merchandise is most in demand on the market right now. To realize her plans she is asking for a loan from Kiva.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy spring assortment of clothing

description: Мухтарам 45 лет, она замужем и имеет 1 ребенка. У нее мелкий бизнес. Она продает сигареты, жевательную резинку, конфеты и тп. При этом не имея постоянной торговой точки она каждый раз привозит свой столик с товаром к местам скопления людей во время праздников и свадеб. Там у нее наиболее лучшая касса ее бизнеса. Муж Мухтарам нигде не работает и использует различные способы чтобы заработать. Мухтарам решила немного расширить свой бизнес и поэтому подала заявку на займ КИВА.\n
description_translated:
Muhtaram is 45 years old, married, and has one child. She runs a small business selling cigarettes, chewing gum, candy and other items. As she doesn't have permanent place to sell at, she she sets up her table and goods where people gather at celebrations and weddings. She has the most business there. Muhtaram's husband is unemployed and finds various ways to make a living. She decided to expand her business a little, and so is requesting a loan from Kiva.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Business expansion

description:
Lhagvasuren A. is a widow. She has two daughters. Her family lives in Uvurhangay province, one of the Mongolia\'s southern provinces. Her two daughters are both college students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. \r\n

\r\nShe has been running a small restaurant out of a traditional "ger" (a circular, nomadic tent) in Uvurhangay since 1998. She caters mostly to those traveling by car. In her 11 years of service, she has gained significant experience and has some loyal customers. She hopes to be able to afford the yearly college tuition for her two daughters until they graduate. In the future, she dreams of having her own full-service restaurant in the province. She requests a loan to purchase inventory, such as soft drinks, for her business.
loan_use: Buy supplies, such as soft drinks, for restaurant

description:
Leonita C., 29 years old, is the mother of three children and a helpful wife to her husband. Leonita and her family resides at Sta. Cruz, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental.\r\n

\r\nLeonita helps her husband in their lumber/timber business. They need additional capital amounting to PHP 10,000 to sustain the demand and for Leonita and her husband to be able to grow their business.
loan_use: To finance their timber/lumber business

description: Batsuh G. is a married father of a fifteen-year-old son and a ten-year-old daughter. Both his children attend elementary school. The family lives in a condo in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Together with his wife, Batsuh has run a grocery store for the past seven years. Batsuh buys the goods wholesale and his wife, along with one saleswoman, runs the store. They pay $330 per month in rent on the store.  Their average daily gross income is $200. About 20 percent of that is profit. They pay their saleswoman $100 a month. Batsuh owns a minibus for transporting goods for his business. Their dream is to one day have their own supermarket. Batsuh is a very open and cheerful person. They are requesting a Kiva loan to buy bread, flour, rice and vegetables.
loan_use: To buy food products

description:
Adwoa A. is fifty-five years old. She is married with five children, two males and three females. One of her children is pursuing a tertiary programme and another in senior high school. The rest are in junior high and the basic schools.

Adwoa is a businesswoman. She sells all kinds of goods. She lives with her husband and children in a family house in Mampong in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Adwoa sells items such as yams, maize, clothes, cosmetics, etc. She buys her goods from the nearby towns and villages and sells in the local market square. Adwoa also treks to other markets to sell. She has been in this business for twenty years. She wants a loan to procure more goods to be able to supply more customers. She hopes to send her children to school up to high levels.
loan_use: To procure goods for re-sale

description: Octavia es una mujer que desde muy joven supo lo que es trabajar duro, vive en su propia casa, junto a su esposo y sus 3 hijos, Elías de 12, Andrés de 10 y Luisa de 7 años, espera poder mejorar su vida, para darle unos buenos estudios a sus hijos. Sale desde muy temprano de su casa a vender sus deliciosos panes, camina junto a su inseparable triciclo por la calles de la ciudad de Juliaca, en espera de encontrar un cliente que le compre su producto. Los deliciosos panes que vende Octavia son preparados por su esposo, quien desde las 3 de la madrugada hornea los panes con mucha paciencia y tranquilidad, para luego dárselos a su esposa para que los venda. Lo que más le gusta a Octavia de su trabajo, es que mientras vende puede ir saboreando los panes que horneo su esposo y así evita pasar hambre, lleva 8 años realizando esta actividad y anhela tener una panadería más adelante donde pueda vender sus panes con una mayor comodidad, lo más difícil de su trabajo es tener que soportar el intenso frió que hace por las mañanas, lo cual la ha llevado a estar enferma muchas veces. Octavia se encuentra en su segundo préstamo con MFP y está muy agradecida, puesto que con el primer préstamo pudo terminar de construir su horno, ahora espera pagar sus cuotas a tiempo y no perjudicar a su banco comunal. Con lo mil quinientos nuevos soles que solicita comprará un nuevo triciclo para llevar a vender sus panes, ya que hace unas semanas sufrió el robo del suyo, lo cual ha perjudicado sus ventas.
description_translated:
Octavia is a woman who learned to work hard at an early age. She lives in her own house with her husband and her three sons, Elias (12), Andrés (10), and Luisa (7). She hopes to improve her quality of life in order to provide her children with a good education. She leaves the house early to sell her delicious breads, walking with her inseparable tricycle cart on the streets of the city of Juliaca, hoping to find customers. The breads Octavia sells are made by her husband, who patiently bakes them at 3:00 in the morning to give to his wife to sell. What Octavia loves most about her work is that she can savor the bread her husband bakes and avoid hunger. She has spent 8 years doing this and longs for her own store where she can sell her bread comfortably since the most difficult part of her job is braving the intense cold in the morning, which has often made her sick. This is Octavia's second loan with MFP and she is very grateful; she used the first loan to finish building an oven. She will pay her loan back on time to avoid hurting her local bank. With this new 1500 sole loan she will buy a new cart to sell bread since her old one was stolen a few weeks ago, hurting her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Shanti Singh, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To replace her stolen tricycle cart for selling bread

description: Astou C. est mariée et membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Palal. Son activité est la vente de fruits locaux et l’embouche. Elle veut relancer son commerce de fruits. Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
description_translated:
Astou C. is married and is a member of the village loan group of Bayouf Palal. Her business involves selling local fruit and pasture fattening of livestock. She would like to boost her fruit-selling business. She is asking for a loan which will be reimbursed at the end of six months in a single payment.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To sell fruit

description: Mrs. Cleofas T. is a 68-year-old widowed mother of three children, and lives at Aloran, Misamis Occidental. As she was skilled in dressmaking, she made it her business. She makes pillow cases and curtains and sells to her primary customers, which include her neighbors, friends and members of Paglaum Multi-purpose Cooperative (PMPC). The cooperative has helped her especially in financial assistance aside from other benefits given to members. She applies for PHP 20,000 to buy additional material for making pillow cases and curtains. With this loan, she looks forward to making her business successful and hopes to open her own tailoring shop someday.
loan_use: to buy additional material for making pillow cases and curtains

description:
Les dix femmes du groupe Horogna sont toutes mariées, la moyenne d’âge des femmes de ce groupe se situe autour de 35 ans  et elles ont en moyenne  6 enfants. Les membres du groupe Horogna vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles  élargies au  village de Paridara au bord du fleuve (région de Ségou, république du Mali). 
Elles se sont  connues  à travers des liens  de voisinage et de parenté. 
Elles exercent presque la même activité  de vente de beurre de karité et de secco. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Pour satisfaire  le  besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Horogna   décida d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier   prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter et stocker du beurre de karité et des Seccos qu’elles achètent avec leurs maris qui le confectionnent. Les Seccos sont vendus au comptant en détail au bord du fleuve à Paridara (où il n’y a pas  de marché). Quant au beurre de karité, il est vendu et à la maison et au marché de San. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 35 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
description_translated:
The ten women of the group Horogna are all married and average about 35 years of age and 6 children each. The group members live in large traditional extended families in the village of Paridara on the banks of the river (Ségou region, Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they do almost the same work, selling shea nut butter and secco butter. The women are in high demand in this business of theirs.

To satisfy the ever-growing needs of their customers, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first solidarity loan (group loan).

They intend to use this loan to buy and store shea nut butter and seccos that they buy with their husbands, who process it. The seccos are sold in retail cash transactions on the riverbank in Paridara (where there is no marketplace). As for the shea nut butter, it’s sold at the house and at the San marketplace.

The group members each hope to realize an average profit of 35,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy shea nut butter and "secco"
borrower_names: Assa, Saniya, Tresé, Dani, Besou, Bibia, Rebeka, Veronique, Béatrice, Martine
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
Mrs. Rosalinda T., 56 years old, is married and blessed with nine children, six of them married. A member in good standing of Paglaum MPC since 2004, her source of income comes from pottery-making. Her project started only thanks to her experience from her neighbors. 

Short of capital to start her pottery business, she accessed a loan in the amount of  PHP 3,000 from Paglaum. The business is doing well and now she needs a bigger amount to buy some stocks of clay, and for cost of labor and transportation expenses. Her hopes and aspirations are to generate employment in the future and send all her children to college.
loan_use: To buy clay and pay labor  and transport expenses
town_name: Plaridel - Biasong, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidenta

description:
Amusatu A. is 37 years old. She is married with five children.  Four of her children are in either junior high or the basic schools. One of them is a seamstress by profession. Amusatu lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Mampong in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Her husband is a plumber by profession.
Amusatu sells iced sachet water. She procures bags of sachet water from the manufacturers who come around in trucks to distribute to her community. Amusatu then puts the water in the fridge to be iced. She hawks the water at the market centre. She says sales are best in the afternoons when the weather is warm and many are dehydrated. She has been in this business for barely one year and wants a loan to procure more bags of sachet water to maximize her profit margin. Amusatu hopes to sponsor her children in higher levels of schooling.
loan_use: To procure sachet water

description:
Con una sonrisa en su rostro, todos los días la señora Marta B. atiende a sus clientes en su pulpería ubicada en el municipio de Ciudad Sandino de la ciudad de Managua donde habita.

Ella se ha caracterizado por ser una persona muy trabajadora y hoy en día ha acudido a Ceprodel porque requiere de un crédito para la compra de los productos para continuar ofertándolos en su propia pulpería cuyo sueños es crecer en su municipio.
description_translated:
With a smile on her face every day, Mrs. Marta B. serves her customers at her store located in the municipality of Ciudad Sandino in the city of Managua where she lives. She has been characterized as a very hardworking person and has now turned to Ceprodel because she requires a loan for the purchase of products she will continue to offer in her own shop. Her dream is to grow her business in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy products for her shop

description: Don Jairo es agente de la Policía Nacional, desde hace seis años, brinda su servicio de seguridad a los Nicaragüense las desventaja es que el salario es bajo, tiene 30 años, reside en el barrio Enrique Bermúdez, su esposa le tiene dos hijos los cuales estudian, ella se dedica a la venta de cosmético ambulante para apoyar a las necesidades de su familia. Con este crédito va a comprar materiales de construcción para hacer un muro en la parte de atrás de su casa para tener  seguridad para su familia ya que lo tiene con zinc y desea que sea mas seguro. Sus planes es poder hacer las mejoras necesarias en su casa para el bienestar de su familia.
description_translated:
Jairo has been a member of the Nicaragua National Police Force for six years. The disadvantage is that wages are low. Jairo is 30 and he lives in the Enrique Bermúdez district.

He and his wife have two children, both at school. His wife sells cosmetics door to door to support the family.

He will use the loan to build a wall behind his house to provide his family with more security, since the current wall is made of zinc is not so secure.

He plans to make necessary improvements in his home for his family's welfare.

Translated from Spanish by John Rynne, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy construction materials to build a wall behind his house

description:
Lourdelyn D. specializes in manicure and pedicure treatment. She took a thorough seminar on this work and is now serving the entire community, especially wives wishing to have their nails polished and cleaned. Lourdelyn, the 35-year-old mother of three children, is married to Cuneberto, a farmer. They have worked together to endure the global crisis that has created instability in businesses such as hers.

Lourdelyn is requesting a loan of Php 5,000 from CEVI to buy new sets of materials for her pedicure/manicure business. The loan will help her gain more customers and earn a larger income.

CEVI is helping people to start and maintain their own businesses. They also provide credit, training and insurance coverage services to help clients achieve business growth.
loan_use: To purchase sets of materials for her manicure/pedicure business.

description:
Maria Luvis R. owns a tricycle (a motorcyle with a side car which is being used as a common public utility vehicle in the rural areas). She is 42 years old and has only 1 child. Her husband, Ricardo R. is driving their small tricycle to supplement the family income. She is planning to establish her own sari-sari store. 
She is now requesting a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI to  repair her tricycle and start buying merchandise for her store. She believes that by selling more items she will have more profit; therefore, the loan will truly help her family to earn bigger income. 

CEVI is helping Maria Luvis to sustain her business, providing credit, training and insurance coverage to feed and clothe her family.
loan_use: To repair his tricycle and purchase permit and start a new business

description:
Danilo D. is engaged in rice farming. He owns a small parcel of land that he uses to support the needs of his family. He is 42 years old and has three children. Danilo has been into farming since he was just a small kid. His parents are farmers and everything he knows about growing crops came from them. Danilo's life is on the farm and he wanted to support his children.

Danilo is asking for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers, and herbicides for his farm. The loan will help enrich the soil and result in good harvests. They need the loan to sustain their business.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start and have their own businesses. They give their clients credit, training and insurance coverage as well.
loan_use: Purchase fertilizers and herbicides.

description: El señor Cirilo Alejandro C. tiene la edad de 34 años, habita en el barrio San Caralampio ubicado en la concepción  - Masaya , el es soltero habita con sus padres , los planes hacia un futuro es poder construir una casa ya que la que tiene actualmente es de madera con plástico y en las madrugadas hace mucho fríos , él desde hace cinco años trabaja como agricultor , con la ayuda de sus papá , los planes hacia un futuro para sus cultivos es poder diversificarlo , el financiamiento lo quiere para la comprar de fertilizantes e insumos para que la cosecha se en buenas condiciones y poder vender a buen precio en el mercado.
description_translated:
Cirilo Alejandro C., 34, lives in the San Caralampio neighborhood located in La Concepción, Masaya. He is single and lives with his parents. His plans for the future are to be able to build a house. The one he has now is made of wood and plastic. In the morning it is very cold. \r\n\r\nSince he was five years old, with the help of his parents, he has worked as a farmer. The future plans for his crops are to diversify them. He wants the loan to be able to buy fertilizer and supplies. Then his harvest will be in good condition, and he will be able to sell it for a good price at the market.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy farming supplies for his farm

description:
The Nuevo Progreso Bank of Hope has been a part of Esperanza International for three years. This group within the bank is requesting their sixth loan. Many of this group's members sell clothing and accessories. They've been able to develop a faithful clientele who purchase enough to enable the group members to pay their loans and make some profits.

Reina P. is the group coordinator and she runs a small grocery store. She will use this loan to buy three items with a large demand: rice, beans, and sugar. Rice and beans are essential to the Dominican diet because they are the main ingredients of the typical Dominican lunch. Sugar also plays an important part in the Dominican diet as it is used to make several sweets (especially with coconut, which is very abundant in the Samana Peninsula) and to sweeten coffee, which Dominicans drink especially strong. Reina wants to see her grocery store become a "super colmado," complete with sitting area, cold cuts area, and everything a customer could possibly imagine.

Please help us support these strong-willed entrepreneurs through this micro loan. Thank you!
loan_use: To purchase rice, beans, and sugar for grocery sales.

description:
Vida O., 37, is the mother of three children, one in senior high school, another in junior high and another in primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in the fishing community of Elmina, one of the tourist attraction centres near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. 

To support her husband financially, Vida works as a trader, selling a variety of footwear including shoes, slippers, sandals, and prim soles in the community market, procuring her products from wholesale dealers in the regional capital, Cape Coast. As well, she sometimes hawks her wares and treks to other markets to sell on the market days. She has been in business for eight years and is requesting a loan to procure more footwear.
loan_use: To buy footwear.

description:
El presente Comité  denominado Kuña activa de la compañía Cabañas de la ciudad de Caacupé, la misma integran 15 mujeres, todas ellas mayores de edad, y residentes en el mismo barrio.

En la actualidad el comité opera en su 10mo. ciclo recibiendo un promedio de guaranies 540.000 por cada integrante. Las mismas beneficiadas destinan sus prestamos en actividades comerciales detalladas mas abajo, que como se observa en la gran mayoria consiste en vender productos variados en forma ambulante que requiere de mayor esfuerzo para demandar los productos.

Es bueno mensionar que,  a la par que éstas mujeres reciben una asistencia financiera, asi tambien se benefician de servicios no financieros que comprenden la capacitación por cada ciclo, en las que las mismas aprenden como mantener la integridad del comité en donde pertenecen, aprenden a ahorrar, y a realizar presupuestos personales y familiares. Todo esto engloba los beneficios que reciben del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras que promueve la fundación Paraguaya de Cooperación  y Desarrollo.

La  integración toda del detallado Comité , agradece a la fundaciòn Parguaya por brindarles este tipo de oportunidades que promueve la creación de pequeños negocios y por ende generar recursos económicos a sectores desfavorecidos por este tipo de beneficios.

1.	Francisca C.        Vivero                             
2.	Elvira V.                   Vivero                            
3.	Inocencia A.          Despensa                      
4.	Marta B.                Venta de ropa             
5.	Felipa Q.            Peluqueria                     
6.	Maria C.                Despensa                       
7.	Elva D.                  Kiosko                            
8.	Juliana V.                   Venta de carbón             
9.	Lidia M.                   Vivero                             
10.	Clementina V.            Venta de ropa                  
11.	Hilaria G.             Venta de chipa                 
12.	Pablina V.         Vivero                              
13.	Maria M.               Despensa                        
14.	Liduvina C.            Despensa                         
15.	Carmen B.             Venta de cosmeticos
description_translated:
The present committee is named Kuña Activa in the Cabañas group from the city of Caacupé. Its membership includes 15 women, all of them adults and residents of the same neighborhood.

Right now the committee works in 10-month cycles, receiving an average of 540,000 for each member. These recipients use their loans for the economic activities detailed below, of which you will see the majority are street vendors that sell various products.

It should be mentioned that as well as the financial assistance that these women receive, they also benefit from non-financial services such as training each cycle, in which they learn to maintain the integrity of the committee, to save and to carry out their personal and family budgets. This encapsulates all the benefits that they receive from the program Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras (Enterprising Women’s Committee) that promotes the foundation Paraguaya de Cooperación y Desarollo (Cooperation and Development of Paraguay).

The members of the Committee thank the foundation Paraguaya for bringing them these types of opportunities that promote the creation of small businesses and generate economic resources for sectors that are not favored for this type of benefits.

1. Francisca C. Nursery 2. Elvira V. Nursery 3. Inocencia A. Small store 4. Marta B. Clothing Sales 5. Felipa Q. Hair Salon 6. Maria C. Small store 7. Elva D. Kiosk 8. Juliana V. Coal sales 9. Lidia M. Nursey 10. Clementina V. Clothing sales 11. Hilaria G. Chipa (bread) sales 12. Pablina V. Nursery 13. Maria M. Small store 14. Liduvina C. Small store 15. Carmen B. Sale of cosmetics

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: For the purchase of merchandise: fruits, vegetables, meats, cosmetics, hardware, bread-making materials, coal, fertilized seeds, plants and others
borrower_names: Maria, Maria, Pablina, Elvira, Lidia, Felipa, Francisca, Juliana, Carmen, Elva, Liduvina, Inocencia, Clementina, Marta, Hilaria
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, false, true, true, true, true, true

description:
The “Lumiere Celeste” or “Heavenly Light” Group is a made of twenty-five male and female entrepreneurs. After successfully repaying their 1st and 2nd loans, they are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with this loan.

Their businesses are very diverse. They range from selling and repairing motorcycles to a bakery and many others in between.

J. J. is the representative of the group. This hard-working young man sells motorcycles. He buys the motorcycles in the Dominican Republic to re-sell in Haiti. He sells in various locations depending on the customer and has an ever-growing client base in multiple cities across northern Haiti. He has one person who works with him who repairs motorcycles as well.

J. is grateful for the increased profits from his business because they have allowed him to purchase chickens and goats, and help family members when they’re ill. He dreams of expanding the business to employ multiple people and earn enough to build a house and eventually get married.

On behalf of J., Lumiere Celeste, and Esperanza we thank you for your support!
loan_use: Motorcycle parts, tools, appropriate oils
borrower_names: Louisjacques, Kesnel, Jean-Claude, Emilcia, Yvon, Rosenie, Marseille, Roseleine, Dieula, Joseph, Marielouise, Ketty, Lucien, Ivrance, Alice
borrower_genders: male, female, male, female, male, female, female, female, female, male, female, female, male, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, false, true, true, true

description: La señora Magdalena R. es madre soltera y  es una mujer emprendedora ya que actual mente tiene un negocio de papelería y renta de computadoras esté es el ingreso de su familia. Actual mente es nuevo negocio le hace falta mas equipo y mercancía  es por eso que esta solicitando nueva mente su cooperación para poder llevar acabo está inversión.
description_translated:
\r\n\r\nMrs. Magdalena Rodriguez is an enterprising single mother who supports her family with a stationer's store where she also rents computers. Her business needs more equipment and inventory so she is again asking for help in order to increase her investment.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To purchase computer equipment.

description:
El Banco Comunal Paz y Amor inicia su ciclo 14 con 20 socias, las socias son del distrito D. Pacaycasa que se ubica a 40 minutos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. abarrotes en general, carne, verduras, frutas, bebidas, tara, cochinilla y la fabricación D. ladrillos.

Como es el caso D. Reyna que es conviviente, tiene 29 años y 1 hija, Reyna tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, además compra tara, cochinilla que luego venD. a los intermediarios.

Por otro lado Demetria es casada, tiene 33 años y 3 hijos, Demetria junto a su esposo se dedican a la elaboración D. ladrillos artesanales, el quemado D. los ladrillos lo realizan en hornos alquilados.

Mientras que Paulina es conviviente, tiene 39 años y 5 hijos, Paulina venD. cerveza, gaseosa, actividad que realiza en su casa, además los días domingos venD. comida en el estadio D. su comunidad.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 450 soles, 600soles, haciendo un total D. 12,950 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra D. arroz, azucar, carne, frutas, bebidas y el pago D. peones.

Los sueños D. las socias son ampliar, surtir sus negocios, comprar una computadora para sus hijos, tener otro negocio mas y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
description_translated:
The “Paz y Amor” (“Peace and Love”) Community Bank is beginning its fourteenth loan cycle with twenty members. The group is from the Pacaycasa district, located forty minutes from the city of Ayacucho. The group's members have businesses which sell a variety of items, such as general merchandise, meat, vegetables, fruit, drinks, tara seeds (used to make tannic acid and starch), pill bugs (used to make ink), and bricks. For example, Reyna is a 29-year-old mother of one daughter who lives with her common law husband. She has a shop in her home where she sells groceries. She also purchases tara seeds and pill bugs to later sell to intermediaries. On the other hand, Demetria is married, 33 years old, and has three children. Together with her husband, Demetria makes artisanal bricks and fires them in rented ovens. While Paulina is 39-years-old, has five children, and lives with her common law husband. Paulina sells beer and soft drinks from her home. On Sundays, she also sells food at the local sports stadium. The group's members need differing loan amounts (300, 450, or 600 Peruvian nuevos soles), for a grand total of 12,950 nuevos soles to be loaned to the community bank. The loans will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, meat, fruit, and drinks and to pay workers' salaries. The bank's members dream of expanding and stocking their businesses, buying computers for their children, having other businesses, and providing their children with good educations.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To purchase rice, sugar, meat, fruit, and drinks and to pay workers' salaries
borrower_names: Marcelina, Vitaliano, Sergio, Lucia, Sonia, Crescenciano, Paulina, Haydee, Haydee, Miguel, Guillermina, Vicente, Paulina Marcelina, Soledad, Amanda, Juan Carlos, Ynes, Guillermina, Demetria, Reyna
borrower_genders: female, male, male, female, female, male, female, female, female, female, female, male, female, female, female, male, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
Monsieur Zoumana Dembélé est un homme marié de 32 ans et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le  quartier Hérémakono nord de la ville de  Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très vite il commença les activités économiques notamment la vente d’une boutique d’articles divers,  apprise auprès de son oncle maternel.
Avec une expérience de 4 ans, Monsieur Zoumana Dembélé maîtrise son activité.
Pour agrandir sa boutique, Monsieur Zoumana Dembélé décida de solliciter le concours de Soro Yiriwaso, pour acheter divers articles (thé, biscuit, insecticides, anti moustique en spirale, lames rasoir, cigarettes etc.)  
Il est à son premier prêt individuel  avec  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
 Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes et a une  clientèle  constituée de toute les catégories sociales.
 Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Zoumana Dembélé compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice il envisage de construire sa maison d’habitation.
description_translated:
Mr. Zoumana Dembélé, age 32, is married and the father of 3 children. He lives with his wife and his children in the Hérémakono neighborhood, in the north of the city of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).\r\nHaving never attended school, he started working early on, and got introduced to selling various items by his mother's brother. Having now four years of experience, Mr. Zoumana Dembélé masters his business. To expand his shop, Mr. Zoumana Dembélé decided to seek help from Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to buy various items (tea, biscuits, insecticides, spiral mosquito repellents, razor blades, cigarettes, etc). He's seeking his first loan from the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He gets his supplies from wholesalers in Bamako, the capital of the Republic of Mali, and has a clientele comprising all social categories. With this loan, Mr. Zoumana Dembélé foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 80), to be used to build his own home.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy various products for his retail store

description: Folake A. is 40 years old and married with three children.  She sells bags, shoes and jewelries.  Folake is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more shoes, bags and jewelry to sell.  Folake says thanks to all Kiva lenders.
loan_use: Purchase more shoe, bags and jewelries to sell.

description: Adetokunbo F. is 29 years old and married without a child.  She sells sarongs.  Adetokunbo is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell.  She hopes to expand her business. Adetokunbo says thanks to all Kiva lenders.
loan_use: Purchase more sarongs to sell.

description: Casilda de 49 años de edad, es madre soltera, vive con sus tres hijos y nietos que la apoyan mucho. Se dedica a la venta de comida, vende desayunos y almuerzos, que complementa con la venta de bebidas gasificadas. Esta actividad la viene realizando desde hace 6 años en las instalaciones de su casa y cuenta con el apoyo de sus hijos. Le gusta mucho su trabajo porque la hace sentir útil, además le es rentable porque se encuentra ubicada en un sitio estratégico (paradero de autos de transporte). Para más adelante, Casilda quiere llegar a ampliar su negocio y constituir un restaurante. Con MFP ya tiene 8 préstamos, y le encanta trabajar con su banco comunal porque hay comprensión entre todos los integrantes. Invertirá 1500 soles en su negocio de la venta de comida y bebidas, y lo demás es para apoyar en los gastos a su hijo quien está estudiando una carrera profesional.
description_translated:
Casilda is 49, is a single mother, and lives with her three children and grandchildren who support her a lot. She sells food, including breakfast and lunch, which she complements by selling soft drinks. She has done this for six years in her home, and she has the help of her children. She likes her job a lot because it makes her feel useful. It is also profitable because her business is located in a strategic place (at a taxi stand). In the future, Casilda wants to expand her business and have a restaurant. She has had eight loans with Microfinanzas Prisma, and she loves to work with her communal bank because there is an understanding among all of the members. She will invest 1500 PEN in selling food and drinks, and the rest she will use to support the educational expenses of her son, who is studying to be a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Increase in capital for her business

description: Balogun A. is 39 years old and married with 4 children. He makes shoes of various sizes and colours for his customers. He is requesting the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more shoe materials to make more shoes to sell. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To purchase more shoe materials to make more shoes to sell

description: Janet, 58 and married with six children, has sold palm oil for years. A client of LAPO, she is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more palm oil to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.  \r\n  \r\n
loan_use: To purchase more palm oil to sell.

description:
Fabiola is the president of the “Juntos de la Mano” (“Holding hands”) Village Bank. She is 29 years old and is the single mother of a two-year-old daughter.

Fabiola sells dry goods like grains, flour, and dried beans and corn from a small grocery store she runs in Anta, a town about 40 minutes outside of the city of Cusco. She recently opened the store in a rented location; before then, she worked from a smaller stand. Fabiola works seven days a week at her store from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. She usually works alone, though sometimes her goddaughter helps her, as does the father of her daughter.

Fabiola is requesting a loan of 1500 soles to stock her new store. She still has to take inventory, so she isn’t sure exactly what products she will need to buy yet. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan on time and in full.

Fabiola’s goal for the future is to open her own large supermarket.
loan_use: To stock her recently opened small grocery store

description: Ketty tiene 27 años de edad, es madre de 2 hijos, vive junto a su esposo, quien le apoya y está de acuerdo con sus objetivos de negocio. Ambos viven en la casa que con mucho esfuerzo pudieron conseguir. Ambos se dedican a la venta de madera trabajada, su esposo es el encargado de comprar la madera en bruto y llevarla a un aserradero para que la dejen lista la venta, mientras ella, administra el negocio y se contacta con los clientes. Con esta actividad ya tienen laborando un periodo de 4 años, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que se relaciona con muchas personas. Lo bueno de este negocio, y por lo que es rentable, es que cuenta con clientes fieles que le comprar periódicamente, además de satisfacer los pedidos de carpinterías de otras provincias. El deseo de Ketty para el futuro es comprar maquinarias de aserradero (cortadoras, sierras, entre otros). Con MFP ya tiene 3 préstamos, su banco comunal se llama “Las Palmas”, y le gusta trabajar con este grupo porque considera que son personas responsables, que si se presenta un problema, buscan resolverlo lo antes posible, en vez de hacerlo más grave. Ketty invertirá el dinero que ahora solicita en la compra de más madera.
description_translated:
Ketty is 27 years old, has 2 children, and lives with her husband, who helps her and agrees with her business goals. They live together in the home that they acquired with a lot of effort and strength. They both sell treated wood—her husband is in charge of buying the untreated wood and taking it to a sawmill to prepare it for sale. Ketty runs the business and communicates with their customers. They have been working in this business for the past 4 years and like it because they get to interact with many people. The good part about this job, and the reason that it is profitable, is that they have loyal customers who buy their wood. They also fill orders from carpenters from other states. In the future, Ketty hopes to buy sawmill machines (cutting machines, saw, etc). This is her third loan with MFP and her community bank is called “Las Palmas.” She enjoys working with this group because she believes they are responsible people, and if there is a problem, they all try to solve the problem as quickly as possible, instead of making it worse. Ketty will use this money to purchase more wood.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: wood

description:
Members of Bank of Hope live in Hato Mayor, Dominican Republic. Their town is very small with few industries or services that generate employment. And although fishing is a largely practiced, it receives little support or funding.

The business activities of these entrepreneurs are varied: juice bar/ice cream shop, cosmetics sales, clothing sales and fish selling. Fish in this area are especially good, caught and sold on the same day.

Lourdes T. is the group coordinator. She sells fish for a living. Lourdes buys fresh fish at the Sabana D. la Mar port, where fishermen offer it after they come from work. She takes it home, clean it and sells to customers. Lourdes will use this loan to purchase more fish, which she can freeze if not sold in a short period of time.
