description_translated:
Señora Sara María A. S. is 41 years of age and lives in La Esperanza District of Trujillo Province, Department of La Libertad. She completed her secondary education. She has four children who are economically dependent on her. Sara works selling prepared food and beer from her business which she operates out of her home. Her first loan of 200 Sols which she received from her Communal Bank, Nueva Esperanza II (the Second New Hope), was used to buy utensils for the restaurant, such as pots, dishes and beer. This loan of 1,500 Sols will be used to buy supplies such as beer and soft drinks in order to stock up her business. Sara has a dream of having her own bookstore in order to grow as the owner of a small business.\r\nTo view her previous loans click here and here.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy beer and soft drinks.

description: Janet O. is a married mother of seven children, four sons and three daughters, who are all currently still in school – senior high, junior high and primary schools. She is 45 years old. Janet lives with her children and husband in a family house in Dwenase, a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Her husband is a professional teacher. She is a baker. She bakes bread in her community. She supplies bread to retailers and beverage sellers in her community and hawks to sell. She buys bags of flour from Kumasi. Janet has been in business for over three years and wants a loan to buy bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk. She wants to expand her business and give her children a good education.
loan_use: To buy flour in bulk

description:
Mercedes es socia del Banco Comunal Hormigas.
Mercedes es casada, tiene 48 años y 6 hijos, Mercedes venD. comida en el mercado Nery García, actividad que realiza por las mañanas D. manera ambulatoria, además Mercedes venD. golosinas en L. puerta D. su casa por las tardes y noches.
Mercedes necesita un préstamo D. 800 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. azúcar, arroz y golosinas.
Los sueños D. Mercedes son que sus hijos sean profesionales y mejorar su negocio.
description_translated:
Mercedes is a member of the Hormigas Community Bank. Mercedes is 48, married, and she has six children. Mercedes sells food in the Nery García market. She sells on foot in the mornings. Mercedes also sells sweets in the doorway to her house in the afternoons and evenings. Mercedes needs a loan for 800 PEN to buy sugar, rice, and sweets. Mercedes’ dreams are for her children to become professionals and to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy sugar, rice, and sweets

description: Beatrice K. is a friendly and hard-working 40-year-old widow with five children aged 12 to 20 years of age. The older two are currently on vacation, while the rest are in secondary school. She also cares for one nephew, one niece and her own parents. Beatrice makes a living running a canteen and a farm that she has owned for five years. She is also a seamstresss, who learned her trade at a school where she now teaches sewing other people, mostly young girls. \r\n\r\nIn her canteen, Beatrice sells a variety of products because this attracts more customers, and uses a portion of her income to pay school fees for her children and to maintain their standard of living. She has applied for this loan to complete work on the building where she teaches sewing, and to buy more products for her canteen, particularly sugar, bread and cakes. She leads the Tulwanirewamu loan group pictured here.
loan_use: To restock her store and buy building materials .
borrower_names: Beatrice, John, Martha, Esther, Robert, Joy, Mariam, Hellen, Deborah, Aisha, Rose, Musana, Angella, Jane, Geofrey, Lydia
borrower_genders: female, male, female, female, male, female, female, female, female, female, female, male, female, female, male, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description: Daniel is married and the father of two children who are in school. He is thirty-seven years old. He lives at Suhum in the eastern region of Ghana with his family. He operates a corn mill machine where people come to grind their corn, peeled cassava, and sometimes fresh tomatoes. He happens to be the only person who is in this business in the community. Daniel has been in this business for the past year. He complains that the number of people who come to grind their products are more than what the machine can grind. This has slowed his profits drastically, therefore, he wants the loan to buy an additional corn milling machine and its parts, so that he can meet the demands of his customers before competition emerges in the community. He believes this will make him more resourceful in taking care of the home as a father. He belongs to the village bank called ‘Yehowa nemewhefo’.
loan_use: To buy a corn milling machine and parts to meets the demand of his customers.

description: Stella B. is twenty-six years old. She is married and has one child, a boy who is yet to start school. She lives with her son and husband in a rented apartment in the commercial town of Dwenase, a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. She is a hard working woman. Her husband is in the sand winning business while Stella runs a provision store. She sells groceries such as Milo (a chocolate malt beverage), sugar, rice, candies, and bread in a store on the street. She has been in business for seven years now and wants a loan to buy more provisions to expand her store. She hopes to improve her standard of living and give her child a good education.\r\n
loan_use: To buy provisions for her grocery store.

description:
La asociación denominada “Unión Pro mujer” trabaja junto a  Pro-Mujer hace más diez,  a la fecha  cuenta con doce socias activas, ellas han  demostrado ser un grupo organizado en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito.
Dentro el grupo la mayoría están casadas y con familias, se ven en la necesidad de buscar  otras fuentes de ingresos ya que las necesidades de sus hijos aumentan día a día.
Existen diferentes negocios  dentro la asociación como ser; la venta de ropa usada, víveres, cosméticos otras también se dedican al  tejido de mantas, en lana de vicuña. La mayoría de ellas venden sus productos en ferias de la ciudad Necesitan capital para poder comprar mayor cantidad de mercadería  o productos, de esta manera generar mayores ingresos que les permita ofrecer bienestar a sus familias
description_translated:
The Unión Pro Mujer group has worked together with Pro-Mujer for over ten years. They currently have 12 active members. They have shown themselves to be an organized group regarding their loan payments. Most of the group members are married and have families. They need to look for other sources of income since their children’s needs increase every day. Within the group there are different businesses such as selling used clothes, provisions, and cosmetics. Other group members weave blankets from vicuna wool. Most of them sell products at the fairs in the city. They need capital to be able to buy a larger quantity of merchandise or products. This way they will generate greater income, which will allow them to provide for the well being of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy merchandise
borrower_names: MARIA ANTONIA, MATILDE, ESTELA, FIDELIA, MARTHA NATALIA, GLADYS VIRGINIA, CHARO ROSA, ZELMA ISABEL, BLANCA, CARLOTA, DAVID FELIPE, GLADYS
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, male, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, false, false, true, true, true

description: La Asociación Comunal “Suma Sartawi” tiene aproximadamente 3 años de vida, se encuentra en el Centro Focal “Los Andes”, su presidenta es Judith Agüero, quien indica que la Asociación se conformo con amigas que vivían en la misma zona, alrededor de una escuelita. “Suma Sartawi” esta conformada por 14 integrantes que tienen diferentes negocios como ser: tejido de mantas, venta de ropa, comida, juguetes, repuestos de celulares, zapatos, tienda de barrio y costura de deportivos. Todas manifiestan necesitar el préstamo, para incrementar su capital de trabajo y poder llegar a más mercados.
description_translated:
The Suma Sartawi Community Association has been in existence for approximately three years. The Association is located in the Los Andes Community Center. Their president is Judith Agüero. Judith says that the Association was formed by friends who live in the same zone close to a small school. \r\n\r\nSuma Sartawi is made up of 14 members who have different businesses like weaving blankets, selling clothes, selling meals, selling toys, replacement parts for cell phones, shoes, neighborhood store, and sewing sportswear. All of them need a loan for working capital to be able to go to more markets.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Increase working capital
borrower_names: MARITZA, SEBASTIANA, LIDIA, FACUNDA, NICOLASA, QUISPE, MARIA, BETTY, ELIZABETH, GREGORIO, VIVIANA, CINDA, JUDITH, MARINA
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, male, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, false, false, true, true, true, true, true

description:
Rosalina is the mother of four who believes that poverty is not a hindrance to success. Thus, she is doing her best in sending all her children to school, for them to have good job opportunities someday.

Because of a lack of financial resources, Rosalina is borrowing PHP 7,000 to further sustain her hog-raising business in their village at Bimonton Mallig, Isabela. She has a strong determination to become successful in all her plans in life and she did it by having three of her children graduated from their college courses so that she now only supports the education of her youngest child.

Rosalina’s husband, Warlito, is grateful for having her as his wife and they are helping each other in reaching out for their family success.
loan_use: To use as business capital

description:
Ligaya is 29 years old and married to Bonifacio.They are blessed with three children. Ligaya is a God-fearing person and also teaches her children the words of God.

Ligaya manages a little vending stall in their village selling snacks and some vegetables. She is borrowing PHP 4,000 as additional business capital. This will make her business progressive in the coming days as she generates funds for the education of her three children. Ligaya also wants their living situation to someday be alleviated from poverty and she believes that the lenders will play a big role in achieving her dreams in life.
loan_use: To use as business capital

description:
Rosalinda M., 55 years old, has 3 children. She lives in Navalan, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She has been engaged in fruit vending for 2 years now. She joined Paglaum MPC and has received three loans already.

\r\n\r\nRecently she applied for the amount of PHP 10,000 as additional capital for her fruit vending. The profit she generates from her fruit business will be used in purchasing textiles and to make into curtains for added income. Rosalinda makes use of her time in working at a hobby and at the same time making an additional income.
loan_use: expansion of her fruit vending business

description:
Ednalayn L. is from the village of Anonang, Dumalinao. Zambo Sur. She is 30 years old. Ednalayn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ednalayn works in a family member's business venture selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling personal products to tourists and local community members. Ednalayn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ednalayn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ednalayn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Ednalayn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Ednalayn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve/expand her business.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: to purchase additional products to sell

description:
Magdalin is eighteen years old and lives at Green Valley, Tinago, Ozamiz City, with her husband and child. She is engaged in backyard farming, and started with the fattening of four piglets. She also wants to sell longganisa (spicy sausages or "chorizos") to her neighbors and friends. Her goal is to add to her husband's income.

In her first cycle she borrowed 5,000 PHP for her new business. She is now hoping that with the help of Paglaum MPC and through KIVA finance her small hog fattening business will someday become a big piggery for the future of her family.
loan_use: For hog fattening

description:
“If others can, why can’t I?” This is what Cristina A. voiced when she was asked about her principle in life. Cristina is now 46 years old and married to Zenon who is a foreman carpenter in Cabanatuan City. The couple and their children live in a place near the Cagayan River at Barangay Lullutan, Ilagan, Isabela. They are blessed with three children who are all studying. Crispin, their eldest, is now in college; the same with Melissa who was a college freshman; Angelo, their youngest, is studying in high school.

Cristina runs a variety store in front of their house. She sells various products to generate higher income for her family. She is thankful that, through the business, her family was able to survive the hardships of life. She is very proud that she is able to send her children to school through the business. She even goes to Pangasinan just to purchase fresh and dried fish to have sufficient source of income.

Cristina is hoping that, someday, their way of living will improve through her own sacrifices and patience. But for the meantime, her children’s education is her priority.  She believes that she can also make her business progressive just like others who are striving to succeed. To further develop her business, Cristina is applying for a loan of PHP 8,000 as additional working capital.
loan_use: To use as business capital

description: Fernando G. is from the village of Santiago, Iligan City. He is 42 years old, is separated from his spouse, and has three school-aged children. Fernando owns and operates a specialized retail business, primarily buying and selling scrap materials in his village. He has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Fernando joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of his children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To invest in expanding his business
town_name: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

description:
Rosemarie C., 47 years old, started her business 20 years ago. She always wanted to assist her husband in farming to earn enough to be able to send their seven children to school and to meet their daily needs. She plans to acquire another hectare to expand the business. But in the meantime, her main concern is to sustain her business. In order to this, she’ll need additional capital to purchase fertilizer and other farming necessities.

Thus, she applies for a Php 10,000.00 loan from the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). Since CEVI offers wide services aside from the loans they, Rosemarie is confident that she can meet her obligation responsibly and their ambition to have a better life is now just a few steps away.
loan_use: To buy fertilizer and other necessities

description: Osei is 36 years old.  He is married with four kids.  Three are in school.  He is a taxi driver and has been doing this for the past six years.  Taxi driving has been his major occupation and the main source of livelihood for his family. He picks up passengers from the local station and drives them to nearby towns for a fare of 50 pesewas (0.5 cedis) per head.  However, his business is in crisis because his car has broken down and he needs money for repairs.  He requests a loan to maintain his taxi car to resume his business to make income to support his family and get his kids back to school.  He belongs to a community group called Fervent Trust.  Members guarantee each others loans and apply peer pressure to repay the loans.
loan_use: Maintain taxi car.

description:
Lucia M. R. started her business two years ago with her first Esperanza loan. She opened a colmado out of the side of her house. In the Dominican Republic, a colmado is a small, neighborhood general store. Lucia sells several staple food items such as rice, dried beans, cookies and crackers as well as razors, toilet paper and other daily necessities. Her business has been very successful, and she is now on her third Ezperanza loan.

Lucia's business has helped put her two children through college. She has a son, age 25, and a daughter, age 23. She is enthusiastic about the success of her business and plans to continue to expand her business as much as possible. The community she lives in loves the convenience of having a colmado in the neighborhood. Lucia is now a group leader for Esperanza and her story provides encouragement to all the women in her loan group.
loan_use: Inventory for a colmado
borrower_names: Dominga, Olguita, Maria, Anasilvia, Maria, Leonarda, Dallery, Medeline, Fifa, Antonia, Lucia, Vanesa, Trinidad, Estrella, Benita
borrower_genders: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description: Marielena, the group coordinator, resides in a Batey (small agricultural village) in the La Romana region of the Dominican Republic along with the other members of her credit group. She lives with her husband J. Jimenez and their six children ages 18, 16, 14, 10, 7 and 6. Despite being illiterate she has successfully created a retail business selling various sundry items from a paletera (small retail stand) to support her family. She has been able to expand her business to this point with the help of Esperanza International and this is her third loan, after having successfully repaid the first two.\r\n\r\nWith her new loan Marielena plans to further expand her offerings by purchasing flour, cooking oil, shoes, saltines, lollipops and charcoal to sell; all items for which she has identified a market. In the long term Marielena plans to expand to the point where she can own and operate a colmado (small retail store). She hopes to do so in order to better support her family. Although she recognizes the difficulty of continuing to expand, she is continuing to look for new products which will be in demand in her area.
loan_use: To buy flour, cooking oil, shoes, saltines, charcoal and lollipops

description: Natsagdorj D. is 45 years old and married. His family lives in a "ger" (a nomadic housing tent) district on a plot of land he owns in Arhangay, one of Mongolian central provinces. He runs a retail business, selling small household items such as sponges and loofahs at the local market. In 2008, he started renting a small stall because his business was doing well. Over the last two years, his working capital has increased by a factor of eight. Natsagdorj\'s main goal now is to own his own stall in near future. He plans to use this loan to buy more household items to sell and increase his inventory.
loan_use: To buy small household items to sell to his customers

description: Hilda is a struggling single parent. She is 32 years old and has one child. She sells weavons, hair extensions, and cosmetics in her shop. Hilda is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more weavons, hair extensions, and cosmetics to sell. She says "Thank you."
loan_use: To purchase weavons, hair extensions, and cosmetics

description:
Eva is the leader of a 5-member group. She is 35 years old, married, with four children aged between 3 and 10. Her children go to school. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she is living with three adults. Eva takes care of two additional family members. There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala.

Eva runs a restaurant and so she incurs transport costs to and from shopping. She sells to an average of 40 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include medication, rent for her business, and feeding the family.

Besides this restaurant, Eva sells charcoal. She has been in this business for the last nine years. Eva has been with MCDT for over five years and is servicing her eighteenth loan, working with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more commodities for her business. Eva is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning permanent business premises.
loan_use: To buy more things for her restaurant

description:
La señora Juana pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nueva Generación 2000”  que esta ubicado en el distrito D. Ilave, Provincia D. El Collao, Departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 62 años D. edad, está casada y es madre D. 01 hijo ya independiente, ella no tiene estudios,  vive en la Calle Ramón Castilla.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 9 años,  su primer préstamo fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que invirtió en su negocio D. venta confección D. polleras (faldas típicas D. la Región).

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo D. S/. 2000.00 Nuevos soles, para poder comprar tela D. diferentes colores y así pueda elaborar más polleras las mismas que pondrá en venta.

Su mayor deseo es seguir trabajando para solventar sus gastos.

A ella le gustan las reuniones y las charlas recibidas por el personal D. Manuela Ramos.
description_translated:
Ms. Juana H. is a member of the “Nueva Generación 2000” Microfinance Institute, located in the Ilave district of the El Collao province, department of Puno. She is a 62-year-old married mother with 1 independent child. She received no schooling and lives on Ramón Castilla Street.

She has been working with the Manuela Ramos movement for 9 years. She invested her first 300.00 PEN loan in her pollera (regional skirt) business.

At this time, she needs a 2,000.00 PEN loan so that she can purchase different-colored fabric and make more skirts to sell.

Her greatest wish is to continue working so that she can cover her personal expenses.

She likes the meetings and chats that the Manuela Ramos personnel gives.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase fabric to make traditional skirts

description:
Ganbaatar S., 44, is a married man who has three children aged between 7-20. His family lives in a "ger" (nomadic housing tent) district in Arhangay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. He has been running a sales business related to livestock, traveling to neighboring provinces and purchasing raw materials. He has a Russian vehicle that is used for his business. He drives around the countryside to purchase wool, cashmere, leather and furs directly from local herders at a cheap prices. Then he transport these raw materials to the center of the province to sell to retailers at wholesale prices.

Sometime he goes to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city, to sell raw materials for higher prices. With the profit he has been building a house on the plot of land he owns. His eldest daughter Narangarav, 20, is a university student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. Second child Mendgarav, 18, is just graduating from high school and is planning to enroll in university this year.

Ganbaatar is working hard to complete the building of a house for his family needs and to save small amounts for his two children’s tuition. With this loan, he plans to purchase wool and cashmere at cheap prices.
loan_use: To purchase wool and cashmere for his business

description: Taiba is 30 years old and married with 4 children.She sells cooked foods and she loves this business. She hopes for the loan amount of N 60,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

description: Mrs. Isedra E. is 46 years old and lives at Libertad Bajo, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is blessed with 4 children. Her husband is a farmer and lends a hand in farming specifically in corn production, which is their primary activity. \r\nShe is a member of Paglaum MPC since June 2006. Now she is applying for Php 8,000.00 intended to buy farm fertilizers and pesticides. She has many plans for the future -- to buy a carabao to toil the land, build a simple concrete house and be able to send their children to school and finish a degree.\r\n
loan_use: to purchase fertilizer and pesticides for the corn

description: Maritza tiene 24 años, vive con su pareja y padre de su bebé de pocos meses de nacido, en su casa propia. Se dedica a la venta de cosméticos desde hace más de un año para poder cubrir los gastos de su hogar, su pareja estudia y trabaja a la vez y ella quiere aportar también con los gastos de su hogar para brindarle a su bebé lo mejor. Lo bueno de su trabajo es que puede realizarlo en su casa sin tener que salir y descuidar a su hijo, el cual requiere de muchos cuidados ya que aún es muy pequeño. Las ventas son buenas, pues con su gran carisma logra vender entre sus vecinas muchos productos, resultándole muy rentable su negocio, el cual va creciendo poco a poco. Maritza espera tener una gran tienda donde pueda ofrecer con mayor comodidad su mercadería, sabe que si le pone más dedicación y esfuerzo logrará cumplir todas sus metas para sacar adelante a su familia. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, espera que le vaya muy bien como en sus anteriores préstamos, en los cuales ella y sus compañeras fueron muy puntuales. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de cosméticos para aumentar su stock y así lograr mejores ingresos para su hogar.
description_translated:
Maritza is 24 years old and she lives with her partner, the father of her baby who is a few months old, in their own home. She has sold cosmetics for a living for more than a year in order to meet the household costs. She partner studies and works as well and she also wanted to support him with their outgoings to give their baby the best. The good thing about her work is that she can do it from home without having to go out with her son, who requires a lot of care as he is still very young. Her slaes are good as she is very charismatic when it comes to sales, which means that her business is very profitable and is growing bit by bit. Maritza hopes to have a big store where she can offer her produce more comfortably, and she knows that with some more dedication and effort she will accomplish all his goals and her family will move forward. This is her third credit with MFP and she hopes it goes well as her previous loans with which she and her colleagues were very punctual. With this loan she will buy larger quantities of cosmetics to increase her stock and thereby increaseher earnings for her home.\r\n

\r\n

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To increase her merchandise/Incremento de mercadería

description:
Salvador G. (cachucha blanca)es originario de una comunidad rural llamada La Ica, a una hora del puerto de VeraC., con una población de no mas de 600 habitantes.

Don Chava como lo conocen en su comunidad se dedica a la cria y venta de borregos. El estuvo trabajando en los Estados Unidos cerca de 6 años, en un inicio en el campo y despues en un restaurante. El tuvo que volver a su país ya que enviudo y tuvo que hacerse cargo de sus 5 hijos, de los cuales aun tres de ellos viven con el.

Don Chava inicio con esta actividad hace 2 años. Es por esto que solicita el credito para comprar alimento para sus boregos. Su meta es poder tener un terreno propio, ya que en el lugar donde los tiene actualmente es prestado.

Es integrante de un grupo llamado las abejitas el cual esta conformado por 4 hombres y 8 mujeres los cuales entre otras cosas se dedican a labores como cría - venta de borregos, antojitos regionales, venta de productos por catalogo y comercio en general.

Ellos solicitan un crédito de $53,000 para poder invertirlo en sus diferentes actividades y poder seguir mejorando su calidad de vida y las de sus familias.

Los otros integrantes del grupo y sus actividades son:

Irma B. H....venta de antojitos regionales
Rosa M. C. ROSA...productos naturistas
Juan Miguel L. M....papeleria
Adriana S. C. ...venta de ropa
Jesus N. M....abarrotes
Martha G. S....venta de ropa
Araceli N. A....venta de ropa
Simon M. T....cria de puercos y pollos
Sandra P. C....venta de ropa
Amada G. P....venta de plastico
Eva C. J....venta de puercos
description_translated:
Salvador G. (white cap) is from a rural community called La Ica. La Ica is a small town with only about 600 people located an hour from the port in VeraC.. Don Chava, as members of his community know, raises and sells sheep. He worked in the United States for 6 years first on a farm and then in a restaurant. He had to return to his country when he became a widow and had to take care of his five children. Three of his children still live with him. Don Chava has been raising sheep for two years and this is the reason he is asking for a loan. He wants to buy food for his sheep. His goal is to have his own land since he is keeping his sheep on land that is borrowed right now. He is a member of a group called “Las Abejitas” that is made up of four men and eight women. The members of this group make a living by raising and selling sheep, selling regional foods, selling products from catalogs, and general commerce. They are asking for a loan of $3,975 to invest in different businesses to be able to continue improving their quality of life and that of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Alimento para Borregos
borrower_names: Araceli, Sandra, Eva, Simon, Irma, Jesus, Adriana, Martha, Salvador, Juan Miguel, Amada, Rosa
borrower_genders: female, female, female, male, female, male, female, female, male, male, female, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, false, true, true, true, true, true, true, false

description:
Plan D. Lucha consists of a group of entrepreneurs in the small town of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic who are seeking a micro loan. The members of this group have successfully completed four loans and are eager to continue to grow their businesses with another loan.


Mercedez is the leader of this group and runs a fruit stand. With this loan, she would like to buy more bananas so she can make more guineo, a popular local dish of fried green bananas.


Mercedez lives with her husband and four children aged 20, 17, 15, and 14. She says that her family has been blessed with good health and she would like to grow her business in order to continue providing a healthy life for her children.


Mercedez is an inspiring example of the opportunities that micro loans give the members of this community.
loan_use: To buy more bananas

description:
La señora Rosario, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Paz II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 34 años, 03 hijos pequeños que aun dependen de ella.

Su carácter emprendedor y el amor a su familia le motivaron a iniciar su propio negocio, junto con su esposo brindando el servicio de movilidad, que poco a poco fueron aumentando y ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad. 
 
En la actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio de movilidad, tiene sus clientes fijos que a diario les brinda el servicio. 

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,500.00, invertirá comprando 02 llantas, como repuestos nuevos, para su motokar. Parte del Dinero también lo invertirá comprando.

Rosarito, desea seguir adelante y cumplir sus sueños y metas, porque es una mujer que cuando se propone algo lo cumple. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos,  por ayudarla a contribuir con sus sueños y metas.
description_translated:
Sra. Rosario belongs to the La Paz II community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of San Martin. She is 34 years old, partnered and has 3 young children still in her care.

Her enterprising nature and love for her family led her to start her own taxi business, a business that she operates with her husband. They've been adding to the business bit by bit and gaining experience at this particular line of work. She's still in business and now has a regular set of customers for whom she provides service.

With the loan of S/.1,500 [1,500 soles], she will buy 2 tires, for spares, for her "motokar". [Parte del Dinero tambien lo invertira comprando.]

Rosarito wants to continue pushing ahead, fulfilling her dreams and meeting her goals, because she is a woman who knows what she wants and goes and gets it. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos movemento for helping her with her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy two tires for motokar business.

description:
Roberto E. is a rice farmer from Sta. Josefa Agusan Del Sur, a poor community in Mindanao. His livelihood is farming rice and raising ducks. He is tilling a 1-hectare farm. He is the father of four children, and he works very hard to support his family’s daily needs. Now, he would like to improve the size of his harvest. He is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and to fulfill other farming needs. The loan will really help him achieve better yields. 

CEVI helps small farmers sustain their livelihood. CEVI provides clients with not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.
loan_use: Farming necessities

description:
Elvie G. is managing a small parcel land that is used as a rice farm. She is 39 years old and has three children. Her ultimate goal in life is to send all her children to school. She is doing her best to support the needs of her family.

She wants to apply for a loan of PHP 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and other farming necessities that will improve her harvest. If she improves the harvest she will earn a lot of money and be able to easily buy the things her family needs. 

The program that CEVI offers has helped many farmers sustain their livelihoods. CEVI provides not just loans, but also training and insurance coverage services.
loan_use: Farming necessities

description: Abena is a widowed mother with seven children. Three are in school and the rest are working to earn a living. Abena is a 56-year-old trader. She prepares and sells pastries like doughnuts. She has been in the business for ten years now. People come to buy from her to resell and she sells the remaining at a stand in the community where she lives. She says prices of flour, margarine and other needed ingredients have gone up significantly. She requests the loan to buy bags of sugar, flour, margarine etc. to remain in business. She wants to save part of her profit for her children's educational needs. She belongs to the community group called ’Doduo’ which means ‘Plenty or More’
loan_use: To buy more ingredients

description:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha:  Mercedes del Carmen Sánchez, María Adilia L. R., Darling del Rosario L. P., Jessenia del Carmen Muñoz García y Juan José plarte R..

El grupo solidario Fuerza en Cristo del señor son originarios de la ciudad de Masaya en la comarca Valle de la Laguna, tienen varios ciclos de trabajar con Adim porque sienten que es una institución que ha confiado en ellos, expresan que se sienten como parte de la familia de Adim. 

Doña Mercedes del Carmen se dedica a la venta de verduras  en el mercado de masaya, ella tiene años de tener esta actividad ha sabido como es el giro de su negocio, expresa que ella ha visto como en cada préstamo le va quedando un mayor inventario en el negocio. 
Doña María Adilia L. R. vende ambientadores para todos los usos, vende ambulante en el mercado de Granada, tiene cinco hijos y le ayuda su esposo con los gastos del hogar, con el préstamo compra esencias para combinarlas y vender en líquido estos ambientadores.
Doña Darling del Rosario L. P. ella es una madre joven de 1 hijo pequeño en edad escolar . Su esposo es albañil y le ayuda con los gastos del niño.Ella elabora delantales y los vende en los diferentes mercados del país, los entrega en lugares fijos, todo lo que ha logrado le anima a seguir trabajando y quedando bien en Adim, esto se lo hace saber a su grupo y por eso se encarga de ir a dejar el abono para garantizar la puntualidad. Ella invierte en telas, encajes para adornar los delantales y está haciendo diseños nuevos.

Doña  Jessenia del Carmen Muñoz vende productos perecederos como frutas y verduras en el mercado de Masaya, ella invirtió el crédito en la compra de perecederos como lechugas y zanahorias, para ofrecer más productos a sus clientes, ella sueña tener comodidades en su vivienda y tener mayores ingresos. 

Don Juan José P. se dedica a la venta de ropa en el mercado de Masaya, él vende en un puesto fijo donde ofrece ropa para caballeros y damas, el préstamo lo usó para comprar pantalones de Jeans que tienen mucha demanda.

El grupo espera siempre tener el financiamiento de Adim para sus actividades económicas y asimismo ser puntuales en sus pagos.
description_translated:
Photo from left to right: Mercedes del Carmen Sánchez, María Adilia L. R., Darling del Rosario L. P., Jessenia del Carmen Muñoz García y Juan José plarte R.. The group Fuerza en Cristo are natives of the city of Masaya located in the Laguna Valley. They have worked with Adim for various cycles because they feel that it is an institution that has trusted them. They express that they feel part of the Adim family. Mercedes del Carmen is dedicated to selling produce in the Masaya market. She has done this for years and knows how her business runs. She says that she has seen how with each loan she gets more inventory for her business. María Adilia L. R. sells air fresheners for all uses. She sells on foot in the Granada market. She has five children and her husband helps her with the bills. With this loan, she'll buy essential oils to combine them and sell, in liquid, those air fresheners. Darling del Rosario L. P. is a young mother to one small child who is school age. Her husband is a bricklayer and he helps with the family expenses. She makes aprons and sells them in different markets in the country. She sells them in fixed places. Everything that she has achieved encourages her to keep working and remain in good standing with Adim. Her group know this and, as a result, she is in charge of making payments to guarantee they'll be on time. She will invest in fabric, lace to adorn the aprons, and she is making new designs. Jessenia del Carmen Muñoz sells perishable products like fruit and produce in the Masaya market. She invests her loan in the purchase of perishables like lettuce and carrots in order to offer more products to her customers. She dreams of having amenities in her home and to have greater earnings. Juan José P. is dedicated to selling clothing in the Masaya market. He sells from a fixed spot where he offers clothes for men and women. He uses the loan to purchase jeans, which are in great demand. The group hopes to always have the Adim financing for their ecomomic activities and, at the same time, to be punctual with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Material for making aprons and to purchase fruit and produce to sell.
borrower_names: JUAN JOSE, JESSENIA DEL CARMEN, MARIA ADILIA, DARLYN DEL ROSARIO, MERCEDES DEL CARMEN

description: Lucia tiene 54 años y junto a su esposo tratan de brindarle las mejores condiciones de vida a su único hijo, por ello construyeron su casa propia donde viven cómodamente. Cuando terminó la construcción de ésta pensó en instalar un negocio, comenzó vendiendo bebidas durante el verano, pero con el tiempo las personas demandaban muchas cosas más, lo cual fue el inicio de su bodega. Esta actividad la viene realizando hace 5 años trabajando desde las 6 de la mañana aseando su local, arreglando sus productos y preparándose para atender a sus clientes con una gran sonrisa, pues más importante que vender en demasía es brindar una atención adecuada a sus clientes ya que esa actitud garantizará el desarrollo y rentabilidad de su negocio, nos dice. Para un futuro cercano, Lucia quiere ampliar su tienda acondicionando un espacio adicional en su casa. Ella considera que el trabajo que realiza en su banco comunal es primordial, puesto que lo realiza en comunión con todas las integrantes de su grupo, utilizando estos créditos como una alternativa de desarrollo. Para Lucia este es su 13vo préstamo con Microfinanzas PRISMA. Los 3000 soles que solicita los usará para la ampliación del local de su tienda.
description_translated:
Lucia is 54 years old and, together with her husband, is trying to provide better living conditions for their only son. That is why they built their own house, where they are now living comfortably. When they finished constructing their home Lucia thought about setting up a business. She began by selling beverages during the summer, but soon her customers were asking for many more items. This led to Lucia establishing her grocery store. She has been involved in this activity for 5 years. She begins work at 6 in the morning by tidying up the store, arranging her products, and getting ready to attend to her customers with a big smile. Lucia tells us that one of the secrets to selling a lot of products is to provide suitable attention to her customers, and having that attitude will guarantee her business’s development and profitability. In the near future Lucia wants to expand her store, setting up an additional space in her home. She thinks that the work she does in her communal bank is very important, since she works together with all of the members of her group, using the loans as a good development alternative. This is Lucia’s 13th loan with Kiva partner Microfinanzas PRISMA. She will use the 3000 soles she is requesting to expand the premises of her store.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Expanding her store

description: Cirenia E. is from the town of Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old, married, and has five adult children. Cirenia owns and operates a hog-fattening business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2001, Cirenia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Cirenia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feeds and other supplies. This loan will be her 11th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To purchase feeds and other supplies for her livestock

description:
Hardworking and industrious, Norma P. is 66 years old, married with one child, and presently lives at Macabayao, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental.

Norma joined Paglaum in April 2008 to secure financial assistance for her sari-sari store to buy additional stock such as laundry items, seasonings, goodies, toiletries, drinks and other household items. She aims to have a successful business with a concrete store and have her child finish a college degree and have a good future.
loan_use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

description:
Fatima D. is from the village of Poblacion 4, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Fatima is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Fatima owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Fatima has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Fatima joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fatima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4500 PHP from GDMPC. Fatima is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Fatima from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: to invest in expanding the business

description:
Foto De izquierda a derecha: Lester de los Angeles Gaitán Gaitán, Angela del Socorro Téllez y Fanny del Carmen López Tórrez.

Este grupo es originario del barrio Monte Fresco de la ciudad de masaya, son perswonas trabajadoras y bien conocidas entre ellos.

Don Lester de los Angeles es un joven señor que se dedica a la venta de esquimos de forma ambulante, vende en el mercado y en los barrios de Masaya, hace esta actividad desde muy joven y cuando se casó se dedicó totalmente a este negocio porque no encontraba trabajo, ahora tiene muchos clientes y de esto mantiene a su familia que está compuesta de cinco hijos y su esposa. Sueña con poder darle educación a sus hijos, ellos estudian en la escuela cercana a su casa.Es el coordinador del grupo para este ciclo.

Doña Angela del Socorro tiene una pequeña pulpería en su casa, con lo que ayuda a su esposo con los gastos, tiene muchos años de experiencia, sus hijos le ayudan a atender la venta, están en edades adolescentes y dos pequeños. Ella sueña con poder mejorar su casa.

Doña Fanny del Carmen vende quesillos de forma ambulante, sale a vender a otros departamentos del país, compra estos quesillos en el mercado de Masaya, ofrece su producto a  buen precio y por eso sus ventas se han incrementado, el crédito lo ocupó para comprar mas quesillos y tortillas.
Tiene como meta mejorar su casa para darle mejores condiciones a su hijo.
description_translated:
Photo from left to right: Lester de los Angeles Gaitán Gaitán, Angela del Socorro Téllez y Fanny del Carmen López Tórrez. This group is from the Monte Fresco neighborhood in the city of Masaya. They are hard working people who know each other very well. Lester de los Angeles is a young man who works as a street vendor selling ice cream sandwiches. He sells in the market and the Masaya neighborhoods. He has been doing this since he was very young. When he got married he worked at this full time because he could not find other work. He now has lots of customers. This is how he supports his family, which consists of five children and his wife. He dreams of being able to give his children an education. His children go to a school near their house. He is the coordinator of the group for this cycle. Angela de Socorro has a small convenience store in her house, which is how she helps her husband with the household expenses. She has many years of experience. Her children help her with the sales. They are adolescents and two are small. She dreams of being able to improve her house. Fanny del Camren sells cheese as a street vendor. She sells in other departments of the country. She buys the cheese in the Masaya market. She sells her products at a good price, and her sales have been increasing. She used the loan to buy more cheese and tortillas. Her goal is to improve her house in order to give her son better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Buy ice cream sandwiches, cheese, and other things
borrower_names: LESTER DE LOS ANGELES, ANGELA DEL SOCORRO, FANNY DEL CARMEN

description:
Foto De izquierda a derecha :  Juana María A. M., Sandra del Socorro J. Velásquez  y  Eugenia Martínez.

Doña Juana María es comerciante de sandalias de mujer, ofrece en todos los estilos, ella comercializa en los departamentos de Rivas, Managua y Masaya. Le ayuda su esposo con los gastos de la casa, trabaja en una zona franca. Tiene a su cargo dos hijos. Sueña con mejorar su casa y dar un mejor nivel de vida a sus hijos.

Doña Sandra del Socorro es la coordinadora del grupo, es persona muy responsable y líder del grupo. Se dedica a la venta de ropa interior y cosméticos, tiene muchos clientes que le piden encargos para sus hijos y familia. El préstamo lo ocupa en comprar ropa por docena en el mercado Oriental de Managua, compra ropa de mujer y de niño porque es la que mas vende.
Ella sueña con mejorar algunas partes de su casa y tener mejores ingresos.

Eugenia Martínez vende zapatos de forma ambulante, le ayuda su hijo que ya es joven, se dividen zonas de los departamentos para vender más, ella compra el calzado en los talleres de Masaya a buen precio, tiene muchos clientes. Su esposo le ayuda con los gastos del hogar porque trabaja como obrero en una zona franca.
Ella sueña con poder tener mías clientes para su producto y ayudar a su hijo a estudiar
description_translated:
Photo from left to right: Juana María A. M., Sandra del Socorro J. Velásquez and Eugenia Martínez.
Juana María sells women’s sandals in all styles. She works in the Rivas, Managua and Masaya districts. Her husband helps her cover household expenses and works in a free trade zone; they have two children. She dreams of making improvements on her home and improving her children’s quality of life.
Sandra del Socorro is the group coordinator. She is a very responsable person and leads the group. She sells underwear and cosmetics, and has many customers who make orders for their children and families. She is using the loan to purchase garments by the dozen in Managua’s Oriental market. She buys women’s and children’s clothing because they are the most profitable. She dreams of making improvements on parts of her house and of increasing her income.
Eugenia Martínez sells shoes as a street vendor and her son, who is already a young man, helps her. They divide up the district zones in order to make more sales. She buys footwear from the Masaya shoemakers at a good price, and has many customers. Her husband helps her pay the bills because he works as a labourer in a free trade zone. She dreams of having more customers and of supporting her son’s studies.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase clothing and shoes to sell as street vendors
borrower_names: EUGENIA, Juana María, SANDRA DEL SOCORRO

description:
Mrs. Gemma M. of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, is 19 years old, married to a fisherman, and has one child. She has been a member of Paglaum MPC since July 2008 and is engaged in fishing.

Having completed her 2nd loan, she is requesting a new loan of Php 10,000 for the repair of their fishing boat. The increased profit will enable them to send their child to school and allow them to have a decent life.
loan_use: To repair their fishing boat

description: Armie G. is from the town of Sinian, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. Armie owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily raising chickens for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over thirteen years and earns approximately 3,000.00 PHP a month. In 2007, Armie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Armie is requesting a new loan of 3,000.00 PHP which will be used as capital for her rice production. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To be used as capital for her rice production

description:
Alicia J. resides at Manil, Leon B. Postigo. She is forty-one years old and married to Jaime, a fisherman. She has four children: three of them are helping in generating an income. Her daughter, Liza, is her companion in running their business.

Alicia started her dried-fish vending and fish selling business in 1995 and it has served them well as their primary source of income. She sells her dried fish thrice a week during "tabo" or market day.

She commenced her membership in Paglaum in November 2008. She shows active participation in the micro-finance program. She is now applying for her first loan in the cooperative. She is very optimistic that such loan will help in developing her business.
loan_use: To use as additional capital for her fish-vending business
town_name: Sindangan-Manil, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga del No

description:
Isabel es socia del Banco Comunal Suni que significa Abundante en quechua.
Isabel es conviviente, tiene 39 años y 2 hijos, Isabel vende comida típica en la feria de platos típicos, actividad que realiza los días sábados y domingos con la ayuda de su esposo y otro ayudante.
Isabel necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, fideo, papa, maíz, ají.
Los sueños de Isabel son comprar un terreno para la construcción de su casa y tener una tienda estable.
description_translated:
Isabel is a member of the communal bank “Suni” which means “Abundant” in Quechua. Isabel lives with her partner, is 39 years old, and has two children. Isabel sells traditional food in the typical food market on Saturdays and Sundays. Her husband helps her and she has an assistant. Isabel needs a loan of 1,500 soles to buy rice, spaghetti, potatoes, corn, and chili pepper. Isabel has dreams of buying some land to build a house on and have a store in a stable place.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Para la compra de arroz, fideo, papa, maíz, ají.

description:
Elizabeth is 27 years old, married, and the mother of three children. Currently all her children are in school. She lives with her husband, who is a professional tailor who sews all forms of dresses.

Elizabeth owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, etc. It is through this business that she is supporting all her children in school.

Elizabeth deems it a big opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by customers. With her six years trading experienced she wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc., to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve sales through a customer satisfaction approach to enable her to save more for her children’s education.

Elizabeth belongs to the village bank called ‘“Nyame Ndaye” which means “God Never Sleeps”. She would be grateful for your assistance.
loan_use: To buy more items for her grocery shop

description:
Roberta D. is from the village of Katipunan. She is 51 years old. Roberta is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Roberta owns & operates a business raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Roberta has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Roberta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roberta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Roberta is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Roberta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her
family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

description:
Abiba is 38 years old, married, and the mother with seven children. Two of them are currently in school. She lives in her husband’s house at Sefwi in the western region of Ghana.

Abiba works very hard to support her husband to provide her children’s basic needs. She is a food vendor who sells rice and stew in the community where she lives. She started her operation about twenty years ago in taking care of her entire family.

Abiba’s food production is on a low scale because of inadequate funds to support her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more meat, vegetables and bags of rice to increase her ability to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and raise more income to support and provide for her family and to finance her children’s education.
loan_use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat, firewood etc.

description:
Vida A. is a 34 year old woman. She is single and the mother with two children. She lives in the family house at Sefwi in the western region of Ghana.

Vida is a food vendor and serves food like rice and stew in the community where she lives. She prepares a tasty meal and, because of that, many people buy from her stand.

Vida says that demand for food is on the high side but she does not have adequate funds for expansion. She wants to use the loan to buy more meat and bags of rice to increase her ability to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support her children and finance their education.
loan_use: To buy bags of rice, fish, meat, vegetables etc. for her business

description: Hannah K. is 30 years old. She is an unmarried young woman. Hannah has been selling eggs for the past five years. She obtains her supply of eggs from farming communities and supplies them to her customers in Accra. Hannah’s customers are mostly food vendors and people who retail to other customers. She wants to use her loan to buy stocks of eggs to cater to the demands of her customers. She wants to use the proceeds from her operation to add the sale of tomatoes, which she believes, will give her additional income.\r\n
loan_use: To buy eggs

description:
Janet A., forty years old, is a married woman with four children. Janet enjoys selling from which she obtains her daily source of livelihood. She is a petty trader who supplies margarine to bakers in her community and other customers in other parts of the country. She has been in business for some time now and, with good customer relations, she has won many customers.

However, Janet buys her supplies on credit at a relatively high price due to lack of adequate working capital. With this loan, she wants to purchase margarine in bulk to serve her customers.
loan_use: To buy margarine in bulk

description:
FELIPA H. P.
Es la Presidenta D. la Alcom las Violetas, vive en el  AA. HH Villa Violeta MZ H LT 20 distrito D. Comas – Lima, tiene 56 años, es separada D. su esposo, tiene 4 hijos que son independientes, tiene una  nietecita D. 3 añitos D. edad que esta bajo su responsabilidad, es quien le da fuerzas para seguir adelante dice Felipa,  tiene una bodega en su domicilio que ya esta funcionando hace 4 años que poco a poco con los prestamos que  ha ido incrementando en EDAPROSPO ha   mejorado en lo económico y personal, el dinero desembolsado S/ 1,000.00 lo invertirá para surtir su bodega y con lo que le sobra seguirá haciendo mejoras en su casa.
 
La Alcom las Violetas esta conformada por 10 integrantes esta en el III ciclo, ha desembolsado el monto D. s/ 8,400.00, cada socio se dedica a las diferentes actividades como son vta D. CDs, jugo D. naranja, confecciones, vta D. golosinas entre otros, son clientes muy puntuales, responsables se apoyan entre ellos no permiten que caiga ninguno, se sienten identificados con EDAPROSPO porque les  ayudo a mejorar no solo en sus negocios sino también en cuanto a lo económico y personal.  

La  meta D. la Sra. Felipa es reabrir su  Internet que lo cerró por problemas económicos.
description_translated:
Felipa H. P. is President of the Alcom la Violetas, and lives in the district of Comas, in Lima, Peru. She is 56 years old, separated from her husband, and has four independent children. She is responsible for caring for her three year old neice, which she she says provides her with the strength necessary to move forward. For the last four years she has operated a store from her home and, little by little, and with the help of loans from EDAPROSPO, she has improved both her economic and personal status. She will invest the majority of the loan of S/ 1,000.00 [approximately US $340] to further supply her store and, with any leftover money, will improve her home. The Alcom las Violetas is comprised of 10 members, is in its third cycle, and has until now spent a total amount of S/ 8,400.00. Each member is dedicated to a different activity such as the sale of CDs, orange juice and candy, among others. They are very punctual and responsible clients that help each other out and do not allow any individual member to fail. They reached out to EDAPROSPO because the organization supports them not only in improving negotiations but also to improve economic and personal issues. Ms Felipa's goal is to have Internet access again, which was shut down due to economic difficulties.

Translated from Spanish by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To purchase merchandise
borrower_names: CRISANTO, FELIPA, DORIS, ROSA LINA, MERCEDES, EDWIN ABRAHAM, ROSA ESTELA, LUZ AMERICA, IRWIN FELIX, JACKELINE SUSANA
borrower_genders: male, female, female, female, female, male, female, female, male, female
borrower_pictured: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

description:
Eldith R. A. is a member of the communal bank “Cesar Vallejo” and lives in the city of Pucallpa. She sells clothing and shoes, most of which are ordered in advance by her customers, and also jewelry, cosmetics and perfumes.

Eldith has been working with Manuela Ramos for 11 years and used her first loan to purchase cigarettes for sale. When this business did not go well, Eldith switched to her current enterprise of selling clothing and shoes. During the day, Eldith has a job caring for the three-year-old twins of a neighbor. In the evenings, she heads out to sell her goods in nearby neighborhoods where she has regular clients who have known her a long time. Eldith will use this loan of 1500 Nuevos Soles to invest in more goods for her business.

Eldith is married but separated and has three adult children. Two of her sons still live at home but have their own jobs and no longer depend on their mother. Eldith very much enjoys working. Loans from Manuela Ramos have helped her to advance her business, which dropped off during a recent period when Eldith was ill, but has since been recovering well.
loan_use: To buy clothing and shoes for sale

description:
Mma is 48 years old and she is married with four children. Three are in school and one is working. She is living with her husband in a family house at Sefwi in the Western region of Ghana. She is supportive, determined and above all very hardworking. 

She is a petty trader who trades in cereals like bags of maize, beans, millet, groundnuts etc. She takes delivery of her stock from Tamale in the northern region of Ghana.

Her kids are very proud of her because of the enormous contribution she makes in the home. Selling of foodstuffs has enabled her to rent a store in the market place where she sells to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of maize, millet, beans and groundnuts to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children’s education. She is grateful for your assistance.
loan_use: To buy products in bulk

description: La Señora Cinthia María C. tiene la edad de 44 años. Cinthia esta casada con Juan. Tienen 1 hijo a su cargo. La actividad económica es una pulperia. Hace más de 4 años que se dedica a este negocio. Por lo que inicio con muy pocos prodcutos ya que no ofrecia una gran variedad, pero con el muy poco dinero que recogia de sus ganancias logro aumentar su pulperia, y con la yuda de los financiamientos que fueron de gran ayuda para iniciar este negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de granos basicos,jabones, detergentes y golosinas. El sueño de Cinthia es diversificar en sus productos y convertir su pequeña pulperia en una distribuidoa.
description_translated:
Mrs. Cinthia María C. is 44 years old and married to Juan. They have 1 dependent child. She owns a grocery store and has been in business for more than 4 years. When she started, she had few products and did not offer great variety, but with the little money she saved from her earnings was able to open her business.

The loan she is requesting will be used as working capital to buy basic grains, soaps, detergents and candy. Cinthia dreams of diversifying her products and converting her small grocery store into a wholesale outlet.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Working capital

description: Joyce is a 45-year-old married mother of six. Four of her children attend school while the other two work. She is a food vendor and sells rice with gravy stew in her community. She also sells meat pies. Joyce started her operation about ten years ago in order to take care of her home. Her food production is on a low scale because she has inadequate funds to support her business. She wants to use this loan to buy more meat, vegetables, and bags of rice so she can produce her goods in larger quantities and increase her efficiency. Joyce believes this will help expand her business so she can raise more income to support and provide for her family and to finance her children's education.
loan_use: To buy more vegetables, meat, bags of rice, and firewood.

description:
Michael is a 38 year old man with 2 children. The older child is 6 and the younger is 3. Both children are able to attend a private school - a testament to Michael's hard work since private schools can be very expensive in Liberia. \r\n

\r\nMichael's main business is selling scratch cards and helping people to charge their phones. He also sells rice from the same shop. Sometimes to attract customers Michael gives his customers a bit of rice to go along with their scratch cards. He explains that this makes the customers come back to his shop more!
loan_use: Items for resale in general store

description: Dominga tiene 35  años, vive con su esposo y sus hijos en su casa propia. Desde hace más de 12 años se dedica a la fabricación de tejas y ladrillos, junto a su esposo trabaja incansablemente desde tempranas horas de la madrugada para preparar el horno que cose las tejas y ladrillos que termina de modelar por la tarde, posteriormente los deposita en el horno para la cocción durante 3 días aproximadamente. Este esfuerzo que realiza ella y su esposo tiene su recompensa cuando llegan a vender sus ladrillos y teas por millares  en las ferias de construcción de su ciudad. Para el futuro, Dominga desea tener su propio terreno que será su fábrica permanente, pues por el momento alquila el terreno. Esta es la séptima vez que tiene un préstamo en MFP y está muy contenta de ser parte de su banco comunal, donde viene trabajando hace varios años, el cual es para ella un espacio de crecimiento personal. El dinero que está solicitando será destinado para la compra de los insumos necesarios para la fabricación de sus tejas, los cuales son aserrín y leña, debido a que en esta época del año es donde aumentan las ventas.
description_translated:
Dominga is 35 years old. She lives with her husband and children in a home of their own. For over 12 years now their livelihood has been making and selling bricks and slate. She and her husband work tirelessly starting early in the morning to prepare the furnace which they finish in the afternoon. They then put the bricks and slate in the furnace and wait approximately 3 days for the finished product. All the effort they put in their business pays off when they sell their bricks at cities nearby. In the future, Dominga would like to have her own land for her furnace instead of having to rent from someone else. This is the seventh time Dominga has a loan from MFP. She is very happy to be part of her community's bank with which she has done business for several years and where she feels serves her as a space for personal growth. The money she is requesting will be used to buy production materials such as wood and sawdust to take advantage of the season's high demand for bricks and slate.

Translated from Spanish by Linda Zamora, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: Purchase of raw materials

description:
Mr. Seoung V., 43, is a villager of Ang Krong District of Siem Reap Province. He is married man with two teenage children. One of his sons works in construction and provides his income to help meet his family’s daily foods needs. 

His wife, Lim Sovann (shown in the picture), age 40, is a vegetable seller.  

Mr. Seoung V. plants vegetable and fruit crops on a plot of land behind his house. He sells his mature crops two months after he begins growing them. 

He is requesting a loan to purchase a motor to help reduce the family’s daily travel costs.
loan_use: Purchase a motor

description:
Irene S. is from the village of Danao. She is 30 years old, is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Irene owns & operates a fishing business; the main source of income comes from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Irene has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Irene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC, which she used to to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks & nets. Irene is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to expand the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Irene from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of  her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: to invest in expanding the business

description:
Violeta manages a typical village store in Palao Solana, Cagayan. She is 46 years old and married to Vicente, a farmer. Vicente also works as a carpenter in their community. They are blessed with three children who are all studying in high school and elementary. 

Violeta needs to expand her small business to assist her husband in providing for the needs of their family. They are helping one another and striving to have a better future for their children. Violeta is asking for a loan amounting to PHP 20,000. She will purchase additional items for her store, such as sacks of rice, soft drinks and other basic commodities. She earns an average daily income of PHP 500. She hopes to maintain the business and someday be able to develop it into a larger selling enterprise.
loan_use: Business Capital.

description:
Leonidas es socia del Banco Comunal Paloma.
Leonidas es soltera, tiene 46 años y 5 hijos, Leonidas viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde vende frutas y pollos para criar, y de las ferias compra cereales que vende en los diferentes mercados. Además Leonidas tiene un kiosco cerca del hospital en donde vende bebidas.
Leonidas necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de gaseosas, leche y papel.
Lo sueños de Leonidas son que sus hijos culminen sus estudios y salir adelante.
description_translated:
Leonidas is a member of the Paloma (The Dove) Communal Bank. She is 46 years of age, single and has five children. Leonidas travels to the different fairs in the region where she sells fruits and chickens for raising and breeding. She also buys grains at the fairs that she then sells in various markets. She also has a stand near the hospital where she sells beverages. Leonidas needs a loan of 1,000 Sols which will be used to buy carbonated drinks, milk and paper. She dreams of her children finishing their studies and being able to get ahead. Click Here to see her previous loan.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer
loan_use: To buy carbonated drinks, milk and paper.

description:
Dadeth T. is from the village of Mahayahay, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 22 years old. Dadeth is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Dadeth owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a sari-sari (general store). While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Dadeth has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Dadeth joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dadeth successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Dadeth is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Dadeth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to provide tuition for her children.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisher folks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
loan_use: To purchase additional products to sell

description:
La señora Julia Inés S. D. M. tiene 73 años D. edad, vive en el distrito D. Moche, provincia D. Trujillo, en el departamento D. la Libertad; Perú.
Ella estudió primaria completa, tiene 1 hijo que depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Julia tiene una bodega en la cual venD. insumos para la preparación D. alimentos y útiles D. escritorio. Cuando inició en Manuela Ramos tenía el mismo negocio pero sus ventas eran bajas, solo vendía golosinas y determinados útiles D. escritorio (cuadernos y lapiceros); con las ganas D. que su negocio crezca, empezó también con la venta D. frutas.
